fields.headline: The look of love
fields.trailText: 4 JulyMy boyfriend works across the room from me but he says he want to get a new job. Will he find new love at a new desk?
fields.body:
The problem

I have been involved with a colleague across the room for just under two years. Everyone knows but when we have problems I feel jealous if he flirts with female colleagues.

Now he wants to move jobs to get more money. I am worried that if I stop seeing him during the day he will forget about me and starting flirting with new and attractive females.

The solution

This is not so much a work problem as a relationship problem. I cannot help feel that it might actually be healthier for your relationship if your boyfriend did move to another company - so that you can stop gazing across the room at him and concentrate on your own work.

As far as your jealousy is concerned, I don't know whether it is unfounded or not. Is he really flirting, or just being friendly? Perhaps he does it deliberately to wind you up after a row. Either way, him being out of sight, if not out of mind, will mean that at least you can't see him. Then, at the end of the day, you either trust him, or you don't. And if you don't why are you still with him?

Of course, perhaps you are just a jealous person who can't bear to allow her man to talk to another woman. If this sounds like you, you will need a very understanding guy or else counselling to help you understand and work through your insecurities.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Luciano Berio II
fields.standfirst:
Luciano Berio II ****
Gainsborough Studios, London
fields.trailText:
Luciano Berio II ****
Gainsborough Studios, London
fields.body:
Images of beginning and ending dominated the second all-Berio concert of the Hoxton New Music Days. In a staged version of A-Ronne, the five singer-actors were dwarfed by a projection of a film by Tim Hopkins and Kate Brown that made references to the life of the Gainsborough Studios, a remarkable space where Hitchcock once made movies and which is soon to be turned into flats.

A-Ronne is an investigation of the shattered language of a poem by Eduardo Sanguineti. The text is a play around ideas of beginning, middle and end. Berio uses references to European languages and literature as the starting point for a "documentary" about the ceaselessly subtle processes of verbal communication. The poem is reduced to lines, words or syllables - even single letters. But there is nothing abstract about Berio's composition. He creates a vibrant, absurdist drama of dictators addressing party conferences, lovers in flagrante delicto, and a host of other characters and vignettes. The actors, dressed in 50s clothes, were vividly persuasive in conveying the sharply defined drama of A-Ronne; but sadly the film detracted from the power and intimacy of the performances.

Earlier, Berio's Agnus and Canticum Novissimi Testamenti were presented by the Manson Ensemble under Simon Bainbridge. Both pieces inhabit a world of shifting musical focus, in which words are chopped up and re-assembled, and instrumental textures distort and reform. Canticum Novissimi Testamenti - for an ensemble of clarinets, saxophones and voices expanded from the scoring of Agnus - is another Sanguineti setting. The poem speaks of death, but Berio's structure is a proliferating series of refrains and responses that suggests renewal. The instrumentalists and singers performed brilliantly in one of Berio's most intoxicating pieces.

fields.headline: Sell-off may save Sprint merger
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Analysts believe that WorldCom and Sprint may try to salvage their $115bn (£75.8bn) merger by selling off both telecoms companies' consumer long distance operations to appease global regulators.
fields.body:
Analysts believe that WorldCom and Sprint may try to salvage their $115bn (£75.8bn) merger by selling off both telecoms companies' consumer long distance operations to appease global regulators.

It is one option the companies are apparently considering, though they would retain the more lucrative business long distance arm. "I can say that it is not 100% locked and clearly over," a source close to the deal told the New York Times. "Over the next few days it will become more clear."

The US justice department said last week that it would file a lawsuit to block the WorldCom-Sprint merger as it may lead to higher prices, lower service quality and less innovation in the long distance market.

The European commission also expressed disapproval of the deal and both companies withdrew the merger proposal. WorldCom and Sprint rank second and third in the American long distance telephone market, behind AT&T. The three companies control about 80% of the market.

Bernard Ebbers, WorldCom's ambitious chief executive, may be prepared to sacrifice both companies' long distance assets to grab a strong foothold in the higher yielding mobile market, said analysts. The American consumer long distance market has become increasingly competitive making it less profitable for companies.

If a deal cannot be done between the US companies, Deutsche Telekom appears ready to step in and buy Sprint.

Some US senators yesterday expressed concern at the possibility of a bid by Deutsche Telekom. Their opposition was based on the law that prohibits foreign companies that are part-government owned from buying American companies. The German government has a 66% stake in Deustche Telekom.

fields.headline: Intelligent Finance steps up hostilities
fields.standfirst:
Halifax offshoot claims top interest rates

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Intelligent Finance, the Halifax's new internet and telephone bank, yesterday dramatically stepped up the online banking war by unveiling a portfolio of "market-leading" products and declaring that it aimed to sign up 1.6m customers in its first three years.
fields.body:
Intelligent Finance, the Halifax's new internet and telephone bank, yesterday dramatically stepped up the online banking war by unveiling a portfolio of "market-leading" products and declaring that it aimed to sign up 1.6m customers in its first three years.

The flagship product is a current account paying 5% - higher than internet rivals such as Smile and First-e - and it has set its standard variable mortgage rate at 6.8%, almost a full percentage point lower than the Halifax's own 7.74% rate.

Intelligent Finance claims to offer customers potential savings running into thousands of pounds because of what it says is a "unique" system of connecting products such as current accounts and personal loans, giving people the ability to offset savings against borrowings.

As a result, some people whose savings outstrip their home loan will be able to enjoy a 0% mortgage, while others will pay no interest on their credit card or personal loan, said the bank.

The operation opens for telephone business on July 14 and for internet applications 10 days later.

It has decided on a two-stage launch following the technical problems experienced by Abbey National's internet offering Cahoot when it went live last month.

The Halifax is investing £120m over two years in the venture, including £10m on an advertising campaign.

The internet offshoot has described its target customers as 40-year-old "ABC1s" with families as opposed to twenty- and thirtysomethings, though it has adopted the Fatboy Slim dance hit Right Here, Right Now as the theme music to its forthcoming television commercials to fit in with its "futuristic, upbeat" image, said the chief executive of Intelligent Finance, Jim Spowart.

He described the 5% rate on credit balances it is paying on its current account as the best available for a "full service" account (including a cheque book) in Britain, but this may be contested by Cahoot, which on Friday raised the rates on its current account to 4.5%-6.5%. However, the Intelligent Finance rate beats that paid by Smile and First-e.

Some commentators were struck by the similarity of Intelligent Finance's initial mortgage offering to the flagship home loan offered by Standard Life Bank, of which Mr Spowart was chief executive until last autumn.

Intelligent Finance's deal is a flexible home loan with a 1.5% discount for the first six months, while Standard Life Bank's is a flexible home loan with a 1% discount for six months.

Other products include a savings account paying up to 6.25%, a credit card with a 10.8% annual percentage rate, and a personal loan rate of 10.5% APR.

Customers of Intelligent Finance will be able to do their banking by phone, internet or Wap mobile phone. It has announced that the first 150,000 customers to open a current account or take out a credit card will receive a free Wap phone.

webTitle: Banks cave in on cash machine charges

fields.headline: Banks cave in on cash machine charges
fields.standfirst: MoneyUnlimited
fields.trailText: Three high street banks last night abandoned controversial plans to charge up to £1 to withdraw money from cash machines.
fields.body:
Three high street banks last night abandoned controversial plans to charge up to £1 to withdraw money from cash machines.

The embarrassing u-turn, by Barclays, Lloyds TSB and HSBC, was heralded as a victory for consumers and means that most of the 28,000 cash machines in the Link network will be free of charges from next year.

The banks had argued that the fees were needed to meet the cost of running the cash machine network. The proposed surcharges and "disloyalty fees" - penalties from the customers' own bank for using other cash machines - infuriated the government. In March, Tony Blair threatened banks and building societies with multimillion pound fines if they pressed ahead with plans to charge customers up to £2.50 to withdraw money.

Yesterday Barclays caved into public pressure over its charging plan, which had contributed to its poor image.

A year ago, Barclays said it wanted to introduce a £1 surcharge on rivals' customers who used its cash machines.

The move led to uproar within the Link cash machine network which finally agreed that surcharging could begin from 2001. The decision led to a torrent of negative publicity and pressure from government - and one by one the financial institutions caved in.

The first was Halifax, whose £1 charge for customers who use rivals' machines will be scrapped next year.

fields.headline: Intensity boiled down
fields.standfirst:
Jane Eyre ***
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
fields.trailText:
Jane Eyre ***
Everyman Theatre, Cheltenham
fields.body:
Condensing Jane Eyre into an 80-minute opera seems like an impossible task. But in Michael Berkeley's chamber opera, with its libretto by David Malouf, the story is boiled down to an intense psycho drama of the events at Rochester's country house, Thornfield.

The opera investigates the relationship between Rochester and Jane, as well as the terrible secret of Rochester's wife, locked away in the attic. In Music Theatre Wales's production, Mrs Rochester is onstage almost throughout the opera; laughing, cackling and cursing from an upstairs window. Her character is the most significant of Malouf and Berkeley's changes from Brontë. By giving Mrs Rochester so important a voice, they turn her into a sympathetic figure. Jane and Rochester's love has to be even more powerful than it is in the novel if they are to overcome Mrs Rochester's influence.

Berkeley's music embodies an unrelenting sense of entrapment. Based around the most unstable musical interval, the tritone, every character's music is in the hands of an ominous chromatic grip. When Rochester and Jane agree to marry at the end of the first act, they cannot escape the dissonance that threatens to strip away their happiness. Mrs Rochester's music is even more obviously enslaved by this. And when Adèle dances and fondly remembers Paris, there is a suggestive undercurrent.

Over this continually shifting musical landscape, Berkeley weaves waltzes and references to Donizetti, and creates grim horse rides and depictions of Thornfield's fire. Berkeley uses a 13-piece ensemble with painterly assurance, emphasising the lower register with grotesque contrabassoon and double-bass rasps.

The whole cast give convincing singing and acting performances, but Andrew Slater's brooding Rochester is outstanding. In the title role, Natasha Marsh is by turns demure and passionate. Her alter ego, Emily Bauer-Jones's Mrs Rochester, successfully creates the impression of a woman who is deranged as well as profoundly wronged.

Berkeley's musical compression finds its complement in a set which is both reflective and transparent; a vision of the liberation outside Thornfield and the imprisonment inside. But concentration is one thing, dramatic power is another. At the end of the opera, it is difficult to empathise with the two lovers.

With the impressive, breathless momentum of the whole score comes a lack of time for the love between Jane and Rochester. Even with the tender scene for Jane and Rochester, the opera still seems under the influence of the emotional instability of the rest of the music; a curiously unaffecting conclusion. However, as a complete production, Berkeley and Malouf's collaboration has produced an engrossing reworking of the most familiar of novels.

At Buxton festival on July 18 and 21. Box office: 01298 70395.

fields.headline: A victory for consumers
fields.standfirst:
Banks bow to mutual pressures

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It would be nice to be able to say thank you to Barclays and Lloyds for abandoning plans to charge for the use of cash machines. Nice, but wrong.
fields.body:
It would be nice to be able to say thank you to Barclays and Lloyds for abandoning plans to charge for the use of cash machines. Nice, but wrong. They have taken ages to admit it is in the mutual interest of banks and consumers not to charge people for taking their own money out of cash machines (ATMs).

It is, in any case, current account money that the banks earn money on while offering depositors little or no interest. They give the impression they are only doing it because of an avalanche of negative publicity and because, if competitors drop charges, they could lose business. Barclays said it was doing it because "the market is repricing cash machines to the benefit of all consumers".

Lloyds followed Barclays' withdrawal last night after "reviewing the situation" for a few hours.

That's the nearest we will get to an actual apology from either of them after a disastrous bit of public relations. Barclays had merely been following HSBC's lead last month. Meanwhile, depositors should be celebrating a victory for consumer power.

There is no doubt that, in theory, a system enabling anyone to withdraw money from any bank's ATM is a cartel. In theory they should all be in competition with each other. But it is a cartel that works entirely in the public interest, especially in rural areas where the next ATM may be a bus ride away.

At one stage some of the banks were planning to charge £1 a time for ordinary withdrawals and a "disloyalty fee" of up to £1.50p when their customers used other banks' ATMs. The banks remained adamant even when Don Cruickshank, the special investigator, said that the real cost of a transaction was between 15p and 30p.

Yesterday also marked a victory for smaller banks and building societies without their own ATM networks and for new entrants, like Egg and the internet banks. All of which amounts to a defeat for the big clearing banks. And a rare victory for mutualism.

fields.headline: Barclays drops surcharge
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Barclays held out the possibility of levying some charges on new cash machines last night as it, along with two of its rivals, caved into public pressure by ditching planned charges on its existing network.
fields.body:
Barclays held out the possibility of levying some charges on new cash machines last night as it, along with two of its rivals, caved into public pressure by ditching planned charges on its existing network.

The bank's decision not to introduce a £1 surcharge on rivals customers using its machines from next year followed exactly one year of negative publicity about the controversial plan, which had threatened to destabilise the entire Link cash machine network.

However, while most of the 28,000 cash machines in the Link network will be free from next year, after Lloyds TSB last night also bowed to peer pressure, Barclays was careful not to rule out charges in the future.

Yesterday's statements by Barclays and Lloyds TSB followed confirmation by HSBC last week that it would not introduce disloyalty charges.

Barclays had already stopped levying a disloyalty fee on its own customers when they use rivals' machines, a move which industry experts have estimated will lose it £50m a year in income. The bank planned to recoup the loss by introducing a surcharge on rival customers using its own machines, but was forced to delay the charge until January 2001 after furious rows with other Link members.

In a statement issued yesterday, Barclays said it would not introduce the surcharge on its existing cashpoints.

John Varley, chief executive of Barclays' retail financial services, refused to say what im plications this might have for the future, other than to say that more complicated cash machine transactions would be skewed towards its own customers.

He gave examples of hole-in- the-wall machines that dispensed non-cash items, such as theatre tickets.

The bank's decision not to charge followed a decision first by Halifax, then by Abbey National and NatWest to join the Nationwide Building Society and Co-op Bank in offering cash machine services free to their own customers and those from other banks.

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, who had originally stolen a march on Barclays by setting its fee at half the proposed level, said the planned 50p levy would also be scrapped to avoid any confusion.

Mr Varley at Barclays was unrepentant about the difficult campaign the bank has waged over the past year. He said that the greatest source of confusion among customers - whether they were charged or not - had now ended and that more cash machines were being introduced in to the network.

"That would never have happened if we hadn't taken action," he said.

Surcharges will still feature at some cash machines in areas described as "convenience" locations, run by the Woolwich and Alliance & Leceister and new non-bank entrants such as Securicor, which have been encouraged by the £1 surcharge to operate cash machines.

The decision by the big four banks not to surcharge is of most benefit to the smaller building societies and banks, and new entrants such as Prudential's Egg, which is unable to carry the cost of maintaining and developing vast cash machine networks.

Nationwide's chief executive, Brian Davis, said: "This has been a long running dispute which has raised very strong feelings. We have never believed that it is right that people should have to pay to withdraw their own money from a cash machine. Now this position has been vindicated and the UK consumer is the winner."

Teach yourself banker: What they said

4 July: Barclays announces intention to surcharge rival customers £1 but scrap its disloyalty fee

Peter Duffy, head of screen banking at Barclays says: "We believe that pre-notifying ATM charges is a key industry issue. Making charges clear at the time of a transaction has several benefits. It is much fairer because people can decide whether or not to accept the charge. If they choose not to pay they can simply walk away and use a cash machine that's free."

April 19, 2000: Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, speaking before the Commons treasury select committee, refuses to be moved from his bank's stance that the £1 surcharge is a "stake in the ground".

Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB , stuns rivals with an announcement of a 50p surcharge, which would still allow the bank to make a "very small profit".

March 4, 2000: John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading: "I have a strong personal concern about the effects on lower-income consumers and those with a restricted choice of ATMs."

Sir Brian Pitman, chairman of Lloyds TSB, tells the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers: "We have in vested heavily in our ATM network for the benefit our customers and we do not believe that we should subsidise our competitors".

Abbey National announces: "The size of the fee will be determined in due course, taking into account the costs of our investment in our own network."

July 3, 2000: John Varley, chief executive of retail financial services at Barclays, says: "We live in a competitive market place and the market is repricing cash machines transactions to the benefit of all consumers."

Barclays had already stopped levying a disloyalty fee on its own customers when they use rivals' machines, a move which industry experts have estimated will lose it £50m a year in income. The bank planned to recoup the loss by introducing a surcharge on rival customers using its own machines, but was forced to delay the charge until January 2001 after furious rows with other Link members. In a statement issued yesterday, Barclays said it would not introduce the surcharge on its existing cashpoints. John Varley, chief executive of Barclays' retail financial services, refused to say what im plications this might have for the future, other than to say that more complicated cash machine transactions would be skewed towards its own customers. He gave examples of hole-in- the-wall machines that dispensed non-cash items, such as theatre tickets. The bank's decision not to charge followed a decision first by Halifax, then by Abbey National and NatWest to join the Nationwide Building Society and Co-op Bank in offering cash machine services free to their own customers and those from other banks. Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, who had originally stolen a march on Barclays by setting its fee at half the proposed level, said the planned 50p levy would also be scrapped to avoid any confusion. Mr Varley at Barclays was unrepentant about the difficult campaign the bank has waged over the past year. He said that the greatest source of confusion among customers - whether they were charged or not - had now ended and that more cash machines were being introduced in to the network. "That would never have happened if we hadn't taken action," he said. Surcharges will still feature at some cash machines in areas described as "convenience" locations, run by the Woolwich and Alliance & Leceister and new non-bank entrants such as Securicor, which have been encouraged by the £1 surcharge to operate cash machines. The decision by the big four banks not to surcharge is of most benefit to the smaller building societies and banks, and new entrants such as Prudential's Egg, which is unable to carry the cost of maintaining and developing vast cash machine networks. Nationwide's chief executive, Brian Davis, said: "This has been a long running dispute which has raised very strong feelings. We have never believed that it is right that people should have to pay to withdraw their own money from a cash machine. Now this position has been vindicated and the UK consumer is the winner." Teach yourself banker: What they said 4 July: Barclays announces intention to surcharge rival customers £1 but scrap its disloyalty fee Peter Duffy, head of screen banking at Barclays says: "We believe that pre-notifying ATM charges is a key industry issue. Making charges clear at the time of a transaction has several benefits. It is much fairer because people can decide whether or not to accept the charge. If they choose not to pay they can simply walk away and use a cash machine that's free." April 19, 2000: Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, speaking before the Commons treasury select committee, refuses to be moved from his bank's stance that the £1 surcharge is a "stake in the ground". Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB , stuns rivals with an announcement of a 50p surcharge, which would still allow the bank to make a "very small profit". March 4, 2000: John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading: "I have a strong personal concern about the effects on lower-income consumers and those with a restricted choice of ATMs." Sir Brian Pitman, chairman of Lloyds TSB, tells the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers: "We have in vested heavily in our ATM network for the benefit our customers and we do not believe that we should subsidise our competitors". Abbey National announces: "The size of the fee will be determined in due course, taking into account the costs of our investment in our own network." July 3, 2000: John Varley, chief executive of retail financial services at Barclays, says: "We live in a competitive market place and the market is repricing cash machines transactions to the benefit of all consumers."

fields.headline: Franchise deal for Abbey managers
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National's regional branch managers could more than double their salaries to £150,000 under a pilot scheme by the bank to introduce a franchise arrangement.
fields.body:
Abbey National's regional branch managers could more than double their salaries to £150,000 under a pilot scheme by the bank to introduce a franchise arrangement.

The "small-scale pilot" in 12 out of its 760 branches will get under way at the end of the month, in a move which is to be closely monitored by the financial services authority, the bank's regulator.

Abbey believes it could boost its revenue streams by £250m a year by moving towards the franchise arrangement, which would give local managers greater autonomy over their branches.

The managers - 20 have applied so far for the franchises - will pay Abbey National a fee based on the profitability of the branch in the past, although, unlike other franchise arrangements, all the staff will remain employed by the bank.

The local area managers could boost their salaries up to 2.5 times if they meet certain criteria based on performance. These will include keeping on the right side of compliance rules set out by regulators over sales in an attempt to quash concerns about misselling products.

"We want to turn our managers into entrepreneurs. We hope to attract the brightest and the best of our competitors," an Abbey spokesman said.

The move is a response to pressure to reduce costs.

fields.headline: Transform the world
fields.standfirst:
The Snow Maiden/ Mazeppa*****/*****
Kirov Opera at the Royal Opera House, London
fields.trailText:
The Snow Maiden/ Mazeppa*****/*****
Kirov Opera at the Royal Opera House, London
fields.body:
Written within two years of each other, Rimsky-Korsakov's The Snow Maiden and Tchaikovsky's Mazeppa are poles apart in content and style. Mazeppa, based on Pushkin, though closer in tone to Dostoevsky, inhabits alarming sexual, moral and dramatic territory.

The heroine, Maria, abandons both parents and lover for the glamorous, ageing, violent Mazeppa who immures her in sensual comfort and keeps her in ignorance of the fact that he is having her father tortured in his dungeons downstairs. Maria's inevitable penetration of Mazeppa's schizoid universe has ghastly consequences. Evil triumphs. Mazeppa escapes the resulting conflagration alive. Maria retreats into insanity to some of the most beautiful music Tchaikovsky ever wrote.

It was last seen in London in a notorious English National Opera staging which drew on The Texas Chainsaw Massacre for its imagery. The Kirov, however, have painstakingly reconstructed the first St Petersburg production of 1884. Old-fashioned it may be, but it still has tremendous visceral power. The torture scene is unwatchable. The final image of the demented Maria, fluttering like a wounded bird through the battle zone that was once her father's garden, haunts long after the curtain has fallen.

The performance has the pulverising force of Jacobean drama. Valery Gergiev stares unblinkingly into the sonic maelstrom that Tchaikovsky unleashes. Olga Guriakova, opulent of voice, is a sensuously deranged Maria opposite Nikolai Putilin's strangely lyrical Mazeppa - a man who, like Richard III, can smile and kill while he smiles. Vladimir Vaneev, as Maria's father, achieves the staggering feat of suggesting excruciating physical pain while never for a second straying from the note. The great Larissa Diadkova turns Maria's mother into an icon of tragic vengefulness. Don't miss it.

The Snow Maiden, however, is even more remarkable, a vast, slow-moving bittersweet fairytale that pantheistically hymns the eternal return of nature. Snegourotchka, the titular heroine, is the daughter of Winter and Spring, condemned to melt when Summer brings both warmth and love. It's a subject that directors might lace either with kitsch or Freudian goo. The Kirov elected, wisely perhaps, to perform it in concert. You don't need a staging, in fact, for Gergiev and his cast bring the burgeoning, anthropomorphic landscape of the score to life in a way that no producer ever could.

The central performance by Olga Trifonova has been the greatest revelation of the Kirov season so far. With a voice at once passionate and icy, sensual and brittle, she suggests a being at once magic, fragile and doomed. The rest of the cast is flawless and the whole is simply one of the finest operatic performances I've ever heard in my life. You emerge from it on an incredible high, believing in magic and in the power of music to transform the world into a better place.

Tonight and Friday. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Disciplined self-creation
fields.standfirst:
Juliette Gréco****
Barbican, London
fields.trailText:
Juliette Gréco****
Barbican, London
fields.body:
Juliette Gréco's five-piece backing group (led by her domestic and artistic partner of 25 years, Gerard Jouannest) gave us a few, deep double-bass pulses. Then there was a low swing of the accordion, a tinkle of ivories to put the Left Bank perfume in the air and suddenly there she was - a sheath of black, her bleached face surprisingly plump, her white arms wafting high in the air. She was like a witch-kitten.

The 1,900 fans - many French, many gay - rose to their feet and howled their admiration and gratitude. Gréco has been absent from the stage for over a decade. For those who know her only by her throaty recordings, the elaborate personal choreography is always a surprise: she is sculpting her persona as she sings, her thin, silvery arms sketching, in elegant lofty calligraphy, accusation, disdain, love destroyed.

When Edith Piaf sang she would slump before you, ragged with suffering, noisily defeated; Patachou belted songs out wholesomely for the boys in the back room. But Gréco is still a creature of the cellars, coming out of hibernation into the luminous immense grotto of the Barbican Hall, cracking her lyrics like nuts. She fractured Jacques Prévert's Les Feuilles Morte; stamped on it, the melody lost in her imperious or plaintive growling.

There is actually not much melody in Gréco. But it is not sweet tunes but this curious theatrical fabrication that the fans love. There were songs from Leo Ferré and Jacques Brel, but more suitable was material by Jouannest with lyrics by Luis Bunuel's scriptwriter, Jean-Claude Carrière. In one - Le Contre-ecclesiaste (Rien n'est Vanité) - she affirms that neither the warm skin of a lover nor the caress of fresh wine, is vanity; only the cruel and arrogant averted gaze is vanity and the bitterness of the blasé. In another, with the misleading romantic title, A Summer's Day, she meets a man with blue eyes and a straw hat who invites her to go with him; she refuses.

But when she stands up to death (La Mort! J'arrive!) snarling and whimpering, the theatricality went too far and she reduced that predator to a vaudeville character. And introducing the lovely communard song, Le Temps des Cerises, she told us that revolution was love and, following the line of the best of French idiotic philosophy, that love is revolution.

But this was not about philosophy; it was about one of those incredibly durable, disciplined self-creations that can grapple audiences world-wide to itself and hold them for more than half a century.

fields.headline: House prices reach steady state
fields.trailText: House prices rose slightly last month but not by enough to dispel the growing view that the property boom has passed its peak, according to figures issued yesterday.
fields.body:
House prices rose slightly last month but not by enough to dispel the growing view that the property boom has passed its peak, according to figures issued yesterday.

The cost of an average British home climbed 0.4% last month, and now stands at £81,452, said Nationwide Building Society.

The increase effectively cancels out May's 0.3% decline in prices, leaving them broadly stable over the past two months.

In consequence, the annual rate of increase in house price growth is continuing to decline - it was 15.1% in June, compared with 15.8% in May and 17.5% in April.

"These figures show that prices continue to rise, but at a slower pace than they were during the first quarter of the year," said David Parry, a Na tionwide spokesman.

"We believe that house price inflation has been running at an unsustainable pace in the past year and it was natural and expected that some slowing would take place."

The figures are the latest to indicate that the market is slowing down following the surge in property values seen in the last two years.

Last week the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said that house prices had come to a standstill in London, the region that has led the boom, and had "slowed to a walking pace" across the rest of the country.

Prospects for the wider economy remain favourable, with unemployment expected to fall further and average take-home pay predicted to rise this year.

Given this backdrop, house prices would continue to climb, though the British economy was unlikely to see a return to the rapid growth seen at the end of last year, and there was a good chance that the annual rate of house price inflation would continue to slide in the coming months, said Mr Parry.

The number of house sales climbed to 124,000 in May, compared with 99,000 in April and consumer confidence appears to be improving.

Halifax, which also recorded a drop in house prices in May, will issue its data for June later this week.

webTitle: Portugal trio given long bans after dissent

fields.headline: Portugal trio given long bans after dissent
fields.trailText: Three key Portugal players have been hit with swingeing suspensions for their conduct in Wednesday's semi-final with France, sanctions which may seriously hinder their country's prospects of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup.
fields.body:
Three key Portugal players have been hit with swingeing suspensions for their conduct in Wednesday's semi-final with France, sanctions which may seriously hinder their country's prospects of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup.

Abel Xavier, whose handball to concede a penalty in golden-goal extra-time was the catalyst for ugly scenes which included manhandling of officials and, according to Uefa, spitting at a linesman, was suspended from all matches in Uefa competitions for nine months for grabbing the referee's arm.

Nuno Gomes, the scorer of Portugal's goal in the 2-1 defeat but sent off after Zinedine Zidane converted France's penalty, received an eight-month ban for a violent push on the referee Günter Benkö. Paulo Bento, who tried to take the red card from Benkö, has been sidelined for six months.

"I'm deeply shocked and disappointed," Xavier said. "I didn't expect a punishment of this nature. I did nothing wrong. The footage is available and people can watch it."

Fifa, the world game's governing body, is expected to recognise the suspensions, ruling the trio out of Portugal's early World Cup qualifiers. The campaign begins against Estonia in September and is followed by matches with the Republic of Ireland and Holland in October. Xavier and Gomes will also miss the Andorra match in February.

Gomes, who finished the tournament with four goals, will miss Benfica's Uefa Cup campaign in the autumn. Xavier and Bento, who play for Everton and Real Oviedo respectively, will be unaffected unless they are transferred to clubs who have qualified for Europe. "This does great damage to my career," Xavier added, "because there were clubs which were interested in me, clubs which are involved in European competitions."

Portugal were also fined SFr175,000 (about £70,000). They have until midnight on Wednesday to appeal.

The trouble began when the linesman Igor Sramka signalled handball by Xavier and kept his flag aloft after Benkö awarded a corner. After consultation the penalty was awarded, whereupon the two officials were besieged. After Zidane scored, several Portuguese players ran to the linesman, who was pushed and insulted. "An unidentified player spat at him," Uefa's statement said.

 Italy were fined SFr12,000 for having four players booked and one sent off in their semi-final against Holland, who were fined SFr5,000 for having four players booked in the same match.

webTitle: Barthez cries out for a new life in Manchester

fields.headline: Barthez cries out for a new life in Manchester
fields.trailText: When France lifted the World Cup in Paris two years ago, Fabien Barthez said he cried for the first time in his life. The new Manchester United goalkeeper might have wept again after 90 minutes last night but it would have been for very different reasons.
fields.body:
When France lifted the World Cup in Paris two years ago, Fabien Barthez said he cried for the first time in his life. The new Manchester United goalkeeper might have wept again after 90 minutes last night but it would have been for very different reasons.

His joy as Sylvain Wiltord squeezed in an injury-time equaliser to send this game into extra-time was unconfined, as he leapt about his penalty area.

Knowing him, though, it will not have come as a surprise because Barthez is renowned for possessing the self-confidence of Naseem Hamed. And it was a disappointment that he chose not to enter by flying carpet but walked behind Didier Deschamps for the national anthems instead.

Then again, if ever there is a time for Barthez to feel insecure it is during the Marseillaise, because it always appears that he has sat beneath the wrong peg and slipped on the goal keeper's jersey by mistake.

The official tournament statistics list Barthez as 6ft, the same height as Marcel Desailly, which can only mean he turned up on measuring day wearing a Don King wig. The fact that he stood between Deschamps and Bixente Lizarazu, France's two smallest players, during the anthems certainly seemed to give the game away. No wonder the 29-year-old feels the need to date supermodels, wear dark glasses and shave his head.

So famous is the bald pate that it is shaved by contractual agreement with Bic razors. And a particular shiver must have gone through his cranium as he got his customary pre-match peck from Laurent Blanc. The defender had said this would be his international farewell and - whatever the state of play in his on-off romance with Linda Evangelista - Barthez must find it hard to imagine being kissed by another man.

Not that he was given time to consider such matters. If, after Italy's semi- final against Holland, Barthez expected his most testing moment of the first half would be jumping to touch the crossbar before kick-off, he was in for a nasty surprise. Within 80 seconds he was rushing outside his area to demonstrate his famous kicking ability as Marco Delvecchio chased a Francesco Totti pass.

His new club manager Sir Alex Ferguson, spotted here before the start, must have liked that. But Barthez's relative lack of inches seemed to be exposed when he was caught well off his line as Totti headed wide from a Stefano Fiore corner minutes later.

Yet it is personality as well as undoubted ability that marks Barthez out, and his reaction to an early Demetrio Albertini free-kick that flew over indicated that any Manchester United defenders who threw away their ear plugs when Peter Schmeichel departed could have made an error.

Delvecchio also got a mouthful, and nearly a fistful, when he caught the prone Barthez with his leg. But as the half progressed there was little to test France's No16, who had enough toilet roll lobbed at him by Italy's fans before the second period to last him to the next European Championship.

A few pieces might have been needed to wipe away the tears of anger and frustration when Delvecchio put Italy ahead, Barthez rooted to the spot as the Roma forward scored from close in. Grateful to see Alessandro del Piero and Delvecchio waste further chances, he did his bit late on by saving with his legs from Massimo Ambrosini.

But as the half progressed there was little to test France's No16, who had enough toilet roll lobbed at him by Italy's fans before the second period to last him to the next European Championship. A few pieces might have been needed to wipe away the tears of anger and frustration when Delvecchio put Italy ahead, Barthez rooted to the spot as the Roma forward scored from close in. Grateful to see Alessandro del Piero and Delvecchio waste further chances, he did his bit late on by saving with his legs from Massimo Ambrosini.

fields.headline: France's case for the defence
fields.standfirst: Lemerre's men know how to attack but spare a thought for that back four
fields.trailText: No one had scored first against the Italians since the beginning of Euro 2000. Before last night's kick-off, that seemed the most significant of the available statistics. How would they react if France took the lead? And if Italy, as has become their habit, sneaked a lead, would the French stand a chance in the face of that implacable defence?
fields.body:
No one had scored first against the Italians since the beginning of Euro 2000. Before last night's kick-off, that seemed the most significant of the available statistics. How would they react if France took the lead? And if Italy, as has become their habit, sneaked a lead, would the French stand a chance in the face of that implacable defence?

But then nothing, really, went according to plan in Euro 2000. The De Kuip stadium in Rotterdam, which until Thursday night's dramatic second semi-final was scheduled to have presented the eye with an unbroken field of orange, was instead dressed in a coat of many colours, albeit with a heavy emphasis on shades of blue.

Many of the Dutch fans who decided to attend the match anyway, despite the demise of their heroes, came along in their ordinary clothes, although some could not bear to be parted from the uniform they had cherished so proudly. Having been the colour of a hangover on Friday morning, orange now became the emblem of mourning.

Like the rest of the non-aligned spectators, the bereaved Dutch came along mainly to see if the French players could confirm the belief of many observers that they are among history's great football teams. Winning Euro 2000 would prove to everybody that their World Cup triumph two years ago was not just a question of home advantage and catching Brazil on a day when Ronaldo wasn't feeling himself.

France's back four is certainly among the pre-eminent defensive units of all time, and going into last night's match had never lost when playing as a quartet. Sadly, France's greatest victory had come when one of their number was absent through an unfair suspension, so last night was also an occasion for Laurent Blanc, making the last of his 90-odd appearances in the national shirt, to earn belated compensation for that injustice.

Blanc made his mark as the outstanding performer of the first half, making his tackles and interceptions with rare perception and deftness, always making himself available for a return ball once he had set a French move going.

But this close-knit team found it hard work in the early stages against the obdurate Italians. The tentative nature of their play made them look more like distant relatives than a team so well bonded that they refer to each other as Titi, Lolo, Manu, Zizou, Duga, Djouki, Nico, Didi, Liza, Bobo. One man alone lacks a nickname, although it would be hard to imagine anyone addressing Marcel Desailly as anything other than Marcel Desailly, unless it be Monsieur Desailly.

Roger Lemerre had made the interesting but arguably overcautious decision to leave out Nicolas Anelka, probably reasoning that the Italians de fend deep enough to make his fast-breaking game potentially less effective. Instead the coach reverted to the arrow-head formation tried against Spain, with Christophe Dugarry and Youri Djorkaeff positioned on the flanks, behind Thierry Henry and ahead of Zinedine Zidane.

Unfortunately Dugarry, having made a fleeting impression in his appearances against Holland and Spain, chose the big occasion to revert to the loose technique and sloppy thinking familiar from his brief careers with Milan and Barcelona. In the first half he wasted endless amounts of promising possession, supplied by the skill and effort of Zidane, Bixente Lizarazu and others.

With Demetrio Albertini and Luigi di Biagio taking it in turns to stifle Zidane's runs, France were heavily dependent on the ability of Henry to turn a defender from a standing start and then to trick his way past two or three more.

The recent rebuilding of the stadium has retained the harsh ambiance of the old tin drum; the silver-grey sky and heavy air intensified the atmosphere, and the supporters set up a thrilling rivalrous racket whenever the pre-match canned music subsided, but in truth the match was lacking passion in the first period.

When Filippo Inzaghi rose from the Italian substitutes' bench at half-time and walked across the pitch to the tunnel deep in conversation with Zidane, his Juventus club-mate, it seemed a civilised way of passing the time but hardly indicated the kind of emotional intensity that such a match should provoke.

Zidane's decision to push forward in the second half enabled him to create fine chances wasted by Henry and Sylvain Wiltord, but it may also have changed the emphasis of the play enough to have allowed Italy to spring forward down the right and produce the cross by Gianluca Pessotto from which Marco Delvecchio scored the fateful opening goal.

And once more we saw the value of the Italian science of defending, as Fabio Cannavaro and Alessandro Nesta hurled their bodies in the way of the ball until Wiltord finally managed to force the ball between Francesco Toldo's legs to send the match into extra-time.

webTitle: France add Europe to the world

fields.headline: France add Europe to the world
fields.standfirst:
France 2 Wiltord 90, Trezeguet 103
Italy 1 Delvecchio 54
(aet, France win on golden goal; 1-1 after 90min )
fields.trailText: In the end Euro 2000 was won by magic, not method. A marvellous goal by David Trezeguet in sudden-death extra-time beat Italy, the methodists supreme, in the De Kuip stadium last night as France added the European Championship to the World Cup they won two years ago.
fields.body:
In the end Euro 2000 was won by magic, not method. A marvellous goal by David Trezeguet in sudden-death extra-time beat Italy, the methodists supreme, in the De Kuip stadium last night as France added the European Championship to the World Cup they won two years ago.

Officially this was the golden goal that settled everything. But for the French the really golden moment had come at the end of the third of the four minutes allowed for stoppages when Sylvain Wiltord brought the scores level just as Italian hearts were starting to celebrate.

One of the better tournaments deserved one of the better finals. But finals are about winning or losing; any entertainment that ensues is a welcome side-product which cannot be guaranteed.

At least last night's scenario promised a classic of contrasts. A French team imbued with the spirit of adventure faced an Italian side wary of misadventure, but still one that had survived the semi-finals through summoning up an image of Horatius defending the bridge.

Naturally, football being the perverse game it is, Italy wasted no time last night taking the attack to their opponents, putting early pressure on Bixente Lizarazu on the French left.

Marco Delvecchio and Francesco Totti had been preferred by Dino Zoff to Fillippo Inzaghi and Alessandro del Piero as the men to start up front. With Demetrio Albertini and Gianluca Pessotto, the replacement for the suspended Gianluca Zambrotta, quick to get to grips with the French midfield and hoping to isolate Zinedine Zidane, Italy's football had a more compact look about it.

For France to be able to break down Italy's awesomely efficient defence Zidane obviously had to see a lot of the ball. The Italians, therefore, concentrated on making sure that he did not catch more than the odd glimpse of it.

In these circumstances Patrick Vieira, Youri Djorkaeff and Christophe Dugarry needed to press forward to establish alternative links with Thierry Henry. No easy task when every square metre of space in front of you is being ceded so grudgingly.

Apart from Francesco Toldo dropping a corner under pressure from Marcel Desailly there was little to disturb the equilibrium of Italy's defence in the opening half-hour. At the same time there was now little for Fabien Barthez to do at the other end except watch the game threaten to develop into a midfield stalemate.

The reluctance of both teams to get more players forward to support the man on the ball did not help the spectacle. France in particular were playing too much of their football in front of eight Italians plus the goalkeeper.

For an instant Djorkaeff looked as if he might score the goal the match so desperately needed seven minutes before half-time. Laurent Blanc, pushing up from the back, and Didier Deschamps set up Henry for a 20-yard shot which Djorkaeff stunned near the six-yard line before turning to toe-poke the ball towards goal. The shot did not carry enough power to bother Toldo but the idea was right.

As the half ended, a beautifully disguised pass by Paolo Maldini let in Delvecchio on the left but only for Blanc's effortless interception of the cross to emphasise still further how difficult scoring goals was going to be at either end.

Doing things a bit quicker was one answer and as the second half began the speed with which passes from Zidane and Djorkaeff gave Henry a fleeting chance before he was dispossessed suggested that the tactic had occurred to the French. Within four minutes, moreover, Henry had outpaced and outwitted Fabio Cannavaro on the left before producing a low cross which Zidane, lunging in, just failed to reach.

Italy, too, decided something more positive was needed and after 53 minutes Stefano Fiore was replaced by Del Piero. By the 54th minute France were behind. The movement that led to Italy's goal hinged on an inspired backheel from Totti as he met a ball from Albertini on the right. With the defence momentarily fooled, Pessotto sent in a dipping centre which evaded Desailly, and Delvecchio was behind him to beat Barthez off the side of his left foot.

The goal came just in time to rescue the final from ignominy. Two more might have followed by the 62nd minute. First Del Piero, sent clear by Totti, dragged his shot wide and then Sylvain Wiltord, who had just come on for Dugarry, saw Toldo's legs block his shot after Zidane's pass had beaten the offside trap.

In the 68th minute a floated free-kick from Zidane found Henry making space at the far post. Just as his shot looked like nutmegging Toldo the goalkeeper closed his legs to stop it. Toldo was powerless, though, to prevent Wiltord redeeming a lost cause deep into injury-time.

fields.headline: Germany hand Voller the reins
fields.trailText: Germany have appointed Rudi Völler, a World Cup winner in 1990, as caretaker national coach until the end of next season when he will hand the reins to Christophe Daum.
fields.body:
Germany have appointed Rudi Völler, a World Cup winner in 1990, as caretaker national coach until the end of next season when he will hand the reins to Christophe Daum.

Daum, now coach of the Bundesliga runners-up Bayer Leverkusen, has another year to run on his contract and the club have refused to release him.

The choice of Völler is something of a surprise as the 40-year-old has no coaching experience or qualification. However, he is Leverkusen's sporting director, knows Daum and the two have similar views on how the game should be played.

"I hope Rudi will win all his games," Daum said, aware that Völler will be in charge for the majority of the 2002 World Cup qualifying campaign. "If [he does not] it will put me under great pressure, but I can live with that."

The German Football Federation vice-president Gerhard Mayer-Vorfelder commented: "I am satisfied with this solution. It has been reached with the agreement of all parties."

Joao Pinto, the Portugal midfielder sacked by Benfica before Euro 2000, has signed a four-year deal with their city rivals, Sporting Lisbon. "I was greatly honoured by the invitation," the 28-year-old said. "There were others, but I think I've made the best choice."

Sporting are also said to be trying to complete the signings of Liverpool's Phil Babb and Tranmere's Alan Mahon, both available on Bosman- ruling free transfers.

Chris Hutchings expects to complete his first signing as Bradford City's manager today when the Northern Ireland full-back Ian Nolan arrives, also on a Bosman, from Sheffield Wednesday.

Bradford recorded a 3-1 Intertoto Cup win over Atlantas Klaipeda in Lithuania yesterday, with goals by Isaiah Rankin, Dean Windass and Robbie Blake (penalty). The return leg is on Sunday.

webTitle: Brazil back South Africa's World Cup bid

fields.headline: Brazil back South Africa's World Cup bid
fields.standfirst: Fifa sources declare that England will not host the event in 2006
fields.trailText: Brazil is expected to pull out of the race to stage the 2006 World Cup within the next 24 hours, almost certainly ensuring that the tournament will not be played in Europe for at least another 14 years.
fields.body:
Brazil is expected to pull out of the race to stage the 2006 World Cup within the next 24 hours, almost certainly ensuring that the tournament will not be played in Europe for at least another 14 years.

Sources close to the Fifa executive committee, whose 24 members will vote on the venue on Thursday in Zurich, have confirmed Brazil will withdraw their bid and that their three South American backers will switch allegiance to South Africa in exchange for African support for another Brazilian campaign in 2010.

The alliance between the two countries was forged during several high-profile meetings in Johannesburg over the past few weeks between South Africa's campaign leader Danny Jordaan and Ricardo Teixera, who holds the Brazilian vote on Fifa. "Brazil has made a deal with South Africa and will withdraw," said the Fifa source. "It's a tactical strategy but it doesn't look good for England."

Brazil looked likely to be eliminated early in the ballot after a low-key campaign, especially after being ranked joint last with Morocco in the official Fifa inspection team's report. Clearly the Brazilians think they have a better chance in 2010, which would be South America's turn if Fifa sticks to its policy of rotating continents for the event.

But the timing could not be worse for England. After a traumatic 24 hours last week at the Uefa Congress in Luxembourg, the last lobbying forum before Zurich, campaign officials now accept they will have far less support than had been anticipated. England had been hoping to pick up at least one of the three South American votes.

Should South Africa secure 2006, Europe will almost certainly have to wait until 2014 at the earliest or, more likely, 2018, before staging the World Cup again.

Ironically Tony Banks was trying to make this point in Luxembourg last week when he took on the whole of European football in one of the most hard-hitting speeches ever made in such a politically sensitive forum.

Although many saw it as a last-ditch panic move by a beaten team, Banks's indictment of Europe's support for Germany was designed to emphasise the fact that, unless Uefa backed England, they would be handing 2006 to South Africa on a plate and Europe would not host the World Cup for many years.

Uefa officials were furious, especially when Banks added fuel to the fire by later suggesting that Germany's was the only bid that Uefa had bothered to study.

"It's an insult to say we don't pay respect to the bids. I have read them all," said the Uefa president Lennart Johansson. "And it's an insult to Germany to suggest in public they have less support than England."

Alec McGivan, England's campaign leader, was unmoved. "Maybe what Tony said came as a bit of a shock to some people but we decided quite deliberately to provoke a debate. It is patently obvious that you cannot win this vote with European votes alone and there is no doubt in our minds that we have made the most progress in other parts of the globe."

Until violence broke out in Charleroi and Brussels at Euro 2000 and the Fifa technical inspection report which - scandalously, according to McGivan - placed England behind Germany and South Africa, it was widely assumed that England would garner considerable support from outside Europe.

England expected to score with the three Concacaf members, whose confederation covers north and central America and the Caribbean. McGivan has had countless discussions with the Concacaf president Jack Warner and general secretary Chuck Blazer over the last few days to keep them on side.

He has always conceded that without Concacaf, England's chances of victory are slim, a prediction that is now looking worryingly prophetic, especially after Warner astonishingly appealed to them to withdraw from the race.

"So much damage has been done to their bid in the last few weeks," said Warner. "I suggested they pull out and come back stronger next time because I'm afraid they will be humiliated on Thursday and they are good people and don't deserve that."

England have only two committed supporters in Scotland's David Will and New Zealand's Charles Dempsey.

It will be of little comfort to McGivan but had the vote taken place in March, its original date, instead of being pushed back to this week by Fifa, he may already have been celebrating success. Warner admitted as much. "England were in a far stronger position three months ago than they are now."

Yesterday, McGivan was unrepentant, saying that to pull out would have been to hand victory to English football's yob culture. He said: "Of course our chances are not as strong as they were before the hooliganism at Euro 2000. But it's no good allowing the hooligans to destroy the hopes and aspirations of the majority."

Restoring English football's image will be the first task of the Football Association chairman Geoff Thompson when he takes up his new position as a member of the Uefa elite this week. Relations between Lancaster Gate and the European governing body have been difficult in recent months and he will reassure Uefa that hooliganism will be tackled head on.

Relations between Lancaster Gate and the European governing body have been difficult in recent months and he will reassure Uefa that hooliganism will be tackled head on.

fields.headline: Duckworth-Lewis catches Bears short
fields.standfirst:
Glamorgan 167-4
Warwickshire 201-7
Match tied on D/L method
fields.trailText:
Glamorgan 167-4
Warwickshire 201-7
Match tied on D/L method
fields.body:
Neil Smith, the Warwickshire captain, was bowled by Adrian Dale off the final ball as his side fractionally failed to outwit the arcane Duckworth-Lewis partnership, in a thrillingly tied match.

Smith, with some typically unorthodox blows and the promising, calm Michael Powell had so nearly taken Warwickshire to victory in a determined stand of 67 after the Bears had been set a target of 35 more than Glamorgan because of the revised calculations following earlier rain.

The promoted Ashley Giles had blasted an assertive 40 with some sturdy square-cutting before skying to Matthew Maynard, who had time to catch the visible Swansea-Cork ferry as the ball came down.

Dougie Brown, too, with some lusty blows scored valuable runs as Warwickshire attempted - not always successfully - to pierce Glamorgan's alert fielders. Glamorgan held all their catches, none better than Alex Wharf, who sprinted round to take the ball behind bowler Darren Thomas. Warwickshire had needed 20 off the last three overs - and the match remained excitingly open.

Glamorgan had reached 167 for eight in 38 overs when the rain came and that was the end of their innings. They had leaned almost entirely on Matthew Elliott and Steve James, no longer wasted in the middle order for the limited-over game.

Many of Glamorgan's overseas players have been endowed with flamboyance. Elliott has none; he is, however, a talented, workmanlike left-hander, something of a surprise choice as their temporary Aussie guest until Jacques Kallis returns next year. He has conscientiously grown into the onerous ways of county cricket.

He was 84 not out, having hit Ed Giddins for a straight six in the direction of the Bay, and taken another off Giles. But he is not a man prone to batting liberties. Nor is James, who pushes and guides by inclination, never bludgeons. His half century passed, he was taken at the wicket, just as Keith Newell had been in the third over.

Maynard's emerging intentions were cut short as he skyed to long-on. Then Dale, leaning a delivery from Graeme Welch, succumbed too easily to mid-on. Yet Elliott looked in no obvious trouble and only the weather, it seemed, denied him a deserved hundred.

 Worcestershire, the Division One leaders, had to settle for two points after their National League match against Leicestershire at New Road was washed out. Somerset closed the gap when their total of 296 proved too much for Kent at Maidstone.

In the day's other First Division match, a century from the Sussex captain Chris Adams helped the Sharks to a 43-run win at Northampton in a match reduced to 33 overs by rain.

In the Second Division, Stuart Law was unbeaten on 104 from 96 deliveries as Essex passed the Middlesex target of 213 for nine with eight overs and seven wickets to spare at Chelmsford.

webTitle: Vintage with a hint of Headingley '81

fields.headline: Vintage with a hint of Headingley '81
fields.standfirst: An astonishing second test at Lord's breathes new life into the series
fields.trailText: The crowd stayed long after the baubles and bouquets had been handed out and the champagne corks popped in the England dressing room. As Dominic Cork, bathed in soft seven o'clock sunshine, clubbed the winning boundary and set off on his adrenalin-fuelled celebrations, they poured across the green acres in their thousands to stand in amazement in front of the pavilion and there they remained, unable or unwilling to tear themselves away, hoping the magic might last just a little longer, until finally the sweeper crews moved in and they wandered off into the St John's Wood evening.
fields.body:
The crowd stayed long after the baubles and bouquets had been handed out and the champagne corks popped in the England dressing room. As Dominic Cork, bathed in soft seven o'clock sunshine, clubbed the winning boundary and set off on his adrenalin-fuelled celebrations, they poured across the green acres in their thousands to stand in amazement in front of the pavilion and there they remained, unable or unwilling to tear themselves away, hoping the magic might last just a little longer, until finally the sweeper crews moved in and they wandered off into the St John's Wood evening.

This had been not only a vivid Test match but a truly great one, a game that for all three days fluctuated wildly in fortune before the most dramatic of climaxes. West Indies were not out of it until the moment Cork's final square-slash left his bat and, eluding the cover fielders, raced to the boundary between the Tavern and Mound stands; certainly not while the giants Courtney Walsh and Curtly Ambrose had a breath left in their bodies.

Together these two warriors, up there with the Taj Mahal and the Great Wall of China as wonders of the age, pulled West Indies back from the brink just as they had done so often in the past. Walsh claimed the first six wickets, to finish with 10 in the match, and is marching relentlessly on towards 500 Test dismissals. No spoils for Ambrose, though, until he had Andy Caddick lbw as the match came to a head, but that merely serves to illustrate that there is no justice, certainly not in the cricket world.

Quite simply Ambrose served up one of the finest displays of relentless, metronomic, micrometer-accurate pace bowling that anyone had witnessed, passing the lunging edge of the bat time and again, the difference between success and failure little more than a hair's breadth. Mike Atherton, who has faced him down more than most, said it was the most searching examination of his career.

Lord's will not see the pair in Test action again and gave them a rousing send-off as the throng parted and, led by Walsh, the West Indies team made their way to the Nursery End of the ground to take the plaudits of their supporters and give their own thanks.

In a match containing heroes in abundance, Cork took the man-of-the-match award from Ian Botham, who had himself so famously turned the tide of match and series 19 years ago. On the first day of Cork's return to international cricket it had been his waspish bowling which gained control after Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith had taken toll of England's early inertia, and which then began the process of chipping away at the innings. Then, on that incredible Friday when 21 wickets had fallen and for the only time in Test history a part of all four innings was played in a day, he had breezed in to finish the job of demolishing West Indies' secondinnings after Caddick and Darren Gough had started the task.

On Saturday, though, the fire of competition burned fiercest in his eyes at a time when history suggested that the game was up for England; 48 runs were still needed when he arrived at the crease, and 28 when he was joined by Gough with only the rookie Matthew Hoggard to come.

While Gough employed studious defence against Ambrose, Cork launched into Franklyn Rose, pulling him into the Grandstand for six and lofting him to the long-on boundary. Sixteen needed and it might have been 60. Singles were scampered in hair-raising fashion, leg byes greeted with acclaim by the crowd.

Finally, as his last throw of the dice, Jimmy Adams brought back Walsh to partner Ambrose. Drip by drip England closed in until leg byes brought the scores level. In came the field, Cork held his nerve and carved his place in English cricket history. The stand had occupied three nail-biting quarters of an hour.

The win was set up by the second-wicket partnership of 92 between Atherton, whose whole cricket existence is for days and confrontations such as this, and Michael Vaughan, who restated his Test match credentials. Neither rushed: Atherton took nine overs to get off the mark and Vaughan 11, and Atherton's 45 took him 3 hours before Walsh got him. He has never made a Test century at Lord's but this was as good as. Graeme Hick and Alec Stewart continued the aggression with some forthright strokes and suddenly the win was in range.

So a series has been resurrected in the most dramatic fashion, and goodness knows the summer has needed it. And no one should be blinded by the fact that this was a great escape by England; West Indies have suffered a huge setback at Lord's because they are proud of a marvellous record of triumphing in the close games, especially when they are bowling last.

Losing now has taken the wind from the tourists' sails and were the series continuing a week on Thursday, as it normally would, England's momentum might have proved irresistible just as it was when Botham and Willis turned the tide at Headingley. Instead, though, we move into one-day mode, and there is a chance for West Indies to regroup and specifically for Walsh and Ambrose to recharge. A one-day series, with strokeplay the imperative, may just prove the catalyst that revitalises Brian Lara too.

England really needed this to be a continuous series and they now have selection dilemmas for the third test at Old Trafford, which starts on August 3. Ostensibly the side who lost at Edgbaston were kept together as far as was practical and were offered the chance of redemption, and redeem themselves they have. Doors were opened, however, by injuries to Nasser Hussain and Andy Flintoff, and although Craig White had a modest game, Vaughan must now have put pressure on Mark Ramprakash, who failed yet again at Lord's and whose opening spot is in jeopardy; he looked a forlorn figure amid the triumphalism on the England balcony.

There must surely be a recall soon for Graham Thorpe too, although with Hussain's return one further batsman would have to make way. Hick would be most under pressure but one solution, with an all-seam attack, is to employ seven batsmen.

But that is in the future. For now England should relish the moment. Their endeavours have given new life to test cricket and resuscitated a series. And for that, in a hitherto depressing sporting summer, we should be grateful.

webTitle: Great comebacks from Tennyson to Solskjaer

fields.headline: Great comebacks from Tennyson to Solskjaer
fields.trailText: The Oval 1902
fields.body:
The Oval 1902

England beat Australia by one wicket

England needed 263 to win on the last day of the fifth test but MacLaren (2), Tyldesley (0) and Palairet (6) soon went and it was 10-3. They looked unlikely even to last into the afternoon when Braund and Hayward departed to make it 48-5.

Jessop joined Jackson and added 109, then more with Hirst. Jessop's 100 was posted in 75 minutes and 75 balls and a spectator was said to have gnawed all the way through his ivory umbrella handle. Just like Cork and Gough on Saturday evening, Hirst and Rhodes - "We'll get 'em in singles" - saw England home.

The early apogee of the Edwardian golden age.

Edgbaston 1922

Hampshire beat Warwickshire by 155 runs

Warwickshire made 223 and then bowled out Hampshire for just 15. The visitors followed on and at 98-3 at the end of the second day still needed 110 to avoid an innings defeat. At this point the home captain, the Hon FS Calthorpe, suggested a game of golf to the Hampshire captain, Lord Tennyson, once the match was over the following day.

Tennyson fumed and laid a substantial wager that his Hampshire side would win, whereupon George Brown hit 172 and Tennyson continued seething at Calthorpe. Warwickshire were left to score 314 but could manage only 158, leaving Hampshire winners by 155 runs and Tennyson collecting a fortune.

Wisden noted: "The victory taken as a whole will surely be without precedent in all cricket."

Wembley 1953

Blackpool 4 Bolton Wanderers 3

Although he was to play on in league football for another decade, the 1953 Cup final was presumed to be Stanley Matthews' last throw on the big stage, having missed a winner's medal twice before.

It was Coronation year, Everest was conquered, Gordon Richards won the Derby and England regained the Ashes after 20 years - but in the event the "Sorcerer of Soccer" upstaged them all.

He left it theatrically late, though. With less than half an hour to go, Bolton led 3-1. First Matthews provided a teasingly high cross for Stan Mortensen to make it 3-2 and then, with three minutes left, Mortensen equalised with a raging free-kick. Then Matthews flickered through Bolton's defence and cut the ball back for Bill Perry to score - and the young new Queen prepared to hand Matthews his medal. He was knighted within weeks.

The Olympics 1980

Seb Coe v Steve Ovett

The prime minister Mrs Thatcher did not want any British presence at Moscow's showpiece - but it seemed the world willed the showdown between England's two all-time finest middle distance runners.

The head-to-head caught the imagination of all sport. They were to run two races against each other at these Games - but surely Coe would win his speciality, the 800 metres, and Ovett his at 1500m.

First up, in the 800, Coe panicked and ran a tactically disastrous race. Ovett scooted home. Coe had just a couple of days to pull himself together but, in his depression it seemed unlikely he would.

He moped and he fretted until race day when he received a telegram from an unknown fan, a Mrs McGinty of Leicester - "Pull your finger out Coe, I'm betting on you in the 1500" - which made Seb laugh, realise the possibilities and determined to oblige.

And that evening, heroically, he did so, coming back from the dead in the longer race and gloriously taking the gold medal. He defended it successfully four years later.

Headingley 1981

England beat Australia by 18 runs

England needed 227 to avoid an innings defeat and were at once 6-1 and then 41-4. The Australians Lillee and Marsh took the 500-1 odds offered against England winning.

At 105-5, when Botham came to the wicket, it was still odds-on for a painful defeat. But in partnerships with the tailenders Dilley and Old, Botham - "Let's just give it some humpety" - reached 149 unbeaten to leave Australia 130 to win. Willis tore in from the top end and by the time Australia were 58-4 the huddles were growing around high-streets TV rental shops just as they had on the Saturday evening. It seemed the rest of the nation had transistor radios jammed to their ears.

Lillee and Bright put on 35 nailbiters for the ninth wicket before Gatting famously caught Lillee at mid-on and Willis yorked Bright for 19 - and England became only the second team in test history to win after following on.

The Crucible 1985

Dennis Taylor v Steve Davis

Following Joe Davis, snooker's pioneer champion, the second half of the century's "Sultan of Sink" and "Prince of Pot" was his namesake, Steve.

He was as irresistible as Joe and just about as unbeatable - and was leading 7-0 in this one-sided woebegone world championship final against Taylor, a tubby little outsider from Belfast with a perky mien and full-moon spectacles. But suddenly Taylor began to bite into that massive lead, gradually at first then pointedly with some daring play.

From that 0-7 down, it was now the unlikely Taylor who stepped forward to sink the final black, last ball of the last shot of the last gasp. And so he did - "It was like Sgt Bilko beating Muhammad Ali over the full 15" said the Guardian.

Bridgetown 1999

West Indies beat Australia by one wicket

West Indies needed 308 in just four sessions of play but were 91-4 in no time. Lara took 47 balls to get into double figures and by lunch on the last day he and Adams had ground out the score to 165-5.

Lara then found the force was with him and went from 50 to 100 in 51 balls. At 238-6, there was still a chance, but at 248-8 West Indies were surely done for. Tailender Ambrose heroically held up an end for 80 minutes and with seven needed, wicketkeeper Healy dropped Lara. With six needed Ambrose went and last man Walsh came in.

A single from Lara brought the scores level and, next over, the little man outrageously ripped Gillespie through the covers. Steve Waugh said it was the best innings he had ever seen and the best test he had ever played in.

Barcelona 1999

Bayern Munich 1 Manchester United 2

The white blazons of Bayern Munich were festooning the Nou Camp, the cacophony of whistles demanding an ending at 1-0 all had German accents. Bayern's presumption that they had returned to the glorious days of a quarter of a century before and become European champions was understandable and it looked a step too far for Alex Ferguson's side.

With two minutes of injury time added on, it all changed. Both centres came in from the left - first Sheringham found the net, followed by Solskjaer. As the whistle blew at 2-1, white had turned miraculously to red. "Football? Bloody hell!" said Ferguson, knighted within a month.
