fields.headline: A missed opportunity
fields.standfirst: A magazine which is selling 120,000 copies a month closed on Saturday.  Jessica Hodgson  asks if Emap has sacrificed Minx's honesty for a digital future
fields.trailText: A magazine which is selling 120,000 copies a month closed on Saturday. Jessica Hodgson asks if Emap has sacrificed Minx's honesty for a digital future
fields.body:
Depending on your perspective, the demise of Minx magazine was either a loss of nerve about the best thing to happen to women's publishing since Helen Gurley-Brown, or the timely end of an outdated fad.

Emap's reticence on the reasons for the closure is deafening. In a statement, Emap Elan Network's chief executive Barry McIlheney said Minx had "failed to find a sales figure high enough to make the magazine financially sustainable". The last magazine ABCs in February showed the title's sales had slipped 18.2% in the previous 12 months, but it was still achieving sales of 123,278. Emap has promised to find jobs within the company for the staff, under editor Vanessa Thompson, and the magazine will gasp its last in August. So what went wrong?

At first glance it's not obviously apparent why Emap should want to close a magazine still selling 120,000 copies a month.

Minx was launched in 1996 under editor Toni Rogers with an edgy £1.5m TV and poster ad campaign and a brief to go after "girls who don't buy magazines", according to Sam Baker, who edited the magazine between April and December 1998 and now edits Company: "The girls who bought Minx always made up a very specific market - girls who bought Diesel jeans, girls who went clubbing and who didn't necessarily have time for other women's magazines." Arriving in the wake of the ladette movement, it steered an uncertain path somewhere between the locker-room sexual obsession of more! and the aspirational intelligence of Marie Claire.

Minx's sexual explicitness and "upfront" approach to subjects like drugs brought it into a few predictable brushes with controversy, notably a slapped wrist from drugs czar Keith Hellawell after "recommending" its readers try an "ecstasy-style" drug called BOD. The editorial described the drug as "hip" and said, with its tongue firmly in its cheek, that it will deliver "inner strength, good humour and contentedness".

Minx's response to the criticism, that "our readers can make up their own minds", seemed to encapsulate its approach; that readers were big and ugly enough to appreciate the discrepancy between the received wisdom peddled by women's magazines on health and lifestyle issues and the way young women were increasingly choosing to live. This was backed up by a more leftfield approach to fashion, plus articles extolling the virtues of the scooter as a status symbol offering a refreshing alternative to the standard interiors shoots, and thoughtful - if explicit - writing on sexual encounters.

The magazine's ethos was built around kicking back at the narcissism that it believed characterised the women's market.

Polly Vernon, a former staffer, wrote in the Guardian following the spat between Marie Claire's Liz Jones and Sam Baker over magazines' responsibility for anorexia: "I write for Minx, a women's magazine whose proposition bounces between a desire to be smart and funny and irreverent and feelgood and also aspirational, glamorous and just that little bit prettier than anyone has a right to be. The point that Jones and Baker are missing [in slinging mud about whether women's magazines contribute to or alleviate anorexia] is that women's magazines are not about helping women feel better. Quite the opposite. They're silly, vacant, extravagant and often cruel. Like the fashion industry, they can't help themselves." Minx's subtext, laced with a liberal helping of fashion and lifestyle, was about trying to help women feel better. The irony of its closure, in the week after the launch of Tessa Jowell's anti-anorexia taskforce, will not be lost on any of its former staff.

Or that, at least, was the grand plan. But, for one former staffer, the Minx experience is a salutary lesson in why pressure from advertisers means it's virtually impossible to create a women's magazine that does help women feel better. "There was this constant feeling that we were trying to make a success of going for a 'naughty niche' but not having the balls to really go for it," says the journalist, who prefers to remain anonymous. "As with all consumer magazines, it wasn't about the copy; it was about the relationships with advertisers. There were a number of occasions when we were told not to do this or that so as not to upset the people from Chanel. I remember once we had an article about female ejaculation. I took it to show the editor of the time and she was absolutely terrified," the journalist recalls. "She told me to go away and de-quim it a bit. Minx was a missed opportunity. There was a tremendous amount of enthusiasm around its launch. But that rapidly disappeared."

Other observers believe Minx's ladette tag came to be an albatross. "It was too tough for its market," says Rita Lewis, director of publishing at Emap Elan rival IPC Southbank. "At the age it was pitched to, you've got to be pretty confident to go for that sort of lifestyle proposition." At any rate, the magazine never achieved the sales figures of 200,000 it aimed for at launch.

Minx's competitors in the young adult market, including Nat Mags' Company and IPC's 19, also saw significant falls in sales in the last ABCs - 16% to 242,180 and 26.9% to 126,606 respectively. At the ABC launch, the big magazine publishing houses - Emap, IPC, Attic Futura and Nat Mags - all conceded that the market has become more competitive. The success stories this year have tended to come from the older, glossier end of the sector. IPC's relaunched Woman's Journal added 20.4% to sales, while Marie Claire and Cosmopolitan maintained a relative stability at 450,000 and 470,000 respectively.

The teen market has also seen a loss in sales across the board. The total circulation of this lucrative market experienced a 10.6% slump in year-on-year sales between December 1998 and December 1999 from 3.21m to 2.87m. In February, Emap Elan closed the teenage title Big after sales fell below the 100,000 mark. Bliss's circulation also fell 14.6% to 287,796.

Lewis says magazine sales are falling at an unprecedented rate in the teen and glossy sectors. "As a total market, the women's sector is extremely tough, and in decline at the moment. Over the past few years, the increased coverage in the nationals of a range of women's issues is eating into what used to be the exclusive preserve of the glossies."

She thinks the young adult market is having a particularly tough time, caught between the teen and glossy sectors. "The glossy market has a much larger ad base, so it can afford to get away with lower cover sales. The younger magazines, titles like Minx, B and Sugar, have to sell far more copies because the ad base is much smaller."

She says Minx's sales would have been sustainable with a title pitched at an older market, but "in that sector you'd need to be selling somewhere around the 150,000 mark to make the magazine financially sustainable". And 150,000 is small fry for magazines like Sugar, which was still shifting a healthy 430,217 in the last ABCs.

B, launched a year after Minx, was deliberately positioned as an alternative to ladette magazines and is now selling 223,532 copies per month - almost 100,000 more than Minx. Baker is not surprised that B is doing better than Minx. "Minx was not editorially consistent," she says. Gina Johnson, editor in chief of B, agrees that Minx's lack of editorial cohesiveness was its downfall. "Minx was one of the original 'ladette' magazines and had gone from that to being an aspirational, fashion-based magazine. But it couldn't successfully make the transition."

Baker adds: "As a style magazine for girls within a limited market, Minx was successful, but Emap wanted a big-circulation, mainstream magazine." She believes that it suffered increasingly from an identity crisis, caught between the upbeat, sex-obsessed world of the teen titles and a desire to break into what she describes as "the freedom years market", over which Company still exercises a tenuous hold.

Interestingly, Emap Elan's more!, which pitches its equally explicit content at a younger market, is still holding its own at 300,000 sales. Lewis thinks more! succeeds where Minx failed partly because of the younger market and partly because it "takes itself less seriously". Vernon thinks Minx fell down on the editorial pitch. "People never quite understood that Minx wasn't a teenage magazine."

Is it OK to be rude and lewd in the teenage market but not after you hit 20? Magazine marketing wisdom certainly seems to suggest that consumers and advertisers expect a degree of gravitas to kick in as you move from the teen to the young adult market.

In the larger scheme of things, Emap may regard the demise of Minx as necessary damage incurred in the longer-term battle it faces - to position itself for the internet. Last November the company created a subsidiary, Emap Digital, designed to focus on developing magazine brands into online ones, and in March it was spun off. Emap Digital is working with Channel 4 on interactive content for the teen market for a broadband interactive service - believed to be a joint venture with BT. Its new projects department, elanInvent, is thought to be working on several pre-teen projects.

When it announced the restructuring, Emap said its future strategy for its offline magazine brands meant "money [will only be] invested where there is a substantial opportunity to create value" through digital opportunities. The company's sales staff now sell across print and digital media. Staff working on the company's less successful consumer magazine brands are nervous about a future where a magazine will have to demonstrate not only its capability of delivering sales, but its viability as an online brand. Magazines like Heat and Sky, which occupy the cross-gender lifestyle market, are thought to be being watched, hawk-like, for signs of further sales decline. Heat, which recorded an ABC of 72,510 is undergoing a makeover to help it appeal more to the female marketplace, and rumours abound within Emap that Sky's days are numbered after the magazine shed 24% of its sales.

As B's Johnson notes: "The single most important factor in the survival of a magazine brand is how easily it can be leveraged across different platforms. This means more than just taking magazine content and dumping it online, it means a magazine will have to have strong editorial concepts which will also lend themselves to online sales opportunities and interactive concepts." She thinks that the market for offline magazine launches has also become more cut-throat. "The shelf life for a women's magazine is a lot shorter today and companies need to be constantly thinking about launching new products."

For Polly Vernon, as for other former staff, it's "desperately sad". "The editorial team was made up of hugely talented people and the failure was no reflection on the editorial product. It's a tragic indictment of the women's magazine market that Minx didn't work and the market will be the worse for it."

In the larger scheme of things, Emap may regard the demise of Minx as necessary damage incurred in the longer-term battle it faces - to position itself for the internet. Last November the company created a subsidiary, Emap Digital, designed to focus on developing magazine brands into online ones, and in March it was spun off. Emap Digital is working with Channel 4 on interactive content for the teen market for a broadband interactive service - believed to be a joint venture with BT. Its new projects department, elanInvent, is thought to be working on several pre-teen projects. When it announced the restructuring, Emap said its future strategy for its offline magazine brands meant "money [will only be] invested where there is a substantial opportunity to create value" through digital opportunities. The company's sales staff now sell across print and digital media. Heat, which recorded an ABC of 72,510 is undergoing a makeover to help it appeal more to the female marketplace, and rumours abound within Emap that Sky's days are numbered after the magazine shed 24% of its sales. It's a tragic indictment of the women's magazine market that Minx didn't work and the market will be the worse for it."

fields.headline: The paperless chase
fields.standfirst: Now that newspapers have finally woken up to the online revolution, the battle for readers is spilling on to the internet.  Imogen O'Rorke  traces the billions being spent on the cyberspace race
fields.trailText: Now that newspapers have finally woken up to the online revolution, the battle for readers is spilling on to the internet. Imogen O'Rorke traces the billions being spent on the cyberspace race
fields.body:
Last week United, the media conglomerate that owns Express newspapers, unveiled a copper-bottomed £300m strategy for its new-media division, Xilerate. Hot on its heels, News International is about to go public with its substantial growth plans for News Network. Both, along with Trinity Mirror, which recently pledged a £150m online investment, are manoeuvring to become the dominant players in an increasingly heavyweight new-media arena.

Not so long ago, their online plans were looking pretty sketchy compared to Associated New Media, Guardian Unlimited, or even Hollinger Digital, who were all early adopters (Hollinger as early as 1994), but the pecking order is changing as the nature of online publishing is changing. The last six months have provided the steepest learning curve yet for newspaper publishers trying to swing their weight online.

A new report from PriceWaterhouseCoopers, entitled New Directions in European Publishing, outlines some of the critical issues they face: the breakneck pace of technological innovation and the proliferation of new platforms; declining loyalty in the consumer marketplace; the increasing demand (driven by the industry) for customisation and personalisation. Add to this the prospect of depleting print-ad revenues as the money moves into interactive marketing, online 24-hour media cornering the market for breaking news and the dangerously catchy trend for pan-global mergers such as those between Liberty Media and United GlobalCom, Time Warner and AOL, and most publishers have good reason for sleeping with the door open and the light on, for fear of being eaten.

Oh yes, the romantic days of newspaper publishing - the ones that only ever really existed in movies like Citizen Kane - have gone. This is the era of "strategic authoring" (extending the brand across all platforms into commerce, insurance and even theme parks), "cannibalisation" (bulk reappropriation of original content for your own and others' websites) and "monetisation" (turning your loyal customers into cash cows). The latter is the one that is keeping publishers awake at night.

But with the age of interactive consumption comes increased consumer power. The future, according to PriceWaterhouseCoopers, is about "reaching the consumer community with what the customer wants via the channel the consumer wants to use", or, to use their three commandments on the road to convergence: "Content, Community and Commerce". In order to keep reader loyalty, publishers are having to segment their readerships and extend their services into new areas such as commerce, retail and goods delivery. Electronic customer relationship management (eCRM), a constant response service, is the new science in publishing.

Since all publishers are in the same boat (what are newspapers if not broad portals?), the report concludes, they need to identify their strengths, to ask questions such as: are we trade or consumer? Regional or global? Do we form a stand-alone division to sell off or keep it in-house?

Xilerate, News Network and Trinity Mirror are compensating for their late entry by focusing on commerce and internet services. The good news for the tabloid publishers is that the C2 market (think mum with five kids in KwikSave) is the fastest-growing on the internet, and it will be even more so with interactive TV and wireless. "It's a good market for e-commerce, promising strong revenue streams," says Matt Jellicoe, marketing director of Express Online.

Xilerate is a five-headed commercial hydra. The first division is Business to Consumer, which includes such brands as dotmusic.com, lads' portal Megastar, parenting site allaboutparents.com, youth entertainment site Rapture and interactive site Exchange & Mart. A number of other lifestyle sites are mooted.

"United News and Media has gained its position by stealth - no one saw it coming," says Jellicoe. "Dotmusic is well ahead of nme.com, and Line One [the business's second division] is Britain's second biggest ISP. Behind the scenes we've been developing very strong products. Look at Megastar, which had no marketing whatsoever and has grown organically to 250,000 unique users and 10 million page impressions." Megastar will benefit from the £9m advertising spend that United is discussing.

The other three divisions of Xilerate - Business 2 Business (an investment of £120m), Xilerate Ventures, a fledgling external investments division, and E Services, which includes web hosting, media sales and a raft of technical and "back end" support services - ensure that everything can be done cheaply in-house. Xilerate generated £33m in 1999 and revenues are expected to reach £350m-£500m by 2004.

Commerce, Consolidation and Convergence are the three Cs that Xilerate follows. "We have excellent PC and TV skills but we don't have wireless skills. Broadband is our weakest point but today that is where the opportunity is greatest," said CEO Andrew Nugee recently. Xilerate is currently in discussion with a mobile phone operator (thought to be Vodafone Airtouch) about partnering to exploit its existing gaming and betting service.

Meanwhile, News Network has been as cagey as United has been perspicacious. Following analysts' reports which suggested that the online versions of the Times and the Sun were failing to provide an adequate service to their customers, there was a tentative revamp back in May and rumours have been circulating that the company is investing in a 24-hour interactive news portal, thereby taking on the BBC.

A large portion of the proposed investment will be going straight into "shop" sites. According to Brett Miller, head of e-commerce activities at NN and general manager of its auction site fired-up.com, 15 sites are being planned, ranging from finance to cookery, which will be "tailored to the consumer with retail buying opportunities". Unlike Associated, which has entered into a partnership with Zoom, NN aims to own as much of the transactional process as possible.

Trinity Mirror has a different tack. Earlier this year it announced the rolling-out of 16 localised "ic" portals around the UK, covering news, sports and entertainment, all offshoots of the central revenue-driving ic portal and ISP ic24, which currently has 450,000 customers (target 900,000 by the end of the year). Managing director David Clarke recognises that with 152 local newspaper titles, Trinity Mirror's main strength is in cornering local online habits and advertising revenues. In addition, four more portals are imminent - icShowbiz, icChoice, icSport and icTravel - and there will be "substantial" investment in interactive TV and mobile phone applications.

"We are the consumer's champion," says Clarke. "As a consumer portal we are far ahead of the other newspaper groups." This year, £20m will be spent on targeting new customers. The online versions of the group's papers, including the Mirror, Daily Record and Sunday Mirror, register only faintly in the corporate strategy; Clarke sees his main competitors as being Yahoo, Freeserve and MSN.

But where does all this leave Hollinger Telegraph, Guardian Unlimited and Associated New Media? Money is not in short supply at two-year-old ANM - revenues were up nearly 300% on the first half of last year - but Associated has opted to focus on its areas of expertise, building up This Is London (which draws on the strengths of the London Evening Standard and Metro), the recruitment site BigBlueDog and This Is Money, a new personal finance portal. UKPlus, the net directory, also appears to be performing well.

ANM's showcase site, charlotte-street.com, has lagged dangerously behind in the women's portal race, however, despite a partnership with the shopping portal Zoom. According to Kevin Beatty, chief operating officer of Associated News Media, it will receive a big cash injection which will "take it on to a higher plane", but it also will be brought back into the fold of the Daily Mail, "in order to get the best of both worlds". In other words, a rebranding is on the cards.

Hollinger Digital, which includes the Electronic Telegraph, Handbag and Interactive Investor, has been preoccupied with upgrading its outdated technology (at a cost of £10m) and getting outside hosting, to the detriment of its business development plans. Now the division is future-proof, however, it can start to concentrate on content under the new editorial direction of former Independent on Sunday editor Kim Fletcher.

The Telegraph Sport site will be upgraded in August and money, travel, jobs, property and motoring are next up for exploitation, at a projected cost of £30m-£50m. "It would be easy to say that if we'd made the big investments in '98 we would be in better shape, but the market just wasn't big enough then," says managing director Hugo Drayton.

Drayton is aware that the only way to "take on the big guys" is to partner up - a policy it made public in April - but he is confident: "You can't just buy reputation, trust and brand strength overnight, and we can carry those over. We recognise that our key competence is editing, writing and presentation. How we make money out of that is today's and tomorrow's challenge."

Hollinger's strategy will echo Guardian Unlimited's: push content out simultaneously to print and websites and aim for "scalable, organic growth". GU's traffic has reached 14.5m page impressions per month, and a media portal launches in September. "There is an enormous amount of investment going on among our competitors and we have to double our efforts," says GU head Simon Waldman. "But how much you spend and how big you look is not as important as what you do and whether you spend that money efficiently."

Waldman is sceptical about the late- comers' ability to catch up. "Traditionally, media companies have been able to come in late and be bigger, but that doesn't work any more. Look at Yahoo: they are now almost as big as News Corp, where once News Corp considered buying them." By scaling up their new media assets, Trinity, United and News Network are pitting themselves against a raft of new competitors: the online giants AOL/Time Warner, Freeserve and Yahoo. The rewards could be great, but experiments are getting more and more costly.

fields.headline: Wind of change
fields.standfirst: How a team of Miami Herald reporters correlated hurricane wind speeds and insurance damage reports to win a Pulitzer prize
fields.trailText: How a team of Miami Herald reporters correlated hurricane wind speeds and insurance damage reports to win a Pulitzer prize
fields.body:
Hurricane Andrew crashed down on the south Florida coast in August 1992. When it had passed, it left as its legacy the most expensive natural disaster in US history. Damage exceeded $20bn. More than 40 people were killed and approximately 2m Floridians were evacuated from their homes.

In the weeks that followed, Steve Doig and his colleagues at the Miami Herald sought to put the storm in perspective. Doig employed computerised mapping software - then unknown in newsrooms - to create maps correlating property tax assessment records and plots of the storm track.

Doig was able to show his readers that if Hurricane Andrew had made landfall just 20 miles farther north, it would have roared through the heart of Miami. Physical damage, and quite possibly the death count, could have more than tripled.

That alone was a good and imaginative piece of journalism, but Doig did not stop there. Using the same computing technology, he put together maps that matched geographic-specific wind speeds with building damage reports. He was intrigued to find there was more damage in areas that experienced lower wind speeds.

Having made the invisible visible thanks to the mapping and database software, Doig and other reporters followed their technological lead with the traditional journalist's tool: reporting. They hit the streets to seek explanations from public administrators, insurance companies and contractors as to how lower hurri cane winds could produce more damage than high winds.

What the reporters found was a litany of shoddy inspection by public officials. A few months later, the Miami Herald team was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for coverage that "not only helped readers cope with Hurricane Andrew's devastation but also showed how lax zoning, inspection and building codes had contributed to the destruction".

The digital tools that Doig was using are called geographical information systems or, more commonly, GIS. GIS represents the merger of cartography and digital databases, working together under the cover of today's desktop computer.

Definitions of GIS range from the procedural to the functional, but all result in a similar product: maps and companion statistics that show where things are or where they happened. The "things" can range from specific crime incidents to the demographics of any area. "Things" can include locales with high or low potential for disease, flooding or environmental pollution. They can include voting patterns, tax assessment, land use or the prevalence of dogs over cats as pets.

No matter what the definition or application, GIS is becoming another indispensable tool for reporters and, indeed, all aspects of the news publishing industry, along with telecommunications, word processing, graphics and spreadsheet programs.

While GIS applications are an international trend (see India: www.gisdevelopment.net/home or Qatar: www. gisqatar.org.qa/), the UK is fortunate in having a long tradition of scholarship in geography, cartography and analytic journalism. Daniel Defoe, with his analysis of plague deaths and burials, was probably the first journalist to use data and maps to tell the story.

In the 19th century, Dr John Snow (www.ph.ucla.edu/epi/snow.html), though not a journalist in the traditional sense, did his pioneering mapping of cholera cases. Snow's maps of water pumps and incidence of the disease confirmed his hunch that the pumps were passing on the disease so much that he was convinced to take action and urged removal of the handle from the Broad Street pump.

The rise of GIS is driven by social and technology factors such as the development of faster computers with large, low-cost storage devices and powerful, flexible software applications available at a low price. Add to that the growing availability of digital maps and data with geographic reference points from public agencies, national government organisations and private enterprise, and the growing cadre of people skilled in applying GIS tools in imaginative ways and you have a revolution in the ways stories can be researched.

As a consequence, intellectually aggressive journalists can use maps produced by GIS first to understand a variety of phenomena and second use those same maps to tell the story. A map contains more information than any other two-dimensional form of communication.

fields.headline: Need to know: Eric Stein
fields.trailText: Age? 31.
fields.body:
Age? 31.

Who is he? MD of DoubleClick, a global internet advertising solutions company. Ex-marketing manager of US entertainment software company, Broderbund.

What's the clever idea? "We sell ads on behalf of 1,500 different websites in 24 different countries - 65 in the UK, serving ads on behalf of those 1,500 sites and about 15,000 different websites worldwide."

What's the thinking behind it? "Advertisers look for different things on the web - accountability, tracking, reporting, optimisation, the ability to test things - things that haven't been available on any other medium to date. DoubleClick helps them understand the capabilities of online advertising using the most precise profiling criteria. Our strategy is based on working with the premium websites, because we believe those present the best solutions. We also aim to establish an overall global network that any advertiser worldwide can use."

How does it work? "A client's objective is to reach its target audience online in the most effective way. We say which different websites best fit which objectives - to advertise on them will cost X. They then develop the creative work, give it to us, and we use our technology to deliver it against the set criteria. There's also serving ads. Every time someone accesses certain sites we can identify certain criteria about that user - geographic location, time, day, page of the site, key word entered. Then we can combine that specific information with general demographic web information, helping the advertiser incorporate some of that data and learn about their campaign and type of user. Also, if British Airways says to me it is trying to reach weekday business travellers on a London to New York route, we can say that in the US we represent these three sites and in the UK these three sites, all six of which reach a business audience. We can advertise on them Monday to Friday, targeting just UK users. So we help them reach their target audience."

What's next? "Putting advertising into email packages, so when you sign up for, say, cheap flights, we'll sell little ads in those newsletters that are relevant to the audience and deliver value for the advertiser. Also, the network is built up right now of different affinity [content] groups with sports, business and finance, technology sites. Before Christmas we're adding a new e-commerce group, selling advertising across five to 10 different sites. With some of the premium brand names in the country, it should be huge in the biggest shopping season of the year."

We say which different websites best fit which objectives - to advertise on them will cost X. fields.headline: New media diary
fields.trailText: • Women's portals. Love them or loathe them (and most of us, it seems, loathe them), publishers just can't get enough of them. Last week NatMags marked its entry into dedicated online publishing with the announcement of uk.women.com, a collaboration with Women.com, the leading US women's site, which will draw on Cosmopolitan and Good Housekeeping.
fields.body:
 Women's portals. Love them or loathe them (and most of us, it seems, loathe them), publishers just can't get enough of them. Last week NatMags marked its entry into dedicated online publishing with the announcement of uk.women.com, a collaboration with Women.com, the leading US women's site, which will draw on Cosmopolitan and Good Housekeeping.

According to the press release, it is "poised to become the easiest, fastest and most efficient way for women in the UK to get what they really (really) want on the web with content that is tailored to their needs and interests" and is sure to become a "must visit". Ahhh, so that distinguishes it from all the other wannabe wimmin's portals then? No, but the crucial difference is uk.women.com calls itself a "destination site" not a (snore) portal. "We think the other women's sites haven't really done it," says Duncan Edwards, chairman of uk.women.com. "They are not deep enough or rich enough in content and they don't use enough bespoke software." Futhermore, he adds: "They don't own the space." Well, at least there is plenty left: of the 6m women who are online in the UK, only around 7% visit women's sites every week.

 Meanwhile, Handbag seems to have won a ratings battle with iCircle, which has withdrawn its recent trade advertising because of possible "confusion" over user numbers quoted. It appears iCircle even managed to bamboozle an MMXI survey with its ambiguous figures. "As I understand that iCircle does not have its own registration, I am unsure how it has achieved 1m registrations since launch," Handbag's marketing director Alicen Stenner writes archly in this week's Revolution, just to set the record straight. "I sincerely hope it will exercise similar caution in future in its claims."

 You might think Suggs an unlikely candidate to promote a dot.com, but then again perhaps not. Direct Line is promoting its new online motoring site JamJar (car, geddit?) with an entire spin-off TV show, The Real Car Show, constituting a £15m marketing spend. Suggs will be presenting it with Julia Bradbury, of Top Gear and the Lottery Show, the driving and gambling man' s crumpet.

 Marketing solutions company 24/7 Media has launched "the world's first" network of wireless content providers (31 in total from nine countries), including Sonera Zed, Sportal, Dressmart.com, WAPTOO, MatchON.com and a lot of unpronounceable ones.

 Rumours have been flying that Mike Butcher, editor of New Media Age, was bored and looking for a way out for some time, but now the diary can confirm that he is leaving to edit theindustrystandard.com. And good luck to him.

webTitle: Head for the hills before it's too late

fields.headline: Head for the hills before it's too late
fields.trailText: The phenomenal speed of change and growth of the web as an advertising and communication vehicle has led to an almost Klondike mentality as many early new media prospectors head for "them thar hills" to gorge themselves on previously undreamed of spoils.
fields.body:
The phenomenal speed of change and growth of the web as an advertising and communication vehicle has led to an almost Klondike mentality as many early new media prospectors head for "them thar hills" to gorge themselves on previously undreamed of spoils.

With the online advertising market in Europe projected to grow from £500m to £3bn (and to £17bn globally) over the next five years, according to Jupiter Research, many new media types believe they are at the forefront of a developing medium that will rule the world as other media and forms of communication fade into obscurity.

Before I get accused of being a Luddite, let me say that I don't doubt the power of the web, but I do want to sound a note of caution - unless web pioneers stop for a minute to take stock of the role of offline and online communications in promoting brands, there is a danger that some of the early prospectors will return home broke and with little to show for their efforts, just like some of the Klondike pioneers.

Evan Neufield, vice-president of international research for Jupiter, speaking recently at the Global Online Advertising Forum, said: "Brands that can innovate and adapt to the increasingly fragmented online/offline media mix will become global winners as will [web] media owners and agencies that partner them."

But I believe that it's not only the media companies and agencies who need to partner the brands; equally important should be the partnership between web media owners and traditional agencies, something that I believe is being forgotten in the goldrush.

While I'm sure that traditional agencies can learn plenty from our new media cousins, I believe that the same is true in reverse. Let's put this into context. While online advertising in Europe may be worth more than £3bn in five years' time it will only represent about 5% of total advertising revenue. The other 95% will still be largely controlled by "traditional" agencies whose role it is to decide on the optimum online/offline mix and, as guardians of the brand, the creative proposition and image.

Wouldn't it be better to embrace these generalists than to push them away? And pushing them away is what I think is happening at the moment.

A mixture of arrogance, over-complication and unprofessional behaviour from web operators is forcing many traditional agencies and media buyers to treat web advertising as a necessary - but not particularly welcome - evil.

The key concerns that most agencies have about web operators could easily be addressed by looking to traditional media and traditional practices for guidance. Key examples of poor practice on the web include unprofessional sales operations - stories abound of "appalling standards of selling", "arrogance" and "standards that would not be allowed in other media". These quotes are taken directly from the front pages of the advertising and media buying press earlier this year.

Linked to this is poor administration, non-standardisation of invoicing and, for a medium that's at the leading edge of technology, no reliable form of electronic trading/interface between buyer and seller, making it a very time-consuming and unprofitable medium for many traditional agencies to deal with.

There are no common trading currencies and little accountability through industry standard auditing that verifies a campaign's actual delivery. Furthermore, there is no industry standard audience research that helps in the planning of online campaigns. There are plenty of individual pieces of research available but, again, nothing that has been adopted as the industry standard. And while there is plenty of transactional-based evidence of the effectiveness of web advertising, there is very little to prove that the web can (in conjunction with offline media) build brands.

Allied to this are poor standards of creativity and increasing evidence that consumers are paying less attention to advertisements on the web.

It's time that the online advertising industry woke up to the fact that many of its problems could be resolved by making more of an effort with those old timers who have resolved many of the above problems in traditional media and have been sitting up in "them thar hills" producing gold for many years.

fields.headline: Web users in reading shock
fields.trailText: Think of the earliest websites and how they looked: vast landscapes of text that sprawled across and down many screens, graphics which were crude at best and too large to download for a typical home user. Today, however, the online landscape is more diverse: flashing animation, graphical displays, streaming video, sounds that roar from pages unexpectedly. How far the web has come. Or has it?
fields.body:
Think of the earliest websites and how they looked: vast landscapes of text that sprawled across and down many screens, graphics which were crude at best and too large to download for a typical home user. Today, however, the online landscape is more diverse: flashing animation, graphical displays, streaming video, sounds that roar from pages unexpectedly. How far the web has come. Or has it?

Early results of the eye-tracking study by Stanford University and the Poynter Institute (http://poynter. org/eyetrack2000) caught print and online visual journalists off guard because they revealed that text may be a more immediate entry point than images for online news sites.

As a user interface designer and visual journalist, I too was surprised by the findings. However, it makes sense that new rules apply to the new medium.

The study, involving 67 experienced and regular users of the web, confirmed the obvious for some, and raised doubts for others.

Sceptics argue that the pool of subjects was too small to make the assumption that text is preferred to photos. Site developers and online usability architects, however, were not surprised by the findings.

Relying heavily on previous print studies, as well as lessons from traditional schools of design that confirm images are the entry points to the printed page, many in the design community are insistent that onscreen design is the same.

The study, however, indicates that "more often than not, briefs or captions got the first eye fixations when the first page came up".

Does this mean that photos or graphics do not have a place on the homepage? Hardly.

With 64% of all available photos having fixations, photos are clearly essential. In fact, many online news organisations' log files show that photo galleries are among their most popular destinations.

In the "front-page entry points" sections of the study, page elements were ranked by volume of fixations. Photos come third to articles and briefs, which were looked at 92% and 82% of the time respectively.

So, what can we learn from the early results of the Stanford-Poynter project? The first lesson is to improve headlines and briefs. Many times headlines and briefs run in the newspaper with a photo or other graphic. But once uploaded to the website, the text and visual elements are isolated from each other because of the limited real estate on the screen. One solution is to rewrite headlines to compensate for the lack of visual support. More often, print headlines are written to fit the column space allocated for the story. These limitations do not exist online, so optimise and rewrite headlines to do what they're supposed to do: bring the reader into the story. With headlines and captions drawing the eye first, this may be the only opportunity to bring online readers in.

Just as headlines are packaged directly from the print edition into online, photographs are often taken straight from the paper and displayed on the web. Unfortunately, the quality on screen is worse than in print. Photo editing for online news should consider two questions: is there a different photo more appropriate for online display, one with a single focus or a single subject? And can the crop of the same image be tighter, to help the user focus on the main detail?

The habits of reading from a computer screen are different from those of reading a newspaper or magazine. It is common to observe people focused on reading a newspaper on a bus or waiting in an airport terminal, isolated from distractions. In contrast, online readers are catching up with their news between answering email, talking with colleagues or answering phone calls. The need for quicker access to information is much more prevalent online. Competition for attention comes not only from other online sites but also from daily activity in and around the user's computer.

fields.headline: Taking on the rogue traders
fields.standfirst: A kitemark for charity shops aims to stop cheats muscling in on a £300m sector.
fields.trailText: A kitemark for charity shops aims to stop cheats muscling in on a £300m sector.
fields.body:
Charity shops will tomorrow up the ante in the battle for second-hand goods. It may be old clothes and bric-a-brac to you, but for charity shops, donated items generate almost £300m a year. And profits of this scale have sparked a proliferation of rogue collectors claiming to be charitable.

To fight back, the Association of Charity Shops (ACS) is launching a kitemark scheme. A symbol will be displayed on bags dropped through letterboxes, on the lapels of people collecting the goods and in shop windows. So far more than 60 charities have signed up to the scheme, including Oxfam, Marie Curie Cancer Care and a number of local hospices.

Lekha Klouda, executive secretary of ACS, says: "The scheme is hopefully going to help the public to identify collections going to genuine charity shops, as distinct from the very many suspect, pseudo-charitable collections - many of which are simply commercial organisations exporting clothing."

Klouda contends that some commercial collectors imply that they are helping poor people in developing countries. "In most cases they will be exporting the clothes to be sold at markets in Africa."

According to Klouda, the law governing house-to-house collections is complicated with stipulations coming under three separate acts. Collectors may not technically be breaking the law unless they are claiming to be a registered charity.

Charity shop retailers say the bogus collecting is localised or opportunistic, rather than nationally co-ordinated. According to Pam Cherry, manager of St Giles Hospice shops in Lichfield, Staffordshire, there are collectors in the Birmingham area who use a charity's name when collecting items door-to-door.

The collection of unwanted goods has become a crowded marketplace, with local authorities now joining in to meet their recycling targets. Charity shop operators argue that they have been in the business the longest and make the most of old clothes by turning them into cash.

Stephen Robertson, director of commercial operations at Shelter, has signed up to the kitemark scheme and looks forward to it becoming a nationwide endorsement of the most efficient way of disposing of unwanted goods. "By giving clothes to a charity with a kitemark, we can guarantee to convert them into money for a charity, not profit for rogue collectors."

The main motivation behind the scheme is the drop in income for char ity shops over the past two years, but it is not all the fault of rogue traders. Last year, net profits were down for charity shops for the first time in eight years. "With chains like C&A going under and Marks & Spencer struggling, there is a knock-on effect for charity shops," says Bob Monteatch, managing director of Mind shops. "If people are not buying new clothes, then they are not getting rid of their old ones."

John Tough, director of ACS and head of retail at British Red Cross, hopes that as well as increasing the throughput of stock, the kitemark will act as a guarantee of best practice. The association's code emphasises a professional and responsible attitude to customers, staff and volunteers. "Those who sign up to the scheme have to abide by the association's regulations and agree to meet all of their statutory obligations," says Tough.

Cherry, of St Giles Hospice shops, agrees. "We believe it will be good for our charity to be part of a much larger movement to raise the awareness that charity shops make best use of items donated to them."

Klouda declares: "This is a good example of charities working together to promote public confidence. Donations are the lifeblood of charity shops and we hope this is a way for charities to regain ground in a profitable activity. Although it is mainly old clothes we are talking about, there is serious money at stake."

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Richard Stott, left-of-centre columnist for the News of the World for the last three years, is the first big name to be sacked by new editor Rebekah Wade. He was given the bullet in time-honoured Fleet Street fashion, over drinks at the Savoy, and next week's contribution will be his last. Reports of a row over the champers are denied despite Stott's combative reputation, but as a former editor of the People, the Mirror and Today, Stott understands the rough ways of newspapers. Oddly, Stott's column was about the only thing Rupert Murdoch liked in the tired old paper. The diary hears a New Labour-friendly commentator is likely to assume his space.
fields.body:
Richard Stott, left-of-centre columnist for the News of the World for the last three years, is the first big name to be sacked by new editor Rebekah Wade. He was given the bullet in time-honoured Fleet Street fashion, over drinks at the Savoy, and next week's contribution will be his last. Reports of a row over the champers are denied despite Stott's combative reputation, but as a former editor of the People, the Mirror and Today, Stott understands the rough ways of newspapers. Oddly, Stott's column was about the only thing Rupert Murdoch liked in the tired old paper. The diary hears a New Labour-friendly commentator is likely to assume his space.

 Eddie Mirzoeff, the man who made Elizabeth R, the last BBC royal series, and encouraged new talents including Molly Dineen, is quitting the corporation next month after 38 years and nearly as many awards. It's not that he is retiring, or has lost his touch; he's a victim of the changing fashions that have downplayed the crafted documentary in favour of docu-soaps and video series like MacIntyre Undercover, forcing him to make Children's Hospital and cover for other people's absences. The final straw came when his proposed History of 20th Century Architecture was turned down by BBC2. Over to Channel 4?

 A visibly pregnant Elisabeth Murdoch, stepping down from Sky, held a glittering farewell party last week at chic Moroccan restaurant Momo with all the usual suspects: Tony Ball, chief executive of BSkyB, Kelvin MacKenzie, Alan Yentob, Lord (Waheed) Alli and, naturally, Peter Mandelson. "It was a very nice party. The thing about her is that she always makes an effort," said one guest. It's not clear if she is being replaced at the head of Sky networks by deputy Mark Sharman. But Sky is doing something right. In digital homes last month, the five terrestrial channels saw their combined share fall below 50% for two weeks running, for the first time.

 Meanwhile, Murdoch's boyfriend, PR man Matthew Freud, is being courted for a grand BBC2 series on the Freud dynasty now in production. Adam Curtis, whose Mayfair Set about the Jimmy Goldsmith/Lucan crowd won him a Bafta, is currently tracing the Freud family's influence in the 20th century - and it won't just be about Sigmund. Curtis is fascinated by the way Edward Bernays, Sigmund's nephew, who went to New York in the 1920s, applied his insights in laying the foundations for modern public relations. Curtis says, "It's all about how you make democracy work when people are not rational beings." What genes Matthew Freud has working for him.

 Greg Dyke wants to shore up BBC producers, but can Auntie really compete with the siren charms of the independent sector? Talkback, makers of BBC1 hit They Think It's All Over, has become the talk of the industry because staff from runner upwards have received surprise lump sums of £15-£25,000 following the company's sale to Pearson Television for £62m. Other key executives have also been signed up with five-year profit share agreements to make sure they stay loyal. "Now I know that being in television means you can make money, and not be ashamed of it," says an ex-BBC staffer, "I'm not going back."

 Over at the beleaguered Independent Television Commission, they're burning with eagerness to see what Channel 5's chief executive David Elstein has to say about deregulating in his submission for the communications/ media white paper. fields.headline: Never mind the Horrocks
fields.standfirst: Can the former Panorama editor keep the series at the top of the serious agenda and pull in more viewers in his new role as head of current affairs?
fields.trailText: Can the former Panorama editor keep the series at the top of the serious agenda and pull in more viewers in his new role as head of current affairs?
fields.body:
At the end of a week of wild speculation, the BBC news director, Tony Hall, issued a cheery email to staff last Friday saying an appointments board had "unanimously" named Peter Horrocks as head of current affairs. Seasoned readers of BBC doublespeak immediately concluded that it was split down the middle.

They were not far wrong. For even as the Panorama editor celebrated, moves were under way to entice one of his rivals for the post, the Channel 4 current affairs commissioning editor, Dorothy Byrne, to a specially created position that would effectively emasculate Horrocks and cast her in a powerful role. It is a piece of cynical chicanery that has left observers and participants breathless.

The position of current affairs head has been vacant since Helen Boaden moved to head up Radio 4 in March. The choice of successor, which fell to the news and current affairs directorate and the controllers of BBC1 and BBC2 was simple: experienced insider, or revolutionary newcomer. But views were sharply divided. The news chiefs, led by Hall, favoured a safe pair of hands; the channel heads, Peter Salmon and Jane Root, distinctly unhappy with what they regard as journalistic under-ambition at Panorama, wanted drastic change.

Horrocks's name went into the ring at the start. He was seen as a natural successor to the current affairs throne: from editing Newsnight, masterminding election coverage and overseeing Panorama, he has been in training for the top job for 10 years, a classic BBC Brahmin.

Byrne would be the revolutionary. Admirers says she has the populist touch, an eye for a good story; but in her rise to the top - from World in Action through the Big Story to Dispatches - she has made as many enemies as friends and her detractors say she can be difficult and unnecessarily aggressive.

A number of other internal and external candidates - including Horrocks, Byrne, Fiona Murch from Correspondent and Sian Kevill from Newsnight - were interviewed. The quality of the internal hopefuls did not impress some members of the board and another slate of candidates from outside the BBC was drawn up for a second round. Still, the board could not agree.

So, buoyed up by his controversial speech about the future of the BBC in Canada, the director of television, Mark Thompson - not regarded as a Horrocks ally - took charge. A third round of interviews was held within the last two weeks, with Byrne and Horrocks still in the running.

But such was the chasm between the news chiefs and channel controllers that it was clear there was only one way out. Fudge it.

The plan, agreed upon in an unholy alliance of Horrocks's friends and foes in high places, envisages the head of current affairs being responsible for regular series, with Byrne installed in a new role as head of current affairs specials - including Panorama spin-offs such as last Friday's edition on the London nail bomber and the earlier programme on football hooliganism. This crafty move - deeply Machiavellian even by BBC standards - allows all sides to claim victory, and enabled Hall to boast, accurately but disingenuously, of unanimity in the promotion of Horrocks.

Supporters of Horrocks are delighted, because they believe his position in the BBC is strong enough to allow his power base to grow. But Byrne's backers are pleased too, pointing out that Horrocks's sphere of influence would not extend beyond the Panorama, Money Programme and Correspondent strands. Given that the future of the second is in doubt, and the third is not a prime-time show, they argue that it leaves him in control of little more than at present. Byrne would be left to claim the credit for the high-profile successes - at Channel 4, she has made one-off and short-run current affairs her speciality, and the BBC's best Panoramas have been the special editions, which would fall within the borders of her empire.

Byrne must now decide whether she wants to step into this nest of vipers from her comfortable position at Channel 4. Such is the sensitivity of the situation that Byrne refused to speak to the Guardian at the weekend.

It is not known whether Horrocks is aware of the machinations. Certainly, of the rumour sweeping the BBC last week, little was accurate. Byrne was never, as one story had it, offered the position of head of current affairs first, turning it down because she could not install her Channel 4 colleague, Julian Bellamy, as editor of Panorama.

Speaking to the Guardian, Horrocks soared above the fray, determined to prove his doubters wrong. BBC current affairs must make waves, punch above its weight, and do so with solid, original and aggressive journalism. "These are vital for current affairs," he says. "We have to make sure we get noticed."

He is confident that the department can be turned around. "There is a huge amount of health in BBC current affairs. It is the most attractive place to be because it does serious news with passion." Unlike Thompson, Horrocks is convinced there is a long-term future for serious current affairs on the principal BBC channel. "I've got no doubt that strong current affairs will remain a part of what BBC1 does. There will always be important stories that need to be told to a mass audience." That, he says, is central to the BBC's public service role.

Today, Byrne is considering her next move. Certainly, some senior BBC executives are convinced she will join them. They are impressed by her populist touch at Channel 4 - she won a clutch of awards as series editor of Dispatches - but her current employers are determined to retain her.

Whether or not Byrne decides to swap sides, Horrocks will have a hard task rallying the troops: even his defenders acknowledge that he has a "man management problem". He seems both phlegmatic and shy, poor at socialising and the cut and thrust of daily exchanges. The real question is whether Horrocks has something extra, the flair, and the authority to protect the serious agenda of things people need to know about, while finding new ways to bring audiences to current affairs on BBC1, while at the same time fending off the enemies within.

It's a tough billet.

fields.headline: Is anybody listening?
fields.standfirst: Last week Sir Christopher Bland admitted the BBC spent too much too soon on digital radio.  Maggie Brown asks if it's still the media's most expensive white elephant
fields.trailText: Last week Sir Christopher Bland admitted the BBC spent too much too soon on digital radio. Maggie Brown asks if it's still the media's most expensive white elephant
fields.body:
Digital radio. Those two words sound like a dirge. And deservedly so. For the past five years listeners have been promised a revolution in listening. "Pin-sharp" sound and more choice. But it's been a case of jam tomorrow.

The stations continue to crackle away, and, in the BBC's case, even fall off air. Only a few thousand music buffs and owners of flashy cars have the equipment - estimates range from 3,000 to 20,000. No company is ready to dish out free receivers or spend gargantuan sums on promoting fancy new content - in marked contrast to the competitive ploys of Sky and ONdigital in the growing digital TV market. A Roberts-designed digital radio with government backing is so clunky I overheard a leading radio figure, who longs to see digital radio soar, quietly mock it as ugly. Just last week BBC chairman Sir Christopher Bland admitted the corporation had mistakenly invested too much too early since the launch in September 1995.

But don't stop reading. If digital radio is a boring white elephant why are the moneymen suddenly so active? Could Bland be wrong? Well, the £22.5bn auction of frequencies to host a third generation of mobile phones has made people sit up smartly. Licences for digital radio frequencies (organised as in television into "multiplexes") are being awarded for free, one every month or thereabouts, by the Radio Authority (14 have so far been allocated, covering most of the big cities).

And though they are designed for broadcasting, not one-to-one phone messages, digital radio frequencies have great potential to deliver the same message to any number of callers without the system overloading - avoiding the kind of phone- jam that occurred on millennium night. And up to 20% of the capacity can be used for text messages, alongside conventional audio radio. Digital radio licences are hence coming to be seen as the last great spectrum freebie.

So Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group, now floated on the stock exchange, has seen its shares trading healthily, not (just) on the quality of his quips, TalkSport's controversial football coverage, and the advertising boom, but because analysts appreciate his stake in Switchdigital, which was awarded a London-wide digital radio "multiplex" licence in April. Last week it started broadcasting its first services. Crucially, Carphone Warehouse is a (5%) shareholder.

Simon Spanswick, director of Switchdigital, says: "The BBC was led up the garden path by manufacturers promising equipment which never arrived. But Carphone Warehouse has seen the digital opportunities, as have a lot of consumer electronics companies."

MacKenzie adds: "The market is beginning to value the bandwidth after discounting it before. It's all part of the convergence taking place around all media companies." Yet, he acknowledges, "at the moment it is more of a business than a consumer dynamic".

Everyone now expects hot competition for future licences. Up to now only the two in London were conteste, the rest going to established radio operators - GWR, Capital, Emap and Score (Scottish Radio) - in the areas in question.

Chrysalis Radio chief executive Phil Riley, who has just put Heart 106.2 on Switchdigital, says: "We are passionate believers in digital, this will be the first of many". A further reason for the buzz was graphically demonstrated at ITN's briefing on its 24-hour news channel plans. Chief executive Stewart Purvis gave a star role, alongside Julia Somerville and Carol Barnes, to an eye-catching device resembling a silver saucer. On the market this autumn, the "Wavefinder" can feed news and provide internet access to laptops or PCs.

This development is backed by Psion, the hand-held computer specialist, and will be its first digital radio product. It was also the talk of last Thursday's annual meeting of the Commercial Radio Companies Association, attended by Culture Secretary Chris Smith - who naturally warned that there was still some way to go before consumers saw something for them in digital radio. Who knows if people will want a Wavefinder aerial? And then bother to hook it to their laptop? It sounds like a City trader's toy. But the Wavefinder and products like it are generating excitement about a new generation of mobile hand-held "palm" products, which will be phones, mini-laptops and radios, all rolled into one.

When you're not on the mobile phone, you could be listening to one of 30 carefully streamed music stations through ear-phones. And ordering a track you like over this new e-commerce device. Who is to say whether the pundits are right or wrong?

Simon Cole, chief executive of Unique Broadcasting, the independent radio company best known for producing the Pepsi Network Chart, says: "Digital radio is much more than just audio. It has an opportunity to be part of the converging, multi-content future. Those manufacturers spending time making big grey boxes to plug into hi-fis at £400 so you get slightly better reception for Classic FM are wasting their time. No one is going to pay so much for that. But if you can plug a receiver for your PC to a device you carry around in your pocket, that's different."

Unique's holding company, UBC plc, is itself floating on Aim (the alter native investment market) today, raising £5m which will partly fund its involvement in the Wavefinder approach to digital radio.

There is the unmistakable sound of a digital buzz in GWR's recent annual results. Already the UK's most important commercial radio operator - a dominance reinforced by its takeover of the Daily Mail and General Trust's radio holdings - the company that controls Classic FM also owns 63% of the sole national commercial multiplex, Digital One, which was launched last November. "We have a commanding position in digital radio and the take-up is encouraging," says GWR chairman Henry Meakin.

What about old-fashioned radio services, programmes that people listen to? Well, some variety is starting to appear, to target older listeners and those with a hunger for culture. Talk and Bloomberg start their money news service next month. One Word, a speech-based cultural station featuring readings from books (run by Unique but also backed by the Guardian Media Group), launched in May.

Despite the current flurry of activity, the Radio Authority has barely begun allocating licences, with the first ones for big regional territories, such as central Scotland and north-west England, starting this autumn. It seems inevitable that auctioning spectrum will become an issue in the current debate about future regulation of communications: once there is competition, price provides a way to decide.

As for the BBC, the sadder but wiser digital pioneer finds itself in the middle of a re-examination of its priorities, ordered by Greg Dyke, at the very moment when the market is taking off. Plans for new services on its own public service digital radio multiplex will have to pass new government tests.

"We have had years when manufacturers promised us sets but they did not turn up," says the BBC's Glyn Jones, managing editor of its digital radio division. "They are in the shops. But we have learned to ask them questions like 'when is production starting?' Manufacturers are now naming factories for production, giving details of chips, in the run-up to Christmas. That is building confidence."

The BBC is "simulcasting" its five radio networks digitally and piloting parliamentary coverage, extended sports coverage and the World Service. But new channel ideas - comedy, Asian services, archive programming, oldie pop "gold" and dance and rap music- are on hold.

Jones is unconvinced by the convergence buzz. "Digital radio has been driven so far by people who like radio. They're Radio 3 listeners, music fans. I think radio listening is going to drive it. Not internet usage."

But then radio, as he observes, is a bizarre product. You can pay £2,000 for a snazzy tuner, or collect tokens and get a cheap trannie free. Kelvin MacKenzie has the last word: "I'll be astonished if there is a sizeable audience for digital for about five to seven years. But we are at the beginning of things changing now."

fields.headline: Trescothick knocks on England's door
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes  to get the lowdown on one of the performances of  the week. Today we talk to Marcus Trescothick, Somerset's 24-year-old opening bat, about the innings which propelled him into the England squad for the Triangular Tournament
fields.trailText: Marcus Trescothick, the left-handed Somerset opener and vice-captain, made a stylish 90 against Kent last Thursday in the Championship match at Maidstone. It followed a string of impressive performances - he has a first-class average of over 40 this season. Trescothick has been playing for Somerset since he was 17 and was tipped for early stardom - he has played for England's Under-18, Under-19 and 'A' sides.
fields.body:
Marcus Trescothick, the left-handed Somerset opener and vice-captain, made a stylish 90 against Kent last Thursday in the Championship match at Maidstone. It followed a string of impressive performances - he has a first-class average of over 40 this season. fields.headline: Chechen rebels launch suicide attacks
fields.trailText: Chechen rebels have struck hard at Russian troops in a series of suicide truck bombings that have left at least 49 dead in the breakaway province.
fields.body:
Chechen rebels have struck hard at Russian troops in a series of suicide truck bombings that have left at least 49 dead in the breakaway province.

Most of the dead were soldiers, but eight civilians also perished in a wave of nearly simultaneous attacks on several Russian-controlled cities yesterday evening.

"The terrorists' targets in all cases were the military commandants' buildings and places where Russian troops were located, vitally important buildings on Chechnya's territory," said Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the Kremlin's Chechnya spokesman.

In the deadliest attack, at least 25 Russian servicemen were killed and 81 wounded when a truck exploded outside a dormitory housing Russian troops in Argun, the emergency situations ministry said. Four people were missing after the second floor of the building collapsed in the blast.

Two servicemen and eight civilians were killed in two truck-bomb attacks in Gudermes, the republic's second-largest city. A further three soldiers were killed in a shootout with rebels after one of the bombings in Gudermes, the headquarters of the Kremlin-appointed pro-Moscow Chechen government.

Two soldiers were killed in Urus-Martan, when a truck filled with explosives tried to break through the defences of a building housing the military commandant's office and an interior ministry office, Mr Yastrzhembsky said.

In yet another attack, three people were killed and 20 were wounded in a truck bombing near Novogrozny. In all but one of the incidents, Russian troops opened fire on the bomb-laden trucks and caused the explosions. Each of the trucks carried three to five tons of explosive, NTV television reported.

Rebel leaders said the attacks are in reply to Russian officials' frequent claims that Russian forces had put an end to organised resistance.

"This was a planned action to carry out terrorist acts," said Chechen rebel commander Ramzan Akhmadov. The biggest attack on Sunday targeted an interior ministry dormitory on the outskirts of Argun, nine miles east of Grozny. A special police unit was staying in the building, which was not adequately reinforced, Russian officials said. A neighbouring building was also destroyed.

Russian officials say they have all but won the war to re-establish control over the rebellious region, but the latest wave of attacks shows that the rebels are still active and can launch deadly attacks at will. Russian officials say some rebels have melted into the civilian population, and are drawing on weapon caches hidden in Russian-controlled territory.

Others point to a lack of discipline among Russian troops, including heavy drinking and bribe taking. Russian military commanders gathered Monday in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don for a closed-door meeting on strengthening order in the police and armed forces.

Russian troops were driven out of Chechnya in a 1994-96 war and have since battled to re-establish control in the breakaway province.

They returned after Chechnya-based Islamic militants raided several villages in the neighbouring Russian region of Dagestan. The government also blamed Chechens when 300 people died in apartment bombings.

Vladimir Putin easily won this year's presidential elections after Russian troops seized most of Chechnya in a lightning campaign. But capturing the province and subduing is proving to be two entirely different matters.

fields.headline: Mayor Livingstone sworn in
fields.standfirst: Inaugural speech calls for Britain to join euro
fields.trailText:
Ken Livingstone took office today as London's first elected mayor and used his inaugural speech to urge the government to join the single currency.
 
As Mayor Livingstone and his 25-member cross-party London Assembly formally assumed their powers to administer a
£3.5bn budget and oversee services including transport, police and fire protection, the man once dubbed Red Ken insisted that membership of the euro was vital to maintain London's status as the world's
most internationalised city.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone took office today as London's first elected mayor and used his inaugural speech to urge the government to join the single currency. As Mayor Livingstone and his 25-member cross-party London Assembly formally assumed their powers to administer a £3.5bn budget and oversee services including transport, police and fire protection, the man once dubbed Red Ken insisted that membership of the euro was vital to maintain London's status as the world's most internationalised city.

The capital's ability to take advantage of the trend of globalisation and new technology depended the prosperity of the entire UK, he added.

Mr Livingstone made it clear he did not want to burn his bridges with Labour, despite standing as an independent in the May 4 election after failing to secure the Labour nomination. He said he was still hoping to be the party's official candidate in the next mayoral election in 2004.

The mayor endorsed Tony Blair's "tough on crime and tough on the causes of crime" slogan as the prime minister announced a "zero tolerance" policy on street crime and violence.

Mr Livingstone sought to distance himself from extremist activists by denouncing the "anarchist yobs" who took part in London's May Day riots as "a threat not only to law and order in the city, but its prosperity". But Mr Livingstone showed that he still harks back to his days as leftwing leader of the Greater London Council when he inadvertently referred to setting up the "GLC internet site" this week.

Speaking of the need for London to compete with Berlin and Paris as the leading financial and economic centre of Europe, Mr Livingstone said that London must match the investment in infrastructure and culture and the membership of the euro which gave the German and French capitals advantages.

He said: "If London does not have the adequate resources to compete with this, whatever its current advantages, the entire UK economy will be weakened. "This has to be understood by central government."

Mr Livingstone added: "Creating a squalid London with a broken-down transport system, deep pools of poverty and inadequate policing will not aid the rest of the UK's regions, but weaken the attractiveness of the whole economy of the country."

He said London's representatives "must push for the UK to join the euro as the only way to ensure London remains the financial centre of Europe."

At a press conference after the speech, Mr Livingstone said that his discussions with leading international companies had convinced him that they were planning investment on the assumption that Britain would join the euro by around 2003 and would rethink their multimillion pound plans if this looked unlikely.

"London would be devastated if it became clear that over a decade we weren't going to join," he said. "If you are pushing the government [to join the euro] you are pushing at an open door.

"I don't think there is a split in the government about whether or not to join the euro, the issue is simply at what time we tell the British people we are going to join the euro."

Mr Livingstone maintained his opposition to government policy for a public-private partnership to fund improvements to the London Underground, calling on it to "respect the wishes of the people of London by abandoning partial privatisation and break-up of the Tube".

Transport was "the real test of my mayoralty", he said, adding: "If I get it wrong I will be a one-term mayor."

He said that, despite public confrontation over the Tube, he had found "broad agreement with ministers" over the need for large-scale investment in London's transport system.

He said he was "optimistic" that London's budget for transport spending for the next three years - due to be announced later this month - would be at least 50%, if not 100%, higher than the £1.8bn expected.

He reaffirmed his commitment to congestion charging in central London, saying he expected charges to run at around £5 a day on weekdays.

Mr Livingstone also threatened bus operators with a new penalty system of fines for delays and outlined plans for a freeze on bus fares and a single blanket fare for bus travel in London.

Mr Livingstone sought to play down suggestions that he would seek to use the mayor's office as a platform from which to attack the New Labour leadership.

He said: "There is not one major decision taken since my election that has been affected by whether I was inside or outside the Labour party. Nor will there be during the next four years."

London Assembly chairman Trevor Philips - deputy to official Labour candidate Mr Dobson during the election campaign - warned Mr Livingstone not to use the mayoral office to pursue personal political goals.

He said: "We [GLA members] want to influence your policies and we want to work with you, and should you be successful, we will carry you in triumph through the streets - figuratively speaking at least."

He added: "This is a democracy, not a Kenocracy. If you decide to use your position to advance politics that are not in the interests of Londoners or choose to use the platform for other political ends, we will, I promise, kick your ass."

fields.headline: Policing yob culture
fields.standfirst: Ahead of a Downing Street summit focusing on crime this week, Chris Alden explains the government's crime reduction strategy
fields.trailText: Ahead of a Downing Street summit focusing on crime this week, Chris Alden explains the government's crime reduction strategy.
fields.body:
Why are yobs in the news?
This issue really kicked off two weeks ago, when Uefa - the governing body for football in Europe - made a stand against English hooliganism at Euro 2000. After a Saturday of alcohol-fuelled trouble in Brussels and Charleroi, Uefa warned that any repeat would see England kicked out of the tournament. Amid the ensuing hysteria, many commentators began to point out that the problem wasn't specific to football - and the Home Office saw its chance to get tough.

Why?
Because crime is rising. Regardless of whether yob culture is responsible, Jack Straw is expecting the annual recorded crime figures to show a rise in violent crime of up to 19%, and a rise in all crime of 3.8%. Against such a background, he has to be seen to be acting now, or see shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe gain the upper ground on law and order.

So what is the government doing?
In the past week, the government has been putting its feelers out over three key law enforcement measures. First, home secretary Jack Straw has said he wants to see greater use of his zero-tolerance "anti-social behaviour orders" - by which courts can threaten to jail those who are persistently disorderly but not convicted of specific crime. Second, the Home Office said it wants to give courts powers to shut down the so-called "thug pubs" which become hotspots for violence in city centres. Third and most controversially, prime minister Tony Blair advocated allowing police the power to levy on-the-spot fines for "drunken, noisy, loutish and antisocial behaviour" - saying "if the police want that power they should get that power." He will find out whether they do at a summit at Downing Street today, attended by the chief constables of England and Wales.

Will they support him?
They are decidedly sceptical, but don't want to be seen as undermining the law and order effort. On the record, one chief constable talked of "considerable practical and legal problems" with Blair's on-the-spot fine idea. But off it, many newspapers carry quotes from unnamed "senior officers" said to be unhappy at the politicisation of the crime agenda, the "initiative overload" and, of course, the lack of resources.

So what does the future hold?
Whatever happens, it's got little to do with the yobs. Mr Blair is said to be considering the radical reform of the police service as a project for his second term - an initiative aimed at improving efficiency, management and the way officers respond to the public. If the precedents of health and education reforms are anything to go by, we should sit tight and wait for the backlash.

Where can I find out more?
Police Service
Police Federation of England and Wales
Home Office

Books on BOL.com
Among the Thugs, by Bill Buford
Fight Club, by Chuck Palahniuk
Policing, Vols 1 and 2, by Robert Reiner
