webTitle: The man who outfoxed the Mexican monolith

fields.headline: The man who outfoxed the Mexican monolith
fields.standfirst: More about the Mexican elections
fields.trailText: Vicente Fox, Mexico's new president-elect, is a man of contrasts who has achieved success through a combination of old-time campaigning and new-style marketing.
fields.body:
Vicente Fox, Mexico's new president-elect, is a man of contrasts who has achieved success through a combination of old-time campaigning and new-style marketing.

Tall and rugged, with a booming voice and a loose tongue, he appeals to poor farmers as the local boy who still wears cowboy boots on his ranch. With bankers, he's the former top executive who has the strong hand Mexico needs to join the developed world.

The former Coca-Cola regional president, who turned 58 yesterday, stunned the country by defeating Francisco Labastida, whose Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, has ruled Mexico for 71 years.

Mr Fox won by promising to bring change to Mexico: a cleaner, more efficient government, a cabinet made up of experts from several different parties, a peaceful transition of power.

His underdog campaign helped reassure any doubters that, despite the ruling party's historical dominance, Mexico has become a democracy.

Mr Fox has done little in line with tradition. He formally announced his candidacy three years ago - far before any other presidential candidate ever had. He had been hinting at a run for the presidency since 1993, even before he was elected governor of the small but populous state of Guanajuato in 1995.

His centre-right National Action party considered him an outsider, but no one dared challenge him by the time he was chosen last year as the party's nominee.

As the campaign heated up he spent weekends travelling around Mexico, building a giant "Friends of Fox" support network and raising large amounts of money. He began a huge advertising campaign on radio, television and billboards, though he was forced to drop a negative TV ad which appeared to question Mr Labastida's sexuality.

Mr Fox was the subject of similar abuse from Labastida supporters who took shots at the challenger's masculinity with allusions to his separation from his wife and the fact that he has four adopted children.

On the issues, Mr Fox did not differ hugely from Mr Labastida. Both candidates pledged to fight crime and corruption, improve education and make sure that Mexico's poor see the benefits of a stronger economy.

In style, the two had little in common. Mr Labastida is slight and gaunt, a soft-spoken gentleman with little charisma. Mr Fox is known for wearing cowboy boots and a giant "FOX" belt buckle, and he has been criticised for using sometimes obscene street slang during campaign rallies.

After his victory he poked fun at his reputation for vulgarity, telling supporters: "I'm not going to use rude language. But I will tell you that I feel darn good."

fields.headline: The day of reckoning
fields.standfirst: Nothing strikes fear into a teacher's heart like the news that the inspectors are coming. Last month all 12 teachers at a south London primary threw in the towel after receiving a bad report. Gary Younge found out what happened when one school experienced the Ofsted treatment
fields.trailText: Nothing strikes fear into a teacher's heart like the news that the inspectors are coming. Last month all 12 teachers at a south London primary threw in the towel after receiving a bad report. Gary Younge found out what happened when one school experienced the Ofsted treatment
fields.body:
In March last year David Cripps, the headteacher of Radburn primary school in Letchworth, Hertfordshire, checked the post, saw the future and felt a deep wave of nausea swell up inside him. "We get a lot of mail from Ofsted," he says. "But if you get one with a contract number on the envelope then that can only mean one thing - you're going to be inspected. When I saw it I just felt sick. I knew that it was going to take a year out of my life. I knew that there was going to be this colossal amount of work to do and that we would have to put on this big show. I just knew it was going to be horrendous. And it was."

The letter gave six months' notice of the inspectors' visit. No sooner had it arrived than three teachers and one school assistant announced their departure, insisting that they would not go through another Ofsted inspection - the school had been tested in 1996.

Cripps holds up two ring-bound folders full of policies reviewed and revised specifically for the report. In the month running up to the inspectors' arrival, he and his deputy worked from 8am until 8pm every day including weekends. The entire mood of the school changed. "There was just this quiet, manic hysteria," says one teacher.

It seems like an extreme emotional reaction to what is ultimately a 36-page report on the performance of your school. But not, says the chair of the school governors, when you consider the stakes. "If you failed then a lot of staff would probably leave or the head could be fired," says Terry Ware.

Last week all 12 teachers at a primary school in south west London resigned following an Ofsted inspection. Moor Lane junior school in Chessington was found to have "serious weaknesses" by inspectors last April. After a follow-up inspection last month they told the headmistress and chair of governors that "insufficient progress" had been made. The chairman of the governors said the school had been "wrecked" by Ofsted's decision.

In January, a teacher in Eynesbury, Cambridgeshire, committed suicide after Ofsted inspectors criticised her teaching. Pamela Relf, 57, jumped into a river, leaving a handwritten note which made it clear that she could no longer cope with the stress of modern teaching. The school had been found to have "serious weaknesses". Last month Ofsted partly upheld a complaint brought by the school, admitting that there had been a breakdown in communication between its inspection team and members of the staff.

There are basically three things that can happen as a result of a report from the Office for Standards in Education. Inspectors can pass a school, fail it, or decide that it has "serious weaknesses". If a school fails it then goes on to "special measures". The headteacher has to provide an action plan which is sent to the secretary of state for education. Around six months later, inspectors will return to find out whether the school is following its action plan and they will continue to return on a termly basis. The school is expected to be able to turn itself around and get off special measures within two years.

A school with "serious weaknesses" goes through a similar but less extreme procedure and is expected to address its problems within a year.

At Radburn primary, the inspectors finally arrived on a Monday from a hotel they were staying in nearby. It was three weeks into a new school year and Cripps had three new teachers, some of whom were newly qualified. "By this stage," says Cripps, "I felt completely detached." After a short talk the inspectors roamed around the classrooms during lessons. "You just hope that one of the children isn't going to start playing up or come up with something inappropriate," says one teacher. At the end of the day the inspectors told Cripps they had seen one or two problems in the lessons they had seen. He left school late feeling depressed.

On Tuesday they observed more classes and delivered far more positive feedback. "At this stage I went from thinking this is going to be disastrous to this is going to be OK," he says. But when an inspector walked into one class, one of the teachers tried to defuse the tension by making a joke: "I think you must have the wrong room," he said. It fell horribly flat. "No I haven't," replied the inspector. "I can visit any class in the school."

On Wednesday Cripps had a couple of interviews with the inspectors. They asked him about long-term financial planning and he tried to explain that it was not possible to plan long term when you are not in control of your income and funding changes from year to year. "I might as well have been speaking a different language," he says.

That night they told him the school was not a failing school. But that only convinced him they would decide it had serious weaknesses. "Thursday was dreadful. They were supposed to tell us their verdict the next day but I looked so awful that they asked if I would like to know that evening. I said yes and so they went away and then pulled it together and told us the result. He talked about the strengths and then the weaknesses and I was waiting for him to say 'serious weaknesses'. After a while I just stopped him and said, 'Sorry, do you mean serious weaknesses?', and he said, 'No, sorry I should have made that clear. There are no serious weaknesses.'

"Afterwards I felt relieved but mostly I just felt crushed and exhausted."

During the last inspection cycle around 3% of primary schools failed, and around 10% were found to have "serious weaknesses". The reality of working in a failed school, however, is far less clinical than the statistics. "It just creates a mood where everyone thinks it is all right to blame the school for everything," says one teacher who used to work in a failed school. The pressure not to fail comes not just from the school but from the local education authority. If there is a large number of failed schools in one area the government could remove the provision of education from its tasks and take it over itself or hand it over to a private company. By the time these strains have trickled down to ordinary teachers the stress can just be all too much.

Ofsted says it has now reduced the warning it gives schools to six weeks so staff have less time to worry. Schools that get good reports and have consistently high scores in the Standard Attainment Tasks (Sats) will now get less rigorous, shorter inspections. "We have always recognised that inspection is a stressful business," says a spokesman. "Inspectors don't expect to be liked. Partly because it is human nature not to like someone who is there to pass judgment on your work and, more significantly, because teachers have never had to do anything like this before. It is a shock to their collective system."

Teachers have had a lot of shocks to the system in recent years - Sats, literacy and numeracy hours, the national curriculum - and Ofsted inspections will soon be followed by performance-related pay. Those who have been in the profession more than a decade talk as though they are being drowned under relentless tidal waves of initiatives. Yet Ofsted was more than just one more broadside in the battle to overhaul the education system.

Created in 1992, it was born out of the wave of consumer rights initiatives - from the Citizen's Charter to the cone hotline - which can be identified, for better or for worse, as Majorism. "Before Ofsted came along nobody knew what was going on in our schools," says the Ofsted spokesman. "There was no way of the customer, the parents and the children, knowing how good an education children were getting.

"Sensible schools would see it as a free consultancy. It isn't about criticism but about identifying what a school does well and what it does badly."

Cripps does not see it that way. He describes most of the inspectors who came to his school as "pleasant" and "humane" people doing a terrible job. One of them, however, told his deputy: "This is an elite team." When a teacher pointed to the concrete statues the children made in the front of the school as part of a project, the inspector said: "I've seen better."

Ofsted, points out one former inspector, is there to judge, not to advise. "It is essentially punitive. I think if it were supportive it would make a big difference but that is not its function. At the end of the day a lot of it comes down to whether you have a good team of inspectors or not and that hardly seems fair."

So Radburn primary school didn't fail. There was never really any question that it would fail. This small school in Britain's first garden city, which sits on a working-class estate created from the overspill from north London, does not have any of the advantages of schools in middle-class areas. But nor is it located in an area of major deprivation. Of its 226 full-time pupils, 30 have English as an additional language, 60 are entitled to free school meals and 56 are registered as having special educational needs. As such, demands on its teachers are tougher than for some but less extreme than for many. And given the circumstances, it manages well. The Sats at seven and 11 suggest that its average intake arrives well below the national average at seven and leaves only marginally below the national average at 11, indicating considerable improvement.

In this parallel universe where semantics are everything, the Ofsted report claimed there were "significant weaknesses" but not "serious weaknesses" at the primary. Among the findings was real praise. ("Teachers manage behaviour well in lessons." "Pupils are well-behaved and their attitudes to work are good.")

But there were also criticisms. The school had not done enough to improve on problems raised during the last inspection, it was claimed. "The strategic management, financial planning and performance monitory" were "unsatisfactory"; "effective strategies for staff appraisal and the identification of professional development needs," had not been implemented; and "attainment in English and mathematics is generally below average and significantly below average in writing across the school". Inspectors recommended taking 10 minutes off the lunch hour and adding five to the end of the school day to create more time for the basics. The teachers went into post-Ofsted depression - that flat, numb feeling that comes with a sudden release of pressure. Three governors resigned. "They were volunteers and the report was demanding more than many of them were prepared to give," says Ware, the chair of governors.

"From their [the inspectors'] point of view the whole thing is completely data-driven," says Cripps. "It's one way of looking at the world but it's not one that I would subscribe to. I consider my work child-driven. There is a lot of this work that you simply cannot quantify in a report but which is essential to the job." Other teachers said there were some useful things to come out of the report, but none believed that the pain justified the gain.

Sitting outside Cripps' office is "the biter" - a small boy who bit a small girl because she kept saying she was his girlfriend. Soon afterwards comes another small boy who has been accused of pulling a different girl's hair in the playground. He starts off insisting that he didn't touch her. Then he concedes that he might have flicked her.

"It was just a joke," he tells Cripps.

"A joke for you or a joke for her, because it doesn't look like she found it funny," says Cripps, and points him to the floor on the other side of his office door. And so it goes on. The ebb and flow of little people and their misdemeanours, staff requests, paperwork and phone calls. The variety and scale of work that Cripps insists leaves little time for the kind of administrative tasks that would please Ofsted.

The biter is dismissed just after 2pm and rejoins his class. An hour later, parents gather at the school gate to collect their children. School finishes at 3.10. Next term it will be 3.15. Another five minutes, courtesy of Ofsted.

webTitle: Briton sentenced to death for drug trafficking

fields.headline: Briton sentenced to death for drug trafficking
fields.trailText: A British man who claims he was framed by an airport security officer was convicted today by a  Malaysian judge of trafficking heroin and sentenced to death by hanging.
fields.body:
A British man who claims he was framed by an airport security officer was convicted today by a Malaysian judge of trafficking heroin and sentenced to death by hanging.

Penang high court judge Zaleha Zahari said she was satisfied with the evidence of prosecution witnesses and that defendant David Anthony Chell, 57, took a calculated risk by hiding the drug in his underwear, the Bernama news agency reported.

"Well done," Chell was quoted as saying to the judge in response to the verdict. "You should be ashamed of yourself, madam. I hope you'll not sleep for a year."

Chell, a psychiatric nurse from Stoke-on-Trent, quickly filed an appeal.

Chell was arrested at the Bayan Lepas International Airport in northern Penang state in October 1998, and charged with smuggling 189.86 grams of heroin.

Malaysian customs officials say they found a pouch with the drug in Chell's underwear. Chell denies the charges and accused officials of planting the heroin, saying one of the security personnel had taken it from underneath a cushion at a corner of the airport examination room.

fields.headline: French press hail 'monumental' triumph
fields.trailText: The French press heralded their side's Euro 2000 triumph as "Monumental", "Historic" and "Magic" in the aftermath of Les Bleus 2-1 victory over Italy.
fields.body:
The French press heralded their side's Euro 2000 triumph as "Monumental", "Historic" and "Magic" in the aftermath of Les Bleus 2-1 victory over Italy.

The Sunday paper Journal du Dimanche published a special extra edition after the match dedicated to France's "Fabulous victory" and tracing the team's progress to the trophy.

The sports daily L'Equipe said "the France team has gone down in history" after becoming the first side ever to add the European title to their world crown.

"Two years ago, after their victory in the World Cup final, the Bleus appeared to have reached their summit. But what they have managed to do in this Euro... places them higher in football's historical hierarchy," L'Equipe enthused in a front-page editorial.

France Soir, whose Monday edition was on the Champs Elysees in the early hours as 400,000 revellers gathered to celebrate the victory, said France are "Champions of the universe". Liberation's front page carried little more than the word "Bis" (same again) in giant letters and headlined their editorial "Winning culture."

It explained the unprecedented success by putting it down to the experience gained by the large number of France's squad in "the foreign championships, notably Italian and English, where they have acquired a winning culture which they badly lacked."

It also pointed to "the alchemy of the Bleus, combining an unparalleled physical power and technical virtuosity."

webTitle: Italian press mourn the Azzurri's dismal luck

fields.headline: Italian press mourn the Azzurri's dismal luck
fields.trailText: The Italian media cursed their side's dismal luck and "intolerable" refereeing in the aftermath of their 2-1 defeat by France in the Euro 2000 final - but the players awoke to find they had been made Knights of the Republic.
fields.body:
The Italian media cursed their side's dismal luck and "intolerable" refereeing in the aftermath of their 2-1 defeat by France in the Euro 2000 final - but the players awoke to find they had been made Knights of the Republic.

Newspapers, struggling to put a brave face on things, also praised the battling performance of the side they had written off before the start of the tournament. The appreciation was echoed by Italian President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi, who watched the match and went into the changing room afterwards to offer his condolences. He later made all the players Knights of the Republic.

Reflecting the Italian loss to a golden goal by David Trezeguet, Corriere dello Sport devoted half of its front page to a headline, in giant black letters, reading "What bad luck". Underneath it claimed: "We deserved the title."

"We got into to the final by a stroke of luck because the Dutch deserved to go through," claimed L'Unita newspaper said in a front-page editorial. "And we were beaten in the final by a stroke of bad luck. We deserved to win yesterday's match."

La Stampa daily, speaking for many Italians, said Swedish referee Anders Frisk "dragged the stoppage time on intolerably". "Accursed minute!" ran the headline in Il Messaggero daily. Sports bible Gazzetta dello Sport called it "hateful".

But commentators consoled themselves with Italy's improved performance after their ultra-defensive play in the semi-finals. "What a shame. Italy were great," Gazzetta's headline said.

"After so much criticism of our speculative style of soccer, Italy had shown World Cup champions France that it could play as well or better," Gazzetta's editor Candido Cannavo said.

"Thanks anyway, Azzurri," ran La Stampa's headline.

RAI state radio commented wryly that Italy were used to winning by playing badly, but not to losing when they played well. Former Italy coach Arrigo Sacchi, a stern critic of Italy's traditionally defensive play, offered bitter-sweet praise, saying in an editorial in La Stampa that France perhaps deserved to win but that Italy had been "magnificent".

"They fought with fury, doggedly, with courage. No one held back. This team could not have done any better," he said.

In the search for a scapegoat, most pointed the finger at striker Alessandro Del Piero, who missed two chances that could have sealed Italy's victory. A photograph of him, flat on his back on the pitch, his hands over his eyes, summed up Italy's despair on many newspaper front pages.

"Next season will be the crucial one to see what's left of the great champion we once knew," Corriere dello Sport said.

fields.headline: Opposition wins Mexico election
fields.standfirst:
End of an era as party is ousted after 71 years

More about the Mexican election
fields.trailText: Vicente Fox, a tough-talking former Coca-Cola executive, shattered the governing party's 71-year hold on the  Mexican presidency in a stunning electoral victory that marked a climax in the transition to democracy.
fields.body:
Vicente Fox, a tough-talking former Coca-Cola executive, shattered the governing party's 71-year hold on the Mexican presidency in a stunning electoral victory that marked a climax in the transition to democracy.

The victory threw Mexico's entire political culture in reverse. The Institutional Revolutionary Party, the world's longest-governing party, suddenly found itself in the opposition, and a party that long had only limited regional support became Mexico's most powerful overnight.

As results streamed in from yesterday's elections, Mr Fox's centre-right National Action party also won two governorships and appeared headed to becoming the dominant party in congress.

"Today Mexico is already different. Today Mexico enters the 21st century with its right foot forward," Mr Fox told 15,000 supporters at an early-morning rally today under the gilded angel of Mexico City's independence monument. He takes office on December 1. With 78% of the official count tallied early today, Mr Fox had 44.3% and Francisco Labastida of the ruling party had 34.3%, a gap likely to narrow as rural votes come in. Preliminary figures showed turnout was a record 65%. Just three hours after the voting booths closed - with exit polls and preliminary results showing a clear Fox advantage - President Ernesto Zedillo acknowledged the opposition's win in a nationally televised speech and said he had called to congratulate him.

"Today we have been able to prove that ours is already a mature democracy, with solid and trustworthy institutions and especially with a conscientious and civic-minded citizenry," Mr Zedillo said.

It was a sight that no Mexican had ever seen: their president conceding his party's defeat to the opposition. The governing party, known as the PRI, has long been synonymous with Mexico's national identity. For most of its history, it used fear and favours to maintain ironclad control over almost all aspects of Mexican political life.

Although reforms had cleaned up Mexico's electoral process and opposition candidates had won governorships and ended the PRI's majority in congress, Mexico's powerful presidency had seemed untouchable until yesterday. Mr Fox began his campaign three years ago as a governor of a small state with little national recognition. His National Action party had only limited, regional support.

He built a giant campaign war chest, advertised heavily and quickly climbed in the polls. Wearing cowboy boots and a giant "Fox" belt buckle, the tall, rugged-looking Fox stressed both his roots on a rural ranch and his business savvy as the former regional president of Coca-Cola.

He campaigned promising to fight corruption, improve education and help the poor. But his real message was summed up in his one-word campaign slogan: "ya" or "enough already." He argued it was time for change and only he could beat the PRI.

Mr Labastida, the PRI candidate, was an uncharismatic party loyalist who was second in command in the Zedillo government. Given President Zedillo's popularity and the power of the PRI's political machine, he was the favourite to win the presidency.

The third-place candidate, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the leftwing Democratic Revolution party, was seen as an obstacle to a Fox victory. Standing in his third consecutive presidential race, the veteran leftwinger had little hope of winning, but was expected to divide the anti-PRI vote. Many Mexicans believe he won the 1988 elections, only to be cheated out of a victory by fraud. Most pre-election opinion polls had shown Mr Labastida with a slight lead over Mr Fox, but with a margin tight enough to be considered a statistical tie.

Shortly after Mr Zedillo spoke, Mr Labastida conceded defeat, saying: "The citizens have made a decision that we should respect, and I'll set the example myself."

The PRI lost not only the presidency, but almost everything else as well. Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador of the PRD won the mayorship of Mexico City, while the PAN captured the governorship of Morelos state from the PRI, and held on to the governorship of Mr Fox's home state of Guanajuato.

In his victory speeches, Mr Fox - who also celebrated his 58th birthday yesterday - pledged a peaceful transition and economically responsible policies. "To the international community, we say we shall respect all our commitments.

"We will act with a high sense of responsibility and a firm commitment to economic stability. Our first task will be a transition without rancour, and without resentment."

Addressing tens of thousands of flag-waving supporters who poured on to the streets of Mexico City and other towns, Mr Fox stressed his desire to reach out to other parties and to all Mexicans, saying: "From today forward, we need to unite... We have to work together to make Mexico the great country we have all dreamed of."

"Let's celebrate today, because beginning tomorrow there's a lot of work to do."

Mr Fox pledges to halt corruption, jump-start the economy with foreign investment and jobs programmes and nearly double spending for public education. He favours an agreement with the United States that would let workers cross the border freely.

Yesterday's vote was the first in more than a century in which the outcome was not clear beforehand. Despite hundreds of allegations of pressure and vote-buying - mostly levelled at the ruling party - the elections were widely seen as Mexico's fairest ever.

Opposition parties had unprecedented access to advertising and news coverage and a record 10,000 local poll watchers and 860 foreign observers were stationed at polling centres to prevent fraud.

Observer groups and opposition parties claimed that local PRI officials gave gifts in return for promised votes or warned poor people that government aid would be cut off if they backed the opposition. But the head of the electoral institute, Jose Woldenberg, said that there had been few problems and that his staff "tell us we are experiencing exemplary elections".

webTitle: You bet your life: the final result

fields.headline: You bet your life: the final result
fields.trailText: The final standings:
fields.body:
The final standings:

Scott Murray £300
Sean Ingle £197.97
Mike Hodgkinson £7.08
Paul MacInnes £0

During the past twenty-three days, Football Unlimited's finest went head-to-head in a feast of betting which has been every bit as enthralling and nail-biting as Euro 2000 itself. Well, to some of us anyway.

Armed with £50 each from kind internet betting firm Blue Square, we had to use our skill, cunning and a Watchdog-esque eye for a bargain to recommend the best value bet each day. The name of the game was "You bet your life" - and the aim was to win as much money (for charity, of course) as possible.

At the start betting was cautious: a fiver here, a tenner there. But soon a pattern began to emerge. Scott Murray and Sean Ingle slowly accumulated funds with safe, low-odds bets (Italy to beat Turkey, Holland and France to beat Czech Republic and Denmark respectively).

Mike Hodgkinson rocked 'n' rolled between brave bets (£10 on Turkish substitute Sergan Yalcan to score first goal against Sweden) which never came off, and clever ones (£10 on Turkey to beat Belgium) which often did. And last - from the very beginning - was Paul MacInnes, who never recovered from a shaky but unlucky start.

At the end of the group stages, Ingle and Murray stood neck and neck, with Hodgkinson within sniffing distance. MacInnes - despite rallying briefly after correctly predicting England to beat Germany - was falling fast and getting desperate. Bravely, he gambled his last £8.50 on Gaizka Mendieta to score first against France - the Spanish penalty ace scored second, and he was out.

But the quarter-finals were particularly good for Murray, whose sensible bets (a win double on Portugal and Italy, and France to beat Italy) came off and pushed him over the £100 mark, well clear of the limping pack.

A couple of days later, it seemed all over. The eagle-eyed Murray spotted that France were a 14-1 to beat Portugal with a golden goal and immediately staked £20 on it. Suddenly 20-odd days of shadow-boxing had ended with a swift KO; Murray was £400 up and more than £300 clear.

But was it really game over? The next day Ingle, helped admittedly by the hapless Dutch's inability to score from 12 yards, clawed more than £200 back when his £20 bet on Italy to beat Holland on penalties at 8-1 somehow came off.

It was all wonderfully set up for the final shoot-out. Alas, it didn't happen. Hodgkinson, by now down to his last £7, staked it all on a 100-1 punt on Emmanuel Petit to score the first goal and France to win 2-1. It was a good bet, if only because the pony-tailed poseur failed to appear in the starting line-up. Ingle also went big, staking £23 on France to win 2-0 at 8-1, but came up empty, as did Murray, who had France to win in 90 minutes.

Overall though it was a good Euro 2000 for our punters - if you had have followed all our advice you would have ended up £306.05 ahead, which isn't bad for a few minutes reading each day. More importantly we've made some money for the following charities.

Where the money will go

Scott Murray ends up on £300. He will donate his winnings to the "£12,000 for the year 2000" fund, in aid of Action for Solidarity, a paper which campaigns around core labour movement issues such as the welfare state and the anti-trade union laws and is sponsored by, amongst others, Tony Benn and John Pilger.

Sean Ingle won £197.97. He will donate his money to The Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths (FSID), the UK's leading cot death charity, and the MND Association, which supports people affected by Motor Neurone Disease and promotes research into the illness.

webTitle: Parents appeal for return of 'little princess'

fields.headline: Parents appeal for return of 'little princess'
fields.trailText: The parents of a missing eight-year-old girl have made an emotional televised appeal for her safe return.
fields.body:
The parents of a missing eight-year-old girl have made an emotional televised appeal for her safe return.

Sarah Payne disappeared on Saturday from near her grandparents home in West Sussex after a playtime tiff with her brothers.

Her tearful mother Sara said at a news conference at Littlehampton police station: "She's our life. Our family name for Sarah is 'our little princess' and that's what she is."

She added: "She's a soft gentle little girl, she hasn't got a horrible bone in her body."

Mrs Payne, with her husband Michael, said: "You can't understand what she means to us, we have a strong family and we don't survive well apart.

"We need her home now, today, as quickly as we possibly can, her brothers and sister are really not coping very well without her. Somebody out there must have seen her on that road.

"She's just not the type to wander, she just doesn't go from me, I just don't understand it. She needs to come home, she needs her family and we need her."

Sarah vanished after playing with her sister six, and brothers, aged 11 and 13, in fields at the village of Ferring, near Worthing. A search was launched but no trace of her has been found.

Police want to trace the drivers of two vehicles seen near where she disappeared amid fears she may have been abducted.

Sarah and her family, from Surrey, were visiting her grandparents in Peak Lane in Ferring.

fields.headline: Policing yob culture
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about lager louts and other riffraff, and what Tony Blair has in mind for them
fields.trailText: All you need to know about lager louts and other riffraff, and what Tony Blair has in mind for them.
fields.body:
1. Tony Blair is on a law and order kick. After his weekend speech urging on-the-spot fines for loutish behaviour, he is now proposing new police powers for 48-hour closure orders on rowdy pubs.

2. The prime minister will press his ideas on police chiefs and home secretary Jack Straw today, in Downing Street.

3. The Home Office already has a crime reduction strategy, with reduction of disorderly behaviour a high priority.

4.Police forces have been told to set targets for reducing crime, and the government wants to speed up what it calls youth justice.

5. The Police Federation, which represents officers up to the rank of Inspector, is not wildly enthusiastic about taking on new spot-fining powers.

6. Civil libertarians are opposed to extension of existing police law.

7. However, Blair's new tough-guy approach is likely to go down well with the temperance movement.

8. The Institute for Alcohol Studies has some thought-provoking information on alcohol and crime in general, and pub violence in particular.

9. There is a bleak school of thought that unless crime is curbed, inner cities will fester and decay over the next 25 years.

10. There's nothing funny about loutishness. Unless, that is, you follow the hilarious progress of the Yobs, as drawn by Tony Husband in Private Eye.

webTitle: The rebirth of football and the death of the BBC

fields.headline: The rebirth of football and the death of the BBC
fields.standfirst: Our viewer and reviewer ends his stint in front of the telly with a look back over a relaxing month
fields.trailText: I decided to stick with the BBC for the final mainly because I keep feeling sorry for them after the Match of the Day debacle. That and my innate conservatism, of course. Oh yes and I also needed to confirm what I'd begun to suspect about their football coverage.
fields.body:
I decided to stick with the BBC for the final mainly because I keep feeling sorry for them after the Match of the Day debacle. That and my innate conservatism, of course. Oh yes and I also needed to confirm what I'd begun to suspect about their football coverage.

It's no longer any good. In fact, if one were to equate television channels with teams at Euro 2000, then the BBC would probably represent Scotland. Not at the races and on this form, unlikely to be missed when the tournament reconvenes in four years time.

Their coverage has been sloppy with Gary Lineker lacking the requisite authority needed to keep his infantile panel in check. So we're left with Alan Hansen and Martin O'Neill bickering incessantly, each of them oblivious to the fact that the viewers have just switched channels. David O'Leary meanwhile, just sat in the corner, his face getting steadily redder as the tournament progressed.

ITV were England by the way, lots of overpaid players who've seen better days. Venables would be Ince, talks a good game but four years since he actually made a worthwhile contribution to one. Bob Wilson would be Derek Fazackerly or Arthur Cox (take your pick of the nonentities) and as for the hapless Phil Neville? The hopeless John Gregory of course. Des Lynam, a pleasant, genial man who knows little about football but so enjoys talking about it? Kevin Keegan obviously.

And the final? Well, the first-half was a relatively uneventful affair save for attempts by several Italian players to rearrange the features of Christophe Dugarry's face. All to no avail I'm afraid because, despite several clean hits on his face, he still looked like the unwashed, inebriated tramp you step over on the way home from work.

Unlike Dugarry's appearance, the football improved in the second half.

As for the tournament itself, well it hasn't been such a bad way to spend three weeks. According to Gary Lineker, we've witnessed the rebirth of football. I wouldn't go that far myself, but that's possibly because I was unaware that football had died in the first place.

webTitle: July 3: News in brief and casting couch

fields.headline: July 3: News in brief and casting couch
fields.trailText: George Lucas gets around Cuba embargo, Alex Baldwin reveals helicopter crashes, Ion Gruffud set for Disraeli role, and directors on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Cuba is to be allowed to see Star Wars: Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace thanks to director George Lucas. The long-standing US embargo prevents trade with Cuba, so Lucas donated the Hollywood blockbuster to the cash-strapped island, said state news agency Prensa Latina. The 1999 Star Wars film will be shown across the island, where Cuba's cinema-loving nation have traditionally enjoyed more Latin American, East European and old American movies, than recent Hollywood productions.

 Alec Baldwin has been talking about the flying lessons he has had to take for his role in the forthcoming second world war drama, Pearl Harbor. "The good news is, I did well with the bombing," he said. "The bad news is, I crashed the helicopter five times in a row in the landing. So I flew well, bombed well, and then I crashed." A trailer for the much-hyped film, which also stars Ben Affleck, is currently available at the Rotten Tomatoeswebsite.

 Welsh actor Ioan Gruffudd is being lined up to star as Benjamin Disraeli in a film dramatising the life of the British prime minister. It is understood that Ruffudd would play the 28-year-old Disraeli in the film (provisionally titled Dizzy), which revolves around his affair with an older married woman. Gruffudd, who is probably best known for his part as Horatio Hornblower in ITV's recent adaptation, has been gradually building up his film credits with parts in 1997's Wilde and James Cameron's Titanic. He is to feature shortly in the forthcoming 102 Dalmatians with Glenn Close and alongside Jonathan Pryce in the comedy Very Annie Mary.

 Director Betty Thomas, whose latest film, 28 Days, is currently in cinemas, is in final talks to shoot a comedy, Surviving Christmas. It is the story of a lonely man who rents himself a family for the holidays, and Thomas is believed to be producing the project with partner Jenno Topping.

 Courtney Solomon , director of the long awaited Dungeons and Dragons film, has already named his next project. He is to produce a film version of the cult American comic book, GEN 13, and it will be released by Disney.

fields.headline: George Clooney storms US box-office
fields.trailText: George Clooney's maritime disaster picture The Perfect Storm has gone straight to number one at the US box-office, taking $41.7m over the three-day holiday weekend and becoming the third highest July 4 holiday opener ever
fields.body:
George Clooney's maritime disaster picture The Perfect Storm has gone straight to number one at the US box-office, taking $41.7m over the three-day holiday weekend and becoming the third highest July 4 holiday opener ever (after Men in Black and Independence Day).

It is also the best opener in Warner Bros history (beating Lethal Weapon 4) and the second largest three-day opener this year (after Mission: Impossible 2).

Opening to mixed reviews from the critics, The Perfect Storm, based on Sebastian Junger's best-selling book, tells the tale of an ill-fated fishing boat caught up in a freak storm pattern off the coast of Massachusetts in 1991. Playing the ship's skipper, former ER heartthrob Clooney proved to be a major draw for female moviegoers, who accounted for 53% of the audience. The film's popularity was also boosted by its special effects, which attracted a younger audience. With many businesses shut today, ahead of the Independence Day holiday on Tuesday, it is estimated the film will end the long holiday weekend with $64m in the till.

Mel Gibson's controversial US revolutionary saga The Patriot came in second, grossing $31m since it opened last Wednesday.

webTitle: Drumcree marchers banned from nationalist area

fields.headline: Drumcree marchers banned from nationalist area
fields.standfirst:
Parades Commission
Graphic: route of the march
fields.trailText: Drumcree Orangemen have been barred from marching down  the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road next Sunday, the  Parades Commission has announced.
fields.body:
Drumcree Orangemen have been barred from marching down the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road next Sunday, the Parades Commission has announced.

But commission chairman Tony Holland said a parade could take place in the next three to eight months if Orangemen complied with their decision, stopped Drumcree-related protests and engaged with residents in Garvaghy Road Portadown, County Armagh.

Announcing the commission's decision in Belfast to again ban Orangemen from the nationalist area, Mr Holland said: "In such circumstances the Parades Commission would look to nationalist residents of the Garvaghy Road - that they were genuine in seeking a long-term resolution of the inter-communal tensions in Portadown, by taking steps to facilitate the proposed parades.

"The Parades Commission cannot envisage circumstances in which any subsequent Orange Order parade could take place along the Garvaghy Road except on the basis of a local agreement."

Meanwhile. seven police officers are recovering after being slightly injured in rioting at Drumcree.

Trouble flared for several hours on Sunday night when several hundred loyalists at the church outside Portadown threw bottles, stones and other missiles at security forces. Loyalists also set fire to an armoured vehicle and fired ball bearings from a catapult at Drumcree Hill on Sunday night.

Police arrested a youth in Portadown, who is being questioned about a crate of petrol bombs found in Meadow Lane.

There were also minor scuffles in Belfast. In the north of the city, two men were injured when fights broke out among around 100 people in rival gangs at Westland Road.

In east Belfast, police came under attack as they tried to dismantle barricades on Templemore Avenue and one officer needed stitches above his eye when he was hit by a bottle.

The Orange Order has appealed for no violence but the head of the Portadown Lodge, Harold Gracey, has called for thousands of people around the Province to protest against the Parades Commission.

Tension is likely to build, particularly in Portadown, with continued loyalist demonstrations planned for the rest of the week.

Craigavon deputy mayor, Mark Neale, put forward proposals to try to break the deadlock which include Orangemen being allowed to march down Garvaghy Road on July 9 and a civic forum being set up to help regenerate all sides in Portadown on the following day.

fields.headline: Follett no food for thought
fields.standfirst: Ken Follett's critique lacked insight and originality, so why, asks David McKie, does the media pay attention?
fields.trailText: Ken Follett's critique lacked insight and originality, so why, asks David McKie, does the media pay attention?
fields.body:
The furore over Ken Follett's assault on Tony Blair reflects the way that the nation has become besotted with celebrities.

Mr Follett is a best-selling author whose wife is a backbench Labour MP. Both were close to the former party leader Neil Kinnock, and together they helped raise large sums of money for Labour. Mr Blair, however, treated him with increasing wariness and soon he found himself sidelined. Though the BBC described him all day yesterday as "a senior Labour supporter" he is hardly a figure the Labour party would rally to or revere. The case he makes against Tony Blair for presiding over a government lacking rooted conviction where spin doctors rule and colleagues are crudely disparaged has been made before by people of far greater political consequence: the former Labour deputy leader Roy Hattersley, for example, in the Guardian.

What he says about whispering campaigns against Mo Mowlam has been said by Mo Mowlam herself, not least in her recent interview with Saga magazine, though she made it clear she believed that the agents of denigration were not Blair and Alastair Campbell so much as young jumped up whippersnappers in their entourage.

In his piece for the Observer Follett confessed that the only thing he knew about King Alfred was that he burned some cakes. His grasp on the history of government feuding is equally shaky. He appears to think it started with Margaret Thatcher and her press secretary Bernard Ingham. In fact unattributable slagging off of one's political nearest and dearest is as old as politics. It was practised in the greatest of all Labour governments, that of 1945, with a venom which makes today's participants look almost saintly. Several senior ministers plotted to get rid of Attlee. Herbert Morrison and Ernest Bevin, on the right of the party, advertised to all who would listen their loathing of the charismatic leftwinger Nye Bevan. And in those days they had no platoons of ambitious young thrusters to do their dirty work for them.

What has happened now is that this kind of activity has become big business. The media has vastly expanded since Attlee's day, which preceded the rise of TV and which published newspapers restricted by newsprint rationing to six or eight pages. There is also, it has to be said, a greater readiness in much of the media to pump up the poison talk in a much less critical way. The demand for careful policy analysis has fallen away; the demand for stories about who is up and who's down, and who is slagging off whom, seems insatiable.

The world has not been changed by what Ken Follett has said. We knew all about the fighting and feuding. We knew that it taints our politics. All that has happened is that the case has been made by a best-selling author whose name reverberates outside politics. Perhaps it is some commentary on present day politics that home truths strike that much harder when celebrities rather than politicians air them.

fields.headline: Obiturary: Walter Matthau
fields.standfirst: Wry, ironic, crumpled, curmudgeonly - and a star
fields.trailText: Wry, ironic, crumpled, curmudgeonly - and a star
fields.body:
A fan once stopped Walter Matthau on Coney Island and said to him: "Handsome? I've seen better. But you're something, I don't know what". She was absolutely right. Matthau, who has died aged 79, was quite something. But never your conventional Hollywood star.

There is hardly a director in the world who would not have welcomed him into his cast - Danny Boyle wanted him to play God in A Life Less Ordinary, but he could just as well have played the Devil. He was almost everybody's favourite character actor who, if he couldn't quite hold a film on his own, formed some notable partnerships on the screen. He rose to the challenge of a good script and another first-class actor with unbeatable panache. He was mostly closely identified with Jack Lemmon in The Fortune Cookie (1966), The Odd Couple (1968), The Front Page (1975) and Buddy Buddy (1981). And as a seamed veteran - was he ever really young? - he matched with him again in Grumpy Old Men (1993).

By then both he and Jack had become unwitting caricatures of themselves. But no matter what Hollywood did to him, Matthau managed slyly to momentarily transcend the part. He had plenty of practice. For some years he was cast either as a smirky villain or as the American version of a jolly decent chap. His first film, The Kentuckian (1955), in which he was an evil saloon keeper, was followed by A Face In The Crowd (1957), Charade (1963), Fail Safe (1964) and Goodbye Charlie (1964). But Matthau was still largely unfulfilled, and knew it.

It was Gene Saks's The Odd Couple, which he had played with great success on Broadway, that really made him. After that, Hollywood and particularly the shrewd Billy Wilder, knew what to do with him. Wilder always used to think of Matthau as the quintessential conman - "Watch out," he once commented, "this guy could sell you Brooklyn Bridge."

Saks's film of The Odd Couple, taken from the Neil Simon original, wasn't all that great. But nobody could have played it better than Matthau and Lemmon, the one nervy and panic-stricken, the other totally unable to comprehend the reason why.

Other film-makers followed. Matthau was wonderfully curmudgeonly, coupled with Anne Archer, in George Axelrod's The Secret Life Of An American Wife (1968); hilarious opposite Elaine May in her underrated A New Leaf (1971) and, playing with the great George Burns,who also could time a line to perfection, made Herbert Ross's The Sunshine Boys (1975) into something special.

There were some comparatively straight parts in films like Don Siegel's clever Charley Varrick (1973), where Matthau played a bank robber hounded by the Mafia, and as Senator Russell Long in Oliver Stone's JFK (1991). But by then he was best-known for just being Matthau - wry and ironic, slightly crumpled, derisive of himself and the world at large and a dab hand at timing a line for the maximum effect.

All this hid a more complex personality not unfamiliar with depression, probably the result of his awful childhood, who would tell funny anecdotes on TV talk shows to prevent anyone enquiring too closely about his private life. He was a star who seemed to be giving confidences away by the bucketload but actually told you absolutely nothing personal. The less you say about yourself, he was quoted as saying, the better off you are.

Born in New York, Matthau was always said to be the son of a Russian Orthodox priest who had emigrated to America and eventually migrated from his family. But it seems father was an electrician, carpenter and photographer in whose life prayer did not play a prime part. Nor did his son, so Walter was brought up in the Daughters of Israel Day Nursery while his mother worked as a seamstress for upwards of 12 hours a day to keep everything together.

All this had its effect on him, as did his mother who used, because of her extreme poverty, to collect toilet paper from diners where she had a cup of coffee. Even when Matthau was one of the highest paid Hollywood actors, she did so, despite his protests. At one time she had 15 large paper bags full and a furious Matthau, trying to break her of the habit, put them in the bath and turned the tap on. When he came back to the new apartment he had bought for her in Florida, he found the paper spread all over the terrace floor to dry.

He had started life very much as a poor Jewish boy from the Lower East side whose real name was Matuschanskayasky. Just for fun, he called himself that as the drunk in Mark Robson's Earthquake (1974), where I met him on the set. "This," he said, "is a film which gives me the shakes in more ways than one. I do not wish to comment further until I hear what Charlton Heston has to say to you. He's a serious fellow, and we might not quite match up, you know." I got the impression, since he was playing an alcoholic, that I was talking to a reincarnation of W C Fields. It's a great pity he never played Fields on the screen.

He changed his name soon after appearing as a child actor in New York's Yiddish Theatre, realising that you couldn't get very far with it in show business. During the second world war he served in the USAF as a radioman and gunner, finally making his proper acting debut first in summer stock and then on Broadway in 1946. The part of Oscar in the stage version of The Odd Couple was written for him.

But to him it seemed a long time before he was appreciated as a comic talent. He used to say that he learned most about his craft (which he took so seriously it seemed as if he was not really trying at all) from his days in live television when accidents regularly happened, like the phone ringing when it wasn't supposed to. At that point smarties like him would lift the receiver and put the other actor on the spot by saying: "It's for you".

Matthau was latterly dogged by ill-health - heart disease, facial cancer and ulcers. He would say, contemplating all this and the resulting doctors' bills, that a philosophy for life was probably a necessity but that he could never fasten his mind on one in particular. When asked, he would say that "life was like a cup of tea", prompting the question "why?" - to which his reply was "why not?". Since by then he looked passably old and wise, there would be no real argument.

As for advice about acting, Matthau would quote his mother: "You know," she would say, "'If you'd had a decent father, you could have been a lawyer." Then he would add: "An actor is one who sings and dances on the street and passes the hat to get pennies. It's shameful. But you've got to live, so you make a fool of yourself, which is essentially what I do." What he didn't say was that not many exemplified his craft better and that he gave enormous pleasure to millions. Which is not a shameful thing at all.

Matthau had two children from his first marriage, and a son, Charles, who became a film-maker, from his second marriage, to Carol Marcus.

 Walter Matthau, actor, born October 1 1920; died July 1 2000

fields.headline: Gwyneth Paltrow gets ugly
fields.trailText: Gwyneth Paltrow has signed up to appear in the Farrelly Brothers new feature, Shallow Hal, and, for once, she is not going to play a graceful swan-like beauty
fields.body:
Gwyneth Paltrow is apparently going to 'get ugly' for her next role. She has signed up to appear in the Farrelly Brothers new feature, Shallow Hal, and, for once, she is not going to play a graceful swan-like beauty.

Shallow Hal tells the story of a man (Jack Black, to be seen playing opposite John Cusack in the forthcoming High Fidelity) who is advised by his father when he is 12 years old only to date beautiful women. He follows this advice until he reaches middle age when he falls in love with a very plain woman, played, naturally, by Paltrow.

It is rumoured that Paltrow has accepted this part so she can ditch her 'goody goody' image and poke some fun at herself. She seems to be following the career path of Cameron Diaz, who worked with the Farrelly's on There's Something About Mary, and received critical acclaim when she 'uglied up' for her role as the plain pet shop attendant in Being John Malkovich.

 Shallow Hal is due for a US release in the summer of 2002

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the transfer talk tipped down a hole, covered in earth and remembered at a wake.
fields.trailText: Arsenal are rumoured to have signed Robert Pires on a four-year contract, despite the French winger stating last night that "Madrid is the best club for me". Marc Overmars is now likely to move to either Barcelona, Roma or Lazio.
fields.body:
Arsenal are rumoured to have signed Robert Pires on a four-year contract, despite the French winger stating last night that "Madrid is the best club for me". Marc Overmars is now likely to move to either Barcelona, Roma or Lazio.

According to reports from Germany, former Manchester City striker Uwe Rösler has signed for Southampton from Tennis Borussia Berlin on a two-year contract.

Everton hope to complete the £2.5m transfer of Aston Villa's Steve Watson today.

Chelsea are preparing a £6m for Roma striker Marco Delvecchio.

Turkish international keeper Recber Rustu has expressed a desire to play in the Premiership. The Fenerbahce player is available for £5m - Ipswich, who are resigned to losing Richard Wright, may make a move.

But Wright is unlikely to be moving to Chelsea - former Italian under-21 keeper Carlo Cudicini has signed a permanent contract at Stamford Bridge after a year-long loan period. "Carlo is a very capable keeper and is adequate cover for Ed de Goey. We are no longer interested in Richard Wright and will not be contacting Ipswich," managing director Colin Hutchinson said today.

Everton, Bradford and Manchester City are all interested in £2m Leeds midfielder David Hopkin.

Leicester's Neil Lennon wants to join his former manager Martin O'Neill at Celtic. The 29-year-old is expected to ask Peter Taylor for a transfer this week.

Sheffield Wednesday's Ian Nolan will move to Bradford on a free transfer today.

Didier Deschamps may return to France in the summer. Monaco are poised with a £2.5m offer for the 31-year-old Chelsea midfielder.

Chelsea have offered Aston Villa striker Tore Andre Flo in exchange for Gareth Southgate.

webTitle: Jig, rejig and finally revert to the original

fields.headline: Jig, rejig and finally revert to the original
fields.trailText: Between the time our new director of marketing accepted the job and when she actually arrived at Rools, we had spent hours agonising over a strong visual identity for the business.
fields.body:
Between the time our new director of marketing accepted the job and when she actually arrived at Rools, we had spent hours agonising over a strong visual identity for the business.

"I like it - but it does look a bit atomic," was her reaction when she first saw the new logo.

Although we know that the logo is only a part of what makes up a brand, it is an important tool in the dot.com world where relationships with customers are virtual. Get it right - a Nike swoosh, a dog by the gramophone - and you've got a chance to make an impact. Get it wrong - making it too childish, for example - and you turn them off before you've even started.

We were keen for our identity to be consistent with the values of the business and with what we were trying to achieve. But what were those values? Answering this took time.

The whole team met up with our creative branding agency for a little soul searching. At times it felt a little bit like being on a psychiatrist's couch. Words such as "empowering", "responsible" and "secure" surfaced pretty quickly, and we spent a good hour examining what we actually meant by this.

As Rools is a new brand, we wanted an identity first and foremost around which we could build trust with young people and their parents. This meant that wacky, lurid colours were unlikely to feature but it did not necessarily follow that the logo had to be boring with safe, autumnal hues. Indeed we were extremely keen to make it a little bit different and to positively stand out from the crowd.

There were also practical considerations. The logo needed to work equally well when viewed online, in print, when faxed and in both marketing and advertising material.

But our creative agency wanted more. They wanted to understand more about us and what other brands were successful in this area. "Gap meets Sony PlayStation" seemed to sum it up best.

The agency examined every aspect of the business, from where we expected Rools to be in five years' time down to the technical details of how we are processing online purchases.

A selection of five initial concepts was presented within 10 days. Most seemed to meet the criteria that we had set and reflected our vision for the identity - the agency seemed to have listened and taken onboard what we said about Rools. We thought one of the ideas was particularly strong and focused development on that - incorporating the best elements of some of the other designs.

Getting to a final design was a very iterative process. Internally the logo designs elicited strong reactions from even the most reticent members of the team. Opinions were expressed about nearly every element.

The debates that we had over the shape (square or oval?) and the colours (red and blue, or blue and red?) were among the most hotly contested since we started the business.

It seemed that the logo, as the visual representation of Rools and something that we would all have to live with, got right to the heart of everyone's thinking about our service.

The agency had to deal with the fallout. We don't like to think that that we are an awkward client, but we are grateful to our creative partners for the patience they showed as we first jigged, then rejigged a number of times - before returning to the original design.

 Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a service that lets teenagers buy securely online without a credit card

fields.headline: Straight-to-cable shock for Cameron Diaz
fields.trailText: Cameron Diaz's latest film, Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her, due for a US cinema release next month, will now debut on the US cable channel Showtime in early 2001
fields.body:
Cameron Diaz's latest film is so bad that it's going straight to a cable TV release, according to the Sun newspaper. Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her was due for a US cinema release next month but it will now debut on the US cable channel Showtime in early 2001.

The film is a collection of five vignettes with overlapping characters and features an ensemble cast which includes Glenn Close, Holly Hunter, and Calista Flockhart. It premiered at last year's Sundance Film Festival to a good reception from most critics.

The director of photography, Emmanuel Lubezki expressed her shock at the decision: "It sends a very strange, bad message about the movie. I think this is a great picture. We were passionate about the script and it turned out to be better than we expected. I can't understand it."

Variety has given a less sensational version of events, claiming that MGM most likely made the decision not to release the film on the big screen because they feared this intimate, character-driven piece, written and directed by former cinematographer Rodrigo Garcia (son of Pulitzer prize-winning novelist Gabriel Garcia Marquez) would have been overlooked amid the summers big-budget blockbusters.

"It could have gotten lost in the summer movie shuffle and ended up costing MGM a lot more money than it was worth," said Paul Dergarabedian, president of box office tracking firm Exhibitor Relations. "By going straight to Showtime, they figure they can recoup their investment and possibly get the film seen by a lot more people."

Whatever the reason, Showtime are delighted with the decision. Matthew Duda, executive Vice President of Showtime Networks commented "We are thrilled to have such a remarkable film and are determined to make it an event on the channel."

 Things You Can Tell Just by Looking at Her official site

webTitle: Parents urge missing prodigy to contact them

fields.headline: Parents urge missing prodigy to contact them
fields.trailText: The parents of a child prodigy missing from her student accommodation since completing her final exam of the year at Oxford University are appealing for her safe return.
fields.body:
The parents of a child prodigy missing from her student accommodation since completing her final exam of the year at Oxford University are appealing for her safe return.

Sufiah Yosof, 15, who is reading maths at the all-women's college St Hilda's, has not been seen since June 21 when her father helped her clear out her rented room in the city.

On the day of her disappearance a girl claiming to be Sufiah telephoned university authorities to say she was staying with friends.

Thames Valley Police have appealed for her safe return and for anyone who knows of her whereabouts to contact them.

Police have checked more that 400 e-mail messages which she had deleted from her computer, but which were retrieved by the university's back-up tapes, to help shed some light on her disappearance.

Fears are growing that she may have disappeared with someone she met while on the internet.

Sufiah, in her third year of a masters course, failed to meet colleagues and tutors for lunch following her exams.

Her father Farooq, 43, said: "Everyone is simply shattered. Our lives have been turned upside down. We can't sleep. Sufiah fills our every waking moment. We have been going over and over everything in our minds.

"We just can't understand why she has vanished. No one can. We have spoken to her friends at college, her lecturers, her brothers and sisters - nobody has any inkling anything was wrong. We have explored every angle."

He and his wife Halimahton, 44, who live in Northampton but take turns to stay with their daughter during term time in Oxford, are appealing for her to get in touch and described her as "naive and innocent".

fields.headline: The battle of the bookshops
fields.standfirst: Lawsuits and guerrilla action help independents fight US chains
fields.trailText: The ghost of Jack Kerouac, the Bare-Breasted Ladies, and some of America's top lawyers are all part of a fight to save the independent bookshops of the United States: a battle which has international implications for the small independent retailers who are being forced out of business by multinational chains.
fields.body:
The ghost of Jack Kerouac, the Bare-Breasted Ladies, and some of America's top lawyers are all part of a fight to save the independent bookshops of the United States: a battle which has international implications for the small independent retailers who are being forced out of business by multinational chains.

This week it was confirmed that one of America's best-known bookshops, City Lights of San Francisco, is to become a city "landmark", giving it the protection from developers in enjoyed by listed buildings in Britain. This may give the shop - co-founded by the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti in 1953 - a status that could help it survive the current crisis.

Last week the new Borders store in Santa Cruz was invaded by protesters throwing stinkbombs and a group of masked topless women called the Bare-Breasted Ladies. The Bare-Breasted Ladies have also staged actions against Gap and Starbucks.

Their sentiments, if not their action, received the backing of the local mayor, Keith Sugar, who said: "Borders is not welcome here and they know that. These kinds of predatory businesses pose a threat to our town and to local businesses."

Meanwhile, an anti-trust suit is being brought against the Borders and another book chain, Barnes & Noble, by the American Booksellers Association, which represents 3,100 independent book shops and 26 bookstores throughout the US.

It alleges that the chains have unfairly used their clout to coerce publishers into offering special deals and promotions which have not been offered to the smaller bookshops. It will go to trial next year in the San Francisco district court.

Borders and Barnes & Noble deny that they are "engaged in a pattern of soliciting, inducing and receiving secret discriminatory and illegal terms from publishers".

But many bookshop owners believe the future of the small bookshop may depend on the outcome of the case. The decision is likely to have ramifications in the chains v independents war that stretch beyond the world of bookselling.

Jack Kerouac - who has a nearby street called after him - Allen Ginsberg and the beat poets all used City Lights as a gathering place, and it was the first bookshop in the US to sell only paperbacks.

"We have a very, very loyal base of customers but the future is never assured," said Paul Jamazaki, who is a buyer for the shop.

An encouraging number of new young customers and a "brilliant" young staff kept the shop in business, he said, but since the chains arrived its customers had been buying fewer books.

San Francisco still has about 50 small bookshops, many of them specialist ones.

Margie Ghiz, owner of the Midnight Special bookstore in Santa Monica, renowned throughout Los Angeles as the place for liberal leftwingers to buy books, believes that her shop has survived because of loyal customers, staff who know and care about books, and a generous landlord.

"When Borders opened down the street from us in 1995 our sales fell by between 35 and 40% in the first year," she said. "I don't know how long we're going to be able to last."

Ms Ghiz said that the arrival of Amazon.com and the electronic book were another difficulty facing small bookshops. The fact that the electronic book trade was having its first convention in New York this autumn was a sign of its growing power. "When they're big enough to have their own convention, you know they're big," she said.

Orin Teicher, the chief operating officer of the ABA, said of the civil action yesterday: "We're confident the things we've alleged will be proven true and we will prevail."

He said that the number of independent bookshops had declined significantly over the years but every poll of book-buyers indicated that there was support for the smaller bookshops. The point of the action, he added, was to end the "uneven playing field" on which they were competing against the big chains. "We think there is a future [for the independent bookshop] if we can win our action."

Borders and Barnes & Noble will not comment on the lawsuit, except to say that they follow "accepted industry practices in all business dealings". Borders in Santa Cruz said that despite the protests there had been much local support for their arrival.

webTitle: A medallion on a shiny stick

fields.headline: A medallion on a shiny stick
fields.trailText: We award the great and the good with our specially-commissioned Euro 2000 awards.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM OUR SPONSOR

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"How do you expect me to feel?" - Italy's coach Dino Zoff. And you thought you'd never feel sorry for Italy.

THE EURO-TORIAL AWARDS

Well, that's it. We've laughed, we've cried. We've been through the good times and the England matches. And we didn't watch a big game on ITV if there was any alternative. But all good things must pass, and Euro 2000 bowed out last night in a manner befitting a tournament which delivered.

Looking back, we knew it would be good from the minute Belgium and Sweden went at it hammer and tongs in the opening game. Apart from a doltish few, and we can't be bothered to talk about them, everybody went to the party with the intention of having a good time. Even the players.

So, to thank everyone concerned for filling our meaningless lives with a little joy, the Euro has decided to award some, er, awards. They're virtual awards, of course, so we're not sure what they look like. They're probably a bit like a medallion on a shiny stick which you can wear or put on a mantelpiece. Or a sideboard.

Best moment of skill
Christophe Dugarry's flick-up and back-heel against Spain, which was principally outrageous because it managed to trump anything Zinedine Zidane did, and he was trying it on with the saucy moves all month.

Most hopeless act of buffoonery
We don't mean to be too parochial about this, but it's got to be Phil Neville's comedy cameo against Romania. Moving with slightly less agility than the giant man in the opening ceremony, Neville went hackabout and ruined England's chances of being totally humiliated by Italy in the quarter-finals. Actually, thanks Phil.

Best commentary
"It's in! It's Alfonsoooooooooooaaaaaaaaarrrrrggggggghhhhhhhh! It... it's unbelievable!" - John Motson turning into an excited little child when a certain Spanish player scored the winner against Yugoslavia. He's still the best.

Worst commentary
Anything by Peter Drury. We're not even mentioning filthy-tasting cakes.

Most pointless pundit
Want someone to talk up Phil Neville's left foot, or explain why Alan Shearer won't let you down when push comes to shove? Then Dion Dublin's your man. Six-time champion Trevor Brooking didn't even come close.

Most confused old man
Barry Davies. Totti is not Toldo, pal, and not correcting yourself until the semi-finals hasn't won you any friends round here.

Most surreal late-night moment which had nothing to do with Eurosport's Euro 2000 Nightclub
Sideshow Bob Wilson telling a bemused ITV panel that Maldini was "very attractive".

Most tactically inept manager
Oh come on.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country....go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EURONEWS

Bayer Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum is the new coach of Germany, but will not take up his post until next June. Rudi Voller will cop a load of unwarranted abuse from Lothar Matthaus in the meantime.

Let's face it, Robert Pires is signing for Real Madrid and not Arsenal. Speaking minutes after setting up David Trezeguet's golden goal, Pires said: "Madrid is the best club for me. We will see what the people at Madrid want. Money is not the most important thing but how the game is played." How much more blatant a hint does everyone need?

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hmph. It's Karel here, and I'm far from happy. Four weeks I've been turning up early in the morning with the latest Eurorumours. And what thanks do I get?

Now, let me see. I've been manhandled onto a plane, thrown over a mountain, thrown out of a high window, tied up in a basement, put in a cage, been electrocuted and been forced to go into hiding because an irritating faux-cockney idiot was coming round to make a mess in my kitchen. Not to mention the week-long bender I was forced to go on which led to my spiritual enlightenment - and that was something I could have done without, mate.

Well, I've had enough. I'm not going to bother telling you about Turkey's keeper, Recber Rustu, who wants to play in the Premiership. The Fenerbahce player is available for £5m - Ipswich, who are resigned to losing Richard Wright, may make a move.

You won't hear the news that Didier Deschamps may return to France in the summer from muggins, either. Monaco are poised with a £2.5m offer for the 31-year-old Chelsea midfielder.

And don't come running to me if you want to know anything about the £6m bid Chelsea are preparing for Roma striker Marco Delvecchio.

I even missed a date with Britney Spears thanks to you lot. Gah! Well, I'm off, and you won't be seeing me again.

I mean it, now.

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football (9am)
Accept it. It's over. Move on.

fields.headline: Losing currency
fields.standfirst: National symbols like currencies may be increasingly irrelevant in a joint European future, writes economics reporter Charlotte Denny.
fields.trailText: Monday, 1pm: National symbols like currencies may be increasingly irrelevant in a joint European future, writes economics reporter Charlotte Denny.
fields.body:
When countries won their independence, it used to be that one of the symbolic first acts of their new status was throwing out the oppressor's currency and printing their own. The earliest predecessors of the mighty dollar funded America's war against Britain, while the anti-colonial struggles of the 50s and 60s resulted in the birth of a host of currencies.

These days it seems, many countries are desperate to abandon their own currencies in favour of joining a bigger monetary block. When East Timor won its independence from Indonesia last May, it dumped the rupiah, but instead of inventing its own currency, it debated whether to adopt the euro or the dollar, finally deciding this January to use the greenback.

Can countries afford the luxury of their own currencies in an increasingly integrated global economy? The foreign investors who accused the government of "betraying" them by not taking Britain into the eurozone, according to this morning's press reports, clearly think national currencies have had their day. They would rather have the certainty of knowing that the goods they export to Europe won't be priced out of foreign markets by a plummeting foreign exchange rate.

But while business likes certainty, economists agree that the case for abandoning control over monetary policy, which is the price of entering a single currency, is not clear-cut. The advantages of a fixed exchange rate against trading partners have to be weighed against the cost of losing the flexibility of being able to set interest rates to suit local conditions. So for example, when Britain last flirted with fixing its exchange rate against its continental partners, British industry was crushed by the high-level interest rates which the Bundesbank demanded as a price for the reunification of Germany.

Economists who have not been recruited to one or the other side of Britain's increasingly acrimonious debate on the euro agree the case is finely balanced - the margin of error involved in such calculations is greater than any estimation of the size of trade-off between losing independence and gaining stability. Most also agree that the most important benefit Britain gains from being part of the European Union is the single market - the rules which prevent EU countries from imposing tariffs on each others' goods.

In the end, it comes down to politics and a judgement about whether Britain can fully participate in Europe if it becomes the last country to join the single currency.
