fields.headline: Industry 'facing euro meltdown'
fields.standfirst:
Decide now or lose heartland jobs, Whitehall leak warns
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: A memo leaked to the Guardian from the heart of government warns that Britain's manufacturing heartlands face "meltdown" unless the cabinet declares that membership of the single european currency is inevitable.
fields.body:
A memo leaked to the Guardian from the heart of government warns that Britain's manufacturing heartlands face "meltdown" unless the cabinet declares that membership of the single european currency is inevitable.

The stark memo, marked "restricted policy", has been sent to Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, by one of the most senior civil servants in his department.

It also warns that the relative strength of sterling means the government's policy of gradual convergence with the economies already using the euro is "no longer working".

The memo predicts: "We must expect significant high-profile closures. The impact of this will be felt disproportionately in manufacturing heartland regions, exacerbating regional imbalances with all the attendant political problems that implies."

The memo comes from Andrew Fraser, chief executive for the past six years of the DTI Invest in Britain Bureau. He wants ministers, including the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to massage sterling's level down by saying its current level is dangerously unrealistic and that the euro is indispensable to the preservation of Britain's manufacturing base.

The memo's almost desperate tone suggests that inside Whitehall concern at the high pound, the receding political will to confront Eurosceptics and the consequent impact on jobs is far greater than ministers will publicly admit.

The memo states: "The government can no longer escape the essential choice: continue with perception growing that we are slipping back to 'wait and see' and not addressing a growing sense of crisis; or argue publicly for management towards greater convergence - including a more sensible exchange rate - along with firm commitment to euro entry once conditions are right".

The paper concedes: "Carrying public opinion is critical, but the alternative is to preside over meltdown of major manufacturing sectors, and loss of major inward investors."

Recent job losses at Ford and Rover represent, Mr Fraser says, "perhaps the first high profile closures of the major magnet investors". He forecasts that the rate of closures is likely to accelerate dramatically, especially in electronics, textiles, automotive and Japanese-owned factories. The crisis will extend to the City "if the perception grows that we are perhaps not on course for convergence and entry".

The memo comes before a DTI announcement this week that inward investment is at record levels, with 118,000 jobs created or safeguarded. But Mr Fraser clearly feels that British industry is on the edge of a precipice. If the government continues as now, "we face a growing perception of drift as manufacturers are in crisis and anti-euro lobbies build political momentum".

He claims many in business feel a sense of betrayal over the government's loss of nerve over the euro. "The alarming relative appreciation of sterling is leading investors to de mand a policy response. There is a growing sense that the government is backsliding on its commitment to convergence - and when the time is right for entry - and leaving the political argument to the anti-euro brigade."

Claiming that manufacturers are pleading with him to know how soon Britain will join the euro, Mr Fraser says he meets investors in Japan who say: "We put our commitment into the UK, you are our special and trusted partners in Europe. How could you stay out and let us down?"

He urges a courageous and clear response: "It must challenge the Eurosceptics head-on politically and it must express the view that entry into the euro is indispensable if we are to secure the future of Britain's manufacturing base.

Perversely, the weakness of manufacturing competitiveness as a direct result of the pound-euro uncertainties - may provide a window of opportunity politically to drive home the message."

Mr Fraser told Mr Byers: "At the current exchange rates, pound/euro, I suspect very few manufacturing investors are currently profitable. Their exposure is obvious: some 70% of UK production by inward investors is exported, primarily to the euro zone. The constant refrain I hear is that 'we have to have our cost bases denominated in the same currency as our principal revenues'. "

"By way of comparison, I understand that trade from the euro zone economies is 90% within the currency zone: similar figures apply in the US and Japan. This currency risk factor inevitably outweighs whatever other benefits the UK offers them."

He said investors and industrialists are horrified that sterling is above DM3 and "regarded DM3.20 as the upper limit of absurdity".

 Mr Byers yesterday denied political fixing was paramount in deciding whether Britain should join the euro and gave businesses a "guarantee" that the government was not going to "let the issue drift".

He told the BBC TV's On the Record that euro membership had clear benefits, including improvements in trade, and currency stability. He also conceded that within British manufacturing, some key sectors "face difficulty", particularly those exporting into the euro zone under the strong pound.

"As more than half of our exports go into that euro zone, clearly it has a direct impact."

fields.headline: Jobs meltdown fear over euro 'dithering'
fields.standfirst:
The factories Investors will walk away, warn managers and economists

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Two years ago the sleek, silver semi-conductor factory on the dooorstep of Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, stood as a symbol of Britain's new wave manufacturers.
fields.body:
Two years ago the sleek, silver semi-conductor factory on the dooorstep of Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, stood as a symbol of Britain's new wave manufacturers.

Opened just as New Labour came to power, Siemens's £1.2bn North Tyneside complex, with 1,000 skilled workers, came to represent all those Blairite virtues of a knowledge-driven economy.

When it closed suddenly, after 18 months, ministers did their best to blame the catastrophe on a world-wide glut in micro-chips rather than the high pound. But many believe the German electronics giant pulled the plug partly because of equivocation over entering the euro zone.

Suspicions were confirmed a few weeks later when Fujitsu announced the closure of its semi-conductor plant in Tony Blair's Sedgefield constituency, with the loss of 600 jobs - although another manufacturer has since moved in.

Today Mr Byers is well aware that overseas companies dependent on exporting in his north-east, and beyond, are on a knife's edge. Nissan, symbol of the region's industrial rebirth, is struggling to make a profit - and making a loss on every model it exports to Europe. Its warnings are getting louder by the day. Ten thousand jobs are directly in the balance. Economist Keith Burge, who runs a regional consultancy, said there was serious doubt surrounding the future of other overseas companies in the north-east.

Hugh Morgan-Williams, a member of the CBI's national council, runs an electronics plant in Tyne and Wear. He cannot contain his anxieties. "What is really going to drive this home to the government is a major inward investor pulling the plug in the next six months, sending shock waves around the country," he warned.

"Things are pretty grim. Nissan is losing money on every car its produces, and nearby Komatsu [which makes earth-moving equipment] is hardly making anything. Talk to the Invest in Britain Bureau and they will say the number of inquiries from Europe and the Far East has dropped to zero."

In short, the warning by Andrew Fraser, chief executive of the bureau, of a dramatic acceleration in the rate of closures, and the prospect of a "meltdown" in major manufacturing sectors, merely confirms the fears of many industrialists. Some warn that even financial services are feeling the pinch. At the last CBI council meeting, members reacted with horror when told some companies were abandoning Britain to get their insurance business from the euro zone because it was so much cheaper.

While ministers take comfort in an apparently booming economy, they know that the party's heartlands, particularly the north-east, are dangerously close to recession. In the most recent jobless figures, it was the only region to record an increase in unemployment - up 600 to 74,000 seasonally adjusted, or 6.7%. The south-east stood at 2%.

The message coming through to British manufacturers is that the prosperous regions of mainland Europe are a more favourable economic proposition to inward investors than Britain. "I heard recently from a trade delegation back from Japan that it was cheaper to invest in and around Cologne, I kid you not, than in the north-east," said one company chairman.

Wales and Scotland, home to many Japanese companies, are also vulnerable. An economic survey out this week in Scotland will point to a sluggish economy compared with the British average.

In Wales, Japanese and other inward investment helps an otherwise precarious economy that is still among the poorest in the UK. Much of the principality has been awarded "objective once" assistance by the European Union as one of its poorest regions.

Mr Fraser's warning of major cutbacks by Aiwa, the Japanese electronics giant, will set alarm bells ringing. The Wales first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, is sure to renew pressure on Mr Blair to give a timetable for joining the euro.

Neil Hood, a professor and a former head of the government agency, Locate in Scotland, which has attracted billions of pounds of investment, last night joined the chorus calling for the government to state its euro intentions.

He said companies had come to Britain because they had assumed it would play a full role in the EU inside the euro zone. Now many were clearly considering their long-term future in the UK.

"While I don't expect to see lots of them walking away completely, bits and pieces around the edges could go - and, more than likely, re-investment in existing plants will be affected."

Others, however, were holding their breath. For them, the prospect of another Siemens-style closure was just over the horizon.

webTitle: Dusty outpost of despair at the heart of Cyprus

fields.headline: Dusty outpost of despair at the heart of Cyprus
fields.standfirst: In 30 years there have been countless initiatives, but no reunion
fields.trailText: Closed borders, closed minds. Your heart used to sink as you neared Checkpoint Charlie. It sank again a few weeks ago at the post on the Lahore-Amritsar road: the two sides of a divided sub-continent stare at each other in curiosity and incomprehension. But surely this barren, dusty roadway outside the old Ledra Palace Hotel, symbol of Cyprus carved apart, is the most dismal spectacle of the lot.
fields.body:
Closed borders, closed minds. Your heart used to sink as you neared Checkpoint Charlie. It sank again a few weeks ago at the post on the Lahore-Amritsar road: the two sides of a divided sub-continent stare at each other in curiosity and incomprehension. But surely this barren, dusty roadway outside the old Ledra Palace Hotel, symbol of Cyprus carved apart, is the most dismal spectacle of the lot.

I was here half a lifetime ago when the UN peacemakers moved in. They are still here. And there is still no brokered peace. The Berlin wall has crumbled. The first weeping families from South Korea are hugging their long lost relatives in the north. Yet in today's Nicosia, affluent, smiling in the summer sun, an hour away from the crowded beaches of package tourists stripping off for Sky TV cameras, nothing moves and the lemons taste familiarly bitter.

Ethnic cleansing? Cyprus had it first before the phrase was glibly coined. Cyprus still has it. Ethical foreign policy? Cyprus never had that - from its blinkered British rulers, their American cold war cousins, from the fascist, manipulative Greece of the colonels, from the Turks 40 miles away across a deep blue sea. Cyprus is the sum of all blunders, living testimony of man's inhumanity to man and diplomacy's feeble resolution.

How many times since invasion of 1974 have they tried to sort it out? One battered negotiator counts 17 initiatives - and shrugs. So many years, so little to show. And what are we to expect this week as Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots return to Geneva for the third round of the so-called proximity talks, where Greeks and Turks polish their nails in separate rooms while UN chaps hover alongside US and FO goodwill envoys? Waste of time, he says: and, damnably enough, none of the participants disagrees. Another slow boat to no-where around Lac Leman.

Yet, whether those involved quite realise it or not, there is beginning to be a difference. The faces at their separate tables may be the same. Glafcos Clerides and Rauf Denktash, rival community champions, have been together now for 40 years (maybe a day too much). But the context in which they meet and fail to agree is changing hugely. This is an EU problem now. Join Europe - old, sweet song - to keep the peace. Join Europe for prosperity, a single market, single currency - and, in time, for a common defence and foreign policy. OK: I've heard Mr Blair and Mr Chirac. I've read the menu. But this dusty stretch of desolation outside the Ledra Palace is Europe. Greece itself is a euro-hugging member in good standing.

Mr Clerides waits top of the pending queue. Turkey, with due panoply, was solemnly accepted as a candidate member in Helsinki last winter and signs the necessary protocols this autumn. Is this Europe, our Europe of florid aspiration and misty rhetoric, going to pretend that the walls, wire fences and checkpoints across the width of Cyprus don't exist? What, 26 years after the Turkish army hit the beaches, is so frowningly intractable here. Would President Chirac like to clear his throat?

The components of continuing crisis can be amplified interminably over the wasted years or contracted in contentious simplicity. History first - and always. Did ethnic cleansing begin in 1964 when Greek Cypriot gangs, often wearing police uniforms, ran amok and shot or terrified into flight too many Turkish Cypriots? Or did it only begin in 1974 with the invasion? If '64 was the start of chaos (fomented from Athens) then it was the Greek Cypriot side which broke the treaty of guarantee that gave Cyprus its independence and the legitimacy of the government of Cyprus (all Greeks, no Turks) is flawed (whatever the UN or the international courts say). But if history begins in '74, then the Greek Cypriots are the ethnically cleansed victims and Mr Denktash runs a doomed little charade of an unrecognised and unrecognisable state.

I was here (for the Guardian) in 1964. I have to say that I saw too many dead or dispossessed Turkish Cypriots to wipe that slate of history squeaky clean. I can understand the north's muck sweat over security - just as I can understand the profound injustice that Greek Cypriots feel about seeing their homes, lands and livelihoods taken away one night at the point of a Turkish bayonet. With 35,000 Turkish mainland troops still on site, security sweat runs two ways.

But when fear turns into bleak constitutionality on lawyers' lips, hell freezes over. The one thing Greek Cypriots won't negotiate is their international legitimacy as the government of the island - right down to anything as humble as cutting Turkish Cyprus out of a kids' football tournament. The one thing that Mr Denktash won't countenance is any implied slight to his self-proclaimed status - right down to making the UN troops on the ground use a single checkpoint on the long green line. Goalposts move, but goals, including partition - don't.

Thus principle comes to seem pettily vindictive. Thus cross-border contacts wither as Mr Denktash shuts his saddened citizens away and the people of one small island grow so far apart that they might as well inhabit different planets. Thus Greek Cypriots, in the ignorance of isolation, think the north is a flyblown basket case (which it isn't) - and, while everybody says they want a settlement, the inertia of a realpolitik status quo descends - even on Greeks still striving manfully. Thus the EU representative here is persona non grata in Turkish Nicosia, because the union accepted the (Greek) government's application.

Confused? Of course. Anyone would be. But the sheer pettifoggery of the dispute sends its own insular message. How does it sit with Greece's buoyant euro economy and move into the European mainstream? How does it suit a Turkey which argued passionately for the right to be an EU candidate - and prevailed? Where does the crucial rapprochement between Athens and Ankara go from here? Down the drain in October, when Nicosia may call on the Greeks to veto Turkey's candidature unless a palatable solution appears on a negotiating timetable? If Brussels reneges (as it may) on Greek Cypriot admission, will Athens then heed the cry to veto all enlargement - from Poland to Hungary - as a wrecking act of brotherly solidarity?

There isn't slow boat to nowhere any longer; only a speedboat heading for the rocks on a coast near us. Cyprus hasn't been settled these past 30 years because there's been no overwhelming imperative to shift. Dust alley by the Ledra Palace is a monument to decisions evaded and half truths limply embraced. But no. No more. The stakes are rising. This - in its bounty, beauty and necessity for reconciliation - is our fine mess now. Summon the blood, for we shall have to sort it out.

Is this Europe, our Europe of florid aspiration and misty rhetoric, going to pretend that the walls, wire fences and checkpoints across the width of Cyprus don't exist? What, 26 years after the Turkish army hit the beaches, is so frowningly intractable here. Would President Chirac like to clear his throat? The components of continuing crisis can be amplified interminably over the wasted years or contracted in contentious simplicity. History first - and always. Did ethnic cleansing begin in 1964 when Greek Cypriot gangs, often wearing police uniforms, ran amok and shot or terrified into flight too many Turkish Cypriots? Or did it only begin in 1974 with the invasion? If '64 was the start of chaos (fomented from Athens) then it was the Greek Cypriot side which broke the treaty of guarantee that gave Cyprus its independence and the legitimacy of the government of Cyprus (all Greeks, no Turks) is flawed (whatever the UN or the international courts say). But if history begins in '74, then the Greek Cypriots are the ethnically cleansed victims and Mr Denktash runs a doomed little charade of an unrecognised and unrecognisable state. I was here (for the Guardian) in 1964. I have to say that I saw too many dead or dispossessed Turkish Cypriots to wipe that slate of history squeaky clean. I can understand the north's muck sweat over security - just as I can understand the profound injustice that Greek Cypriots feel about seeing their homes, lands and livelihoods taken away one night at the point of a Turkish bayonet. With 35,000 Turkish mainland troops still on site, security sweat runs two ways. But when fear turns into bleak constitutionality on lawyers' lips, hell freezes over. The one thing Greek Cypriots won't negotiate is their international legitimacy as the government of the island - right down to anything as humble as cutting Turkish Cyprus out of a kids' football tournament. The one thing that Mr Denktash won't countenance is any implied slight to his self-proclaimed status - right down to making the UN troops on the ground use a single checkpoint on the long green line. Goalposts move, but goals, including partition - don't. Thus principle comes to seem pettily vindictive. Thus cross-border contacts wither as Mr Denktash shuts his saddened citizens away and the people of one small island grow so far apart that they might as well inhabit different planets. Thus Greek Cypriots, in the ignorance of isolation, think the north is a flyblown basket case (which it isn't) - and, while everybody says they want a settlement, the inertia of a realpolitik status quo descends - even on Greeks still striving manfully. Thus the EU representative here is persona non grata in Turkish Nicosia, because the union accepted the (Greek) government's application. Confused? Of course. Anyone would be. But the sheer pettifoggery of the dispute sends its own insular message. How does it sit with Greece's buoyant euro economy and move into the European mainstream? How does it suit a Turkey which argued passionately for the right to be an EU candidate - and prevailed? Where does the crucial rapprochement between Athens and Ankara go from here? Down the drain in October, when Nicosia may call on the Greeks to veto Turkey's candidature unless a palatable solution appears on a negotiating timetable? If Brussels reneges (as it may) on Greek Cypriot admission, will Athens then heed the cry to veto all enlargement - from Poland to Hungary - as a wrecking act of brotherly solidarity? There isn't slow boat to nowhere any longer; only a speedboat heading for the rocks on a coast near us. Cyprus hasn't been settled these past 30 years because there's been no overwhelming imperative to shift. Dust alley by the Ledra Palace is a monument to decisions evaded and half truths limply embraced. But no. No more. The stakes are rising. This - in its bounty, beauty and necessity for reconciliation - is our fine mess now. Summon the blood, for we shall have to sort it out. peter.preston@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Police hunt hospital killer
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A saboteur being hunted by police in connection with the deaths of three people under anaesthetic may have struck as recently as three weeks ago, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
A saboteur being hunted by police in connection with the deaths of three people under anaesthetic may have struck as recently as three weeks ago, it emerged last night.

Doctors at Leeds general infirmary and St James's hospital, where three people have died and the lives of 20 others have been endangered by interference with anaesthetic equipment, believe that a disgruntled employee is deliberately damaging life-support systems.

The Guardian has learned that suspected sabotage includes breathing pipes and reservoir bags being deliberately punctured or slashed and other anaesthetic equipment being tampered with.

Anaesthetists were sent letters in February warning them to check machinery for tampering before each operation.

The incidents have all taken place in the last 18 months and are believed to be the work of an individual with specialist knowledge of anaesthetic drugs and equipment and legitimate access to them. Both hospitals are part of the United Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS trust, which employs 16,000 people.

Police believe the person responsible is aware of the investigation and is changing his or her modus operandi. Detectives are examining the records of hundreds of patients and interviewing dozens of doctors, nurses and hospital technicians.

Last night a doctor at the infirmary said: "You sometimes get the odd anaesthetic pipe being accidentally crushed by a heavy anaesthetic trolley but these cases are happening far too frequently for it to be explained away by benign means.

"Someone appears to have a grudge and intends to cause serious harm. One of our registrars was targeted within a few days of arriving at the hospital. It went quiet for quite a couple of months but then there was another incident in the last three weeks which sparked everything off again."

The source added: "In terms of deaths, a child died abruptly and unexpectedly at the end of 1998 and what put the wind up people was the same thing happened four days later although that child survived. That really shook people up because he was a perfectly fit kid."

Another senior colleague said: "We have been told to check and double check our equipment for tampering. It is horrific to think a saboteur would be stalking the hospital corridors. Everyone is very uncomfortable."

One of the cases being investigated is the death of Katherine Hallas, a nursery nurse aged 22. She failed to wake up after an apparently routine operation at the infirmary to remove her wisdom teeth.

More than a year later an inquest has still not been held. Julia Ward, her mother, said that when she went to visit her daughter she was told there had been a problem associated with the anaesthetic.

She said: "I just couldn't understand it. I am not looking to blame anyone but I must have answers."

Nazeesh Farooq Khan, three, died at St James's last autumn. Her body was exhumed after blood tests revealed "unanticipated chemical levels", and has not been reburied.

Her father, Mohammed, said: "There is something very wrong at these hospitals. I don't want to jeopardise a criminal investigation by saying too much but I am sure there is much more to come out."

West Yorkshire police have codenamed their investigation "Operation Operation".

Last night the trust sought to allay patients' fears. A spokesman said: "Precautions are taken to check theatre equipment. In the light of these alleged incidents, these precautions have been re-enforced at Leeds general infirmary and St James's hospital.

"There are on-going checks and all hospital staff are being made aware about what is going on. We would like to assure patients that if these incidents are malicious they are not repeated. There is every possibility that these allegations will not be proved at all."

A West Yorkshire police spokesman said: "The trust approached the police in October last year seeking assistance in the investigation of 10 incidents where patients experienced unexpected complications while undergoing treatment. Three people subsequently died.

"Staff at the hospitals fully support the police investigation and inquiries will be completed as soon as possible."

fields.headline: The health of the NHS
fields.standfirst:
Reform it, but preserve the essentials

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The National Health Service (NHS) is heading towards its biggest restructuring since it was founded in 1948. Stand by for nervous pre-emptive strikes by medics, managers and ministers.
fields.body:
The National Health Service (NHS) is heading towards its biggest restructuring since it was founded in 1948. Stand by for nervous pre-emptive strikes by medics, managers and ministers. The past few days have produced a flood of health-related stories. Time for some context.

The NHS was described by one American academic as "the finest bit of social legislation since Magna Carta". The trouble has always been how to fund it. Its tax-based system has proved the cheapest and fairest way of funding health care, but it has suffered from one persistent and serious defect: the politicians had to be persuaded to find the cash. Now they have done just that. Labour has promised to increase spending on the service by a third over the next five years from £50bn to £69bn. Annual spending increases will rise to 6% in real terms, double the historic trend. But as a quid pro quo, ministers have insisted the service must be modernised. A 10-year plan is to be published later this month.

Traditionalists believe the NHS has continued to provide clinical treatment as good as anywhere in the world, but concede that the continuous financial squeeze has left us in some areas with conditions which would cause a riot if experienced on a package holiday: shabby rooms, peeling paint, grim grey corridors. Two recent reports have questioned even the standard of health care. The World Health Organisation's league table of health systems, published two weeks ago, placed the UK 18th out of the 191 member nations - below France, Italy, Greece, Spain, Japan, Norway and Portugal, though ahead of the US, Germany, Denmark, and Sweden. The nation which topped the league, France, carries out 30% more hip-replacement operations and 42% more heart bypasses. One reason, as the health secretary has conceded, is that they have more doctors. Yet it is not that simple. Germany, with twice as many doctors as the UK, came 25th.

A more disturbing report was last Friday's study on lung cancer in the Clinical Oncology journal, which found the disease had become untreatable in more than one in five sufferers because of the time they had waited for treatment. Although the study involved only 29 patients, the government's cancer tsar conceded it was highlighting "unacceptable problems that we know exist and are determined to tackle in our cancer services". Fast-growing tumours are not restricted to lung cancer, but affect head, neck and cervical cancer too.

Changes in the pipeline are not restricted to the national plan. Last week's row at the British Medical Association conference, when the General Medical Council was censured for the first time, was driven by the GMC's proposals for a medical MOT, under which all doctors will have to have their licences to practise revalidated every five years. Labour's Commission for Health Improvement has begun its inspections, which will monitor all units and services in the system. Hospital and health authorities are drawing up annual appraisal systems. A traditionally independent profession is having to come to terms with being made accountable.

Gross though recent medical abuses have been - incompetent operations on children, arrogant removal of organs from dead babies, inappropriate operations on women - doctors point to the numbers treated by the NHS: 1m patients each day. What they ignore is the chief medical officer's report which suggested that one in three hospital consultants and one in five GPs suffered from some performance problem. His aim was not to find scapegoats but to move away from the present blame culture to a system which would identify underperformance early and provide the medics involved with more support. That serves the interests of both patients and doctors. Making the health service more patient-oriented will have that double benefit too. The government is right to ignore BMA grumbles against the new NHS helpline, walk-in clinics and online health care. Medics as well as patients will gain if ministers succeed in breaking down the rigid professional demarcation barriers which prevent doctors, nurses and allied professionals from working more flexibly. A more responsive service can give the professionals more cause for pride and greater job satisfaction.

On one issue both medics and managers are united: their suspicion of central controls. In its 1997 manifesto, Labour insisted that "there can be no return to top-down management"; yet top- down management has returned. But this may have been necessary to generate the energy for reform. The test is whether ministers will be ready to let go of the levers once their framework is in place. The health secretary has spoken of "earned autonomy", which managers have welcomed: successfully run units will be left alone. A modernising blitz is justified. But it must not ignore the old unsolved challenges facing the NHS: chronic care and health inequalities.

webTitle: The best interior design scene: Gangster no.1

fields.headline: The best interior design scene: Gangster no.1
fields.trailText: 1968. London. Gangster (Paul Bettany) has paid a visit to his boss Freddie Mays, only to find his Mayfair flat empty apart from Freddie's girlfriend Karen (Saffron Burrows). The two are not close. Gangster wanders over to an area of the flat being redecorated, pulling back a sheet. Underneath is an unfinished mosaic of a horse.
fields.body:
1968. London. Gangster (Paul Bettany) has paid a visit to his boss Freddie Mays, only to find his Mayfair flat empty apart from Freddie's girlfriend Karen (Saffron Burrows). The two are not close. Gangster wanders over to an area of the flat being redecorated, pulling back a sheet. Underneath is an unfinished mosaic of a horse.

"Freddie's not allowed to see it yet," protests Karen.

Gangster smirks back.

"Do you know, it's not a bad likeness of Freddie. Nose a bit on the large side though."

"Very funny. You know Freddie, he's mad about horses. I thought it might make a nice engagement present."

Gangster is stunned. His smirk vanishes.

"You what?"

"An engagement present. As in me and Freddie. Didn't he tell you?"

"No, he fucking didn't. You up the duff or something? Can we hear the pitter-patter of tiny feet?"

"No, not yet."

Gangster sneers, leaning in.

"Bet you're over the moon, aren't you?"

"That's a nasty way of putting it. I'd have thought any mate of Freddie's would be happy too. What's your problem?"

"Ain't me that's got a problem, darlin'."

"I'm not surprised he didn't tell you. Well, I love Freddie, I'd kill for that man, and I don't give a fuck what you say."

She shoves him away.

"Keep your fucking knickers on."

She leans back, then spits in his face.

See also: The Rebel, American Psycho, Wall Street

Don't see also: Don't Tell Mom The Babysitter's Dead

Pointless trivia: Saffron Burrows made her screen debut in Jim Sheridan's In The Name Of The Father, as "Girl In Commune".

fields.headline: Goodbye to all that
fields.standfirst: Once Labour's working-class heartlands could be relied on to swell the vote at elections. But we are now in a process of 'class de-alignment'
fields.trailText: A distinctive feature of Labour's victory in 1997 was that it successfully appealed to all social classes. The party not only obtained a clear majority of working-class votes. It also secured a proportionately higher share of middle-class votes than it ever had before.
fields.body:
A distinctive feature of Labour's victory in 1997 was that it successfully appealed to all social classes. The party not only obtained a clear majority of working-class votes. It also secured a proportionately higher share of middle-class votes than it ever had before.

Some say that Labour's rightwards policy shift has failed to make provision for its traditional supporters. Low turnouts and weak showing in local authority and European parliament elections are taken as evidence that working-class supporters are frustrated by the government's failure to address their everyday concerns. The fear is that, in spite of Labour's continuing lead in the polls, it will be unable to persuade core voters to make the effort to turn out and take part in the next general election.

But class-based voting has been in decline for 30 years. In the 60s, voters tended to support the party that they thought best represented their class interests. The Tories' stance as the party of property and enterprise resonated with the middle class and the rich. Labour's broadly redistributive position attracted disproportionate support from working-class voters and the less well off. Roughly two-thirds of middle-class voters supported the Tories while two-thirds of the working-class voted Labour. These proportions declined gradually during the 70s and 80s because of changes in patterns of employment and lifestyle - a process labelled "class de-alignment".

But in 1997, Labour still enjoyed a significant advantage over the Tories among the working class (58% compared with 29%). It also led them among the middle class (40% compared with 38%). This margin was crucial for a simple reason. Between 1964 and 1997, the size of the manual working class fell from around 60% of the electorate to around 40%. Labour has to appeal to the non-manual vote: no matter how much support Labour might have gained from the working class in 1997, it would have found it very difficult to win.

Recent evidence suggests this process may have gone further. The chart shows class (as defined by the Market Research Society) and vote in April 2000, using data from a Gallup survey for a project being conducted for the Economic and Social Research Council. For voters as a whole, the Tories' share is 31%, Labour 49% and the Liberal Democrats 13%. But note how the vote is distributed across the classes. Among AB (professional and managerial) voters, Labour support is on 48%. Among C1s (intermediate and routine non-manual workers), it is 45%; among C2s (skilled manual) 51%; and among D/Es (unskilled manual and other) 50%. Note also how the Tory and LibDem vote shares are very similar across the categories.

These figures are relevant to the "heartlands" debate. Labour no longer draws support disproportionately from the working class to any significant degree but instead draws support more or less equally from all social classes. So what are the political implications?

Labour has lost working class (C2, D/E) support since 1997. Some say this implies future electoral success depends on the party's ability to restore its fortunes among its traditional voters. The danger with this approach is that any appeal directed purely at increasing working-class votes risks a proportionate loss of middle-class support.

The positive interpretation focuses on Labour's increased ability to appeal to the middle class. It recognises that over the past 30 years, voters across the board have become far more dis criminating - or fickle - in deciding how to cast their votes. They are no longer prepared to vote along traditional "tribal" class lines. They are becoming more and more like discriminating consumers who evaluate competing products.

As a result, voting decisions are now more heavily influenced by voters' assessments of the main parties' relative managerial competencies and by their evaluations of the rival frontbench teams' leadership abilities. Just as businesses seek to diversify their markets in order to strengthen their overall position, this broad appeal should be seen as a strength rather than a weakness.

It means that Labour can afford to lose support among one group of voters without fatally weakening its electoral position. Crucially, it means that Labour does not need to rely exclusively on its heartlands working-class vote in order to win the next election and that Tony Blair can continue to pursue his current "big tent" policy approach.

Recent analyses have suggested that Labour's opinion poll lead is misleadingly high because Labour voters are less likely to turn out in real elections than other parties' supporters. In the April 2000 Gallup survey, respondents were also asked a question about the likelihood (on a 0-10 scale) that they would actually vote in the next general election. If we adjust the vote shares to take account of this, Labour's vote share falls to 46%, the Conservative share increases to 32% and the LibDems to 14%. The pattern of party support across the different classes described above is unaffected by this adjustment.

In many respects, Labour no longer has a heartland vote. It follows that Labour does not have very much to lose by failing to make a specific appeal to its traditional supporters in the north, on the estates and so on. To do well in the next election, Labour needs to convince enough voters across all social classes that it is meeting their concerns about the things that matter most to them: the economy, the health service and education.

 David Sanders is professor of politics at Essex University.

It means that Labour can afford to lose support among one group of voters without fatally weakening its electoral position. Crucially, it means that Labour does not need to rely exclusively on its heartlands working-class vote in order to win the next election and that Tony Blair can continue to pursue his current "big tent" policy approach. Recent analyses have suggested that Labour's opinion poll lead is misleadingly high because Labour voters are less likely to turn out in real elections than other parties' supporters. In the April 2000 Gallup survey, respondents were also asked a question about the likelihood (on a 0-10 scale) that they would actually vote in the next general election. If we adjust the vote shares to take account of this, Labour's vote share falls to 46%, the Conservative share increases to 32% and the LibDems to 14%. The pattern of party support across the different classes described above is unaffected by this adjustment. In many respects, Labour no longer has a heartland vote. It follows that Labour does not have very much to lose by failing to make a specific appeal to its traditional supporters in the north, on the estates and so on. To do well in the next election, Labour needs to convince enough voters across all social classes that it is meeting their concerns about the things that matter most to them: the economy, the health service and education.  David Sanders is professor of politics at Essex University. sanders@essex.ac.uk

webTitle: Papuans renew their drive for freedom

fields.headline: Papuans renew their drive for freedom
fields.standfirst:
Indonesian province determined to secede by peaceful means
Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The independence movement in Papua, Indonesia's eastern-most province, is holding talks with President Abdurrahman Wahid after a year of reorganisation and consensus-building in which it has already won the right to call the area by its old name.
fields.body:
The independence movement in Papua, Indonesia's eastern-most province, is holding talks with President Abdurrahman Wahid after a year of reorganisation and consensus-building in which it has already won the right to call the area by its old name.

Members of the Papuan Praesidium Council are in Jakarta for their first round of negotiations with the president, knowing that the vast majority of the 2.3m people in the province Indonesia used to call Irian Jaya are fully behind their renewed call for secession.

That was made abundantly clear at a colourful congress in the provincial capital, Jayapura, last month. Thousands of people from all the 254 indigenous tribes and representatives of the migrants who live in the province, which shares the island of New Guinea with the independent state of Papua New Guinea, decided unanimously to campaign for their own immediate independence.

Many of the delegates, dressed only in penis sheaths and feathered headdresses, trekked for more than a week across glacier-covered mountains and barely penetrable virgin rainforest to call for an end to 31 years of Indonesian rule.

"It is not just me but all Papuans who are satisfied by the result of the congress," the praesidium chairman, Theys Eluay, said.

"We succeeded in reaching a consensus on our aspirations and the praesidium now has the legitimacy to take the struggle forward."

Mr Eluay stressed that, in contrast to its own past activity and that of independence movements in East Timor and Aceh, the new Papuan campaign would be peaceful.

"We want to succeed through dialogue and negotiation," he said. "We are determined not to resort to violence."

Contrary to many reports in the Jakarta press, the congress's resolution did not commit the treasonable offence of declaring independence.

Rather, it stated that the Papuan people obtained their independence on December 1 1961, when the Dutch finally left the last of the colonies formerly known as the Dutch East Indies.

It also rejected the 1969 "Act of Free Choice", the UN-sponsored process in which 1,025 community leaders voted unanimously to integrate with President Suharto's Indonesia, on the grounds that it was "conducted to the accompaniment of threats, intimidation, sadistic killings, military violence and amoral deeds that gravely violated humanitarian principles".

Mr Eluay, who was one of the signatories, said they had little choice but to sign.

"If we had not voted for integration our houses would have been burned and our families slaughtered."

In the past two years the level of oppression has declined significantly, although armed militia supporting the Indonesian connection are starting to operate in the far west of the territory, just as they did in East Timor.

They have been involved in several violent incidents, particularly in the town of Fak-fak. One day during the congress security guards seized 14 pistols and two homemade bombs from people trying to enter.

"It is the army and the political elite in Jakarta trying to stir up conflict among us so they will then have an excuse to intervene," said Denny Yomaki, a senior figure in several local organisations.

Mr Wahid's policy somersaults seem to show Jakarta's growing unease at the developments in Irian Jaya. At first he supported the congress to the extent of promising to open it, then pulled out at the last minute, although he still gave 1bn rupiahs (£75,400) to help finance it.

Since the congress ended, he has led the vocal disapproval of its resolution. But he has intensified development programmes in the province, and agreed to let the Papuans fly their flag, the Morning Star, in public as long as it is together with and below the Indonesian flag.

In December he declared that the province should revert to its original name, Papua. An independent commission will be set up to investigate past human rights abuses. But it is doubtful whether all this will be enough to sway Papuans from their desire for independence.

"The basic problem here is not one of money or development," said Yohanes Bonay, director of Jayapura office of the Institute for Human Rights Studies and Advocacy. "It is all about the sovereignty of the Papuan people over their own land. If the people think they have to separate from Indonesia in order to achieve that, then they will continue their struggle until they do. It's up to Indonesia to come up with an alternative."

Despite Mr Wahid's concessions, he is determined to hang on to Papua, not only because of the billions of dollars a year Jakarta gets from the area, but also because he does not want it to precipitate national disintegration.

But national cohesiveness holds little sway in Papua.

"We know that our cause is just and so we are prepared to take as long as is necessary," Mr Eluay said. "But we are determined that it will only be a matter of time before we are completely free."

webTitle: Ulster braced for week of Orange unrest

fields.headline: Ulster braced for week of Orange unrest
fields.standfirst:
Parade ban provokes fighting talk from loyalists as 3,000 flock to Drumcree
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Orangemen in Portadown, Co Armagh, yesterday raised fears of a week-long campaign of violent confrontation with the security forces after calling for protests across Northern Ireland against the parades commission's ban on them marching along the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road.
fields.body:
Orangemen in Portadown, Co Armagh, yesterday raised fears of a week-long campaign of violent confrontation with the security forces after calling for protests across Northern Ireland against the parades commission's ban on them marching along the mainly nationalist Garvaghy Road.

More than 3,000 supporters, far in excess of predictions, flocked to Drumcree, on the outskirts of Portadown, to the first of two consecutive Sunday marches that threaten Northern Ireland's fragile peace. There were minor skirmishes, and one man suffered head injuries as missiles were aimed at the police.

Harold Gracey, the Portadown district grand master, made no repeat of his demand last year for a peaceful protest, after which his lodge walked away from confrontation with the RUC.

To roars of approval, Mr Gracey demanded that loyalists engage in province-wide demonstrations this week, to stretch the army and police. He said the security forces could control a protest solely at Drumcree more easily.

He called for mass support at next Sunday's parade, increasingly seen as the make-or-break flashpoint. He believed that up to 100,000 people could turn up.

In an uncompromising address, Mr Gracey said: "This battle is not just about Drumcree. This is about the Orange Order. It is about the Protestant people. They used to be on their knees. Now they are on their bellies. If they don't get up before it is too late this country will be gone."

In a swipe at the prime minister, Mr Gracey told demonstrators: "I said to Tony Blair, last year you may have duped us. You won't dupe us again."

Orangemen claim Mr Blair promised them a march last autumn if they backed off last year. Downing Street denies there was any deal, but the protesters are furious at what they see as betrayal.

Several paramilitaries were among the demonstrators, including members of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, which has been involved in violence in previous years, and the hardline outfit, the Orange Volunteers. Representatives of the fascist group Combat 18 are expected to join them this week.

One leading loyalist dissident said yesterday: "Next week will be the real test, and we are ready for it. We can't go on backing down."

There was at first a thin line of officers separating the Orangemen from their traditional route back to Portadown after the service at the Church of the Ascension at Drumcree. As fighting began, two armoured vehicles blocked the road. An Ulster Freedom Fighters banner was draped on one of them.

While the Portadown lodge was at the church service, Mark Harbinson, an Orangeman from Stoneyford, Co Antrim, told protesters: "No longer can we stand by and let the same situation happen year after year. Today is a rallying call. This is Ulster's Alamo. Here we stand because we can do no other."

The RUC had wanted to maintain a low-profile, and there had been no moves to build trenches or install rows of razor wire to stop protesters crossing police lines. They are certain to be put in place later this week.

Orangemen confirmed there will be nightly protests at Drumcree, and some violence appears inevitable. But there was no confirmation of claims from one senior Orangeman that plans had been drawn up for demonstrations across Northern Ireland this week.

webTitle: Mugabe says land seizure will continue

fields.headline: Mugabe says land seizure will continue
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe has dashed the hopes of Zimbabwe's white farmers that the land seizures will end now the election is over by urging war veterans to remain on the farms they have occupied.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe has dashed the hopes of Zimbabwe's white farmers that the land seizures will end now the election is over by urging war veterans to remain on the farms they have occupied.

"Let them stay where they are until the government comes with the law and the necessary mechanisms to deliver land to them," he said yesterday in a speech to mark the first anniversary of the death of the nationalist leader Joshua Nkomo.

Several hundred people gathered in the gardens of the home Nkomo owned in Bulawayo, the capital of Mata beleland, to hear Mr Mugabe condemn the unilateral declaration of independence by Rhodesia's last white prime minister, Ian Smith, which he called the greatest violation of the rule of law ever known in his country.

Mr Mugabe told how Joshua Nkomo led a delegation to meet the then British prime minister, Harold Wilson, who was trying to prevent the declaration. "We heard Wilson say he would not send British troops to stop UDI because the British public would not stand for having troops kill its kith and kin," he said, adding that by comparison, the occupation of white farms was trivial.

"The courts said it was tres pass and we should send police to correct that wrong. They've broken a little law of trespass," he said. "Ian Smith broke the fundamental law of the country - Harold Wilson said he would not send his army - but must I see my kith and kin killed because of the law of trespass."

The land the war veterans had occupied had never been paid for by the white settlers, he said. "The Europeans are thieves. They cannot say they are owners. If you buy stolen land, you're not in the position of a legitimate owner."

Farm invasions by war veterans have started up again in several parts of Zimbabwe, according to the Commercial Farmers' Union, the main lobby group for the country's white farmers.

"Groups of veterans have been going round farms saying they are going to take over the land. Some of our neighbours were told they have to be out by Monday,"said Ox Hacking, who owns a farm nine miles south of Marondera in Mashonaland East.The area was rife with intimidation and land occupations by Zanu-PF supporters in the run-up to the election.

"We expected there would be a change of emphasis now. The elections are over. What's the point of intimidation?" said Steve Pratt, the CFU's information officer for the region. He had just returned from a visit to the local police superintendent to give him details of the incidents passed on to his office in the last 48 hours.

"We don't expect the police to walk on to the farms tomorrow and get the war veterans off. That's unrealistic," he added. "But if there's violence and stock theft, I hope they'll take action. At the moment the police are just conducting a holding exercise."

Most white farmers in Mashonaland are too nervous to let reporters visit their farms, even for off-the-record talks. "If the veterans see the media, they often take it out on the black farmworkers the next evening," Mr Pratt said.

Ox Hacking is one of the few who is bold enough to go on the record. He does not mince his words. "If the police had any balls, they'd tell these people 'You've made your point. Now piss off back to the reserves'. But here a police superintendent has no more power than a constable would have in Britain. They're under the politicians' control."

Shortly before the election the government declared that more than 800 white-owned farms would be taken over, a move which forced the postponement of a compromise brokered by the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, in which the UN planned to provide foreign money to compensate the farmers for their land.

Occupations by groups of war veterans have been hitting hundreds of other farms not on the list, such as Mr Hacking's. Four veterans invaded his land and remained until the election, then left. He does not know if they will return.

New occupations are also reported in two other provinces as well as Matabeleland, creating a mood of uncertainty.

'Someone has to give a clear directive. Either the war vets stay and we go, or they go and we stay," Mr Hacking said.

Mr Mugabe appeared to give that directive in a television interview with the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation on Thursday night.

Asked about the future of the land redistribution policy, he replied: "It's continuing with vigour, my brother. We have given notices to the farmers which expire on July 3. We begin the process of acquisition thereafter.

"We then serve the farmers with ownership of the land by government. I think it's going to happen."

Mr Mugabe was referring to today's deadline for the owners of designated farms to appeal to the ministry of agriculture if they contest the take-over. CFU sources say that many will.

The ministry then has 30 days to apply for a court order confirming its decision to acquire the farmland.

webTitle: Drug case failed 'for want of a judge'

fields.headline: Drug case failed 'for want of a judge'
fields.standfirst: Drugs in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Police and politicians have raised concerns about a lack of judges in Scotland after a case against an alleged drug smuggler collapsed because it could not be processed in time.
fields.body:
Police and politicians have raised concerns about a lack of judges in Scotland after a case against an alleged drug smuggler collapsed because it could not be processed in time.

William Varey, 50, was arrested on July 2 last year and accused of being involved in a £50,000 cannabis ring. The deadline to try him expired at the weekend and the charges were dropped because a judge could not be found.

"It is very disappointing," said Superintendent Fred McManus, president of the Association of Scottish Police Superintendents. "This type of scenario raises grave concerns about resourcing in the court system." The Scottish executive, however, has denied that there was a shortage of judges.

The Scottish National Party will raise the issue in the Scottish parliament this week. "There must be an inquiry to establish exactly why a judge couldn't be found," said shadow justice minister Roseanna Cunningham. "It suggests a justice system which is creaking at the seams, which is why there has to be a long hard look at what happened in this case. If the underlying problem is a lack of resources, then it raises serious questions about the £48m underspend in the justice budget revealed last week."

webTitle: 'If Blair doesn't want to know, you're finished'

fields.headline: 'If Blair doesn't want to know, you're finished'
fields.standfirst:
The headline that gave Tony Blair's relationship with Ken and Barbara Follett the jolt from which it never recovered appeared in the Daily Mail on January 20 1995
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: "Bambi in Luvvieland", it read over a feature describing the comings and goings at a dinner party given by the novelist and his then-aspiring MP wife at their £2m home in Cheyne Walk, Chelsea.
fields.body:
"Bambi in Luvvieland", it read over a feature describing the comings and goings at a dinner party given by the novelist and his then-aspiring MP wife at their £2m home in Cheyne Walk, Chelsea.

Douglas Adams, author of The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy, was present. So were the PR guru Lynne Franks, the actor Hugh Laurie, Neil Tennant of the Pet Shop Boys and the ubiquitous Lord Attenborough - the epitome of the "Labour luvvie" tag beloved of some newspapers.

"Bambi" was for a short time the Mail's nickname for Mr Blair. He and his wife Cherie had not attended one of their hosts' politics-and-showbiz meals before - the former Labour leader John Smith had been dead barely six months - and they were evidently not best pleased to find photographers and television crews at the front door.

They scurried in, according to the Mail's account, but managed a smile as they left in the leader of the opposition's official red Rover. The Attenboroughs had come in a Rolls-Royce, the agony aunt Claire Rayner in a Volvo that turned out to have a flat tyre.

"Ken is a lovely person, we're great friends," Ms Rayner later told the Mail. But the incident soured the Folletts' relationship with the Blairs. Stories started appearing to the effect that the Blairs were distancing themselves from the showbiz circuit - that they were more serious people.

In April 1995 Mr Follett announced his resignation as Labour's unofficial fundraiser. He took with him his mixture of charm, jollity (good dinner parties, lots of champagne) and steeliness - qualities that enabled the likes of Lord McAlpine, Margaret Thatcher's gifted moneyman, to wheedle cheques out of the wealthy once the leader had left the table.

Mr Follett had been chairman of the One Thousand Club, an elite group of donors who attended dinners in Park Lane hotels. He continued to work for Labour - helping to find and finance the Excalibur search engine which fuelled Labour's rapid rebuttal unit in the 1997 campaign.

After that crushing vindication at the polls the novelist wrote a bitter piece in the Sunday Times about the shortsightedness of spin doctors.

fields.headline: Army snubs Fijian rebels' demands
fields.standfirst: The Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: The Fijian army said yesterday that it would appoint a temporary government by Thursday which would include ethnic indians, defying the hostage-takers who are demanding that ethnic Indians should be stripped of political power.
fields.body:
The Fijian army said yesterday that it would appoint a temporary government by Thursday which would include ethnic indians, defying the hostage-takers who are demanding that ethnic Indians should be stripped of political power.

The announcement seems to raise the stakes in the political standoff which has prevailed since 27 members of the Indian-led government were taken hostage 43 days ago.

"There will be ethnic Indo-Fijians in the interim government lineup, although percentages I cannot say at this point in time," Lieutenant-Colonel Filipo Tarakinikini said.

The armed forces said last week that they would appoint an interim government without any input from the hostage-takers, who had been demanding a role in naming the government.

Last Thursday Col Tarakinikini said the temporary government would take office only once the hostages were released, but yesterday he said the army would not wait.

Responding to the announcement, the rebel spokesman, Jo Nata, said: "We hope they are prepared for the implications of their actions."

The rebel leader, George Speight, has said that any military action seen as unfavourable to the indigenous population could lead to violence by his supporters.
AP

webTitle: Spin the king in a town called malice

fields.headline: Spin the king in a town called malice
fields.standfirst:
Whitehall's atmosphere of backbiting encourages press attacks
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Of all people Margaret Beckett should have known better than to rubbish Ken Follett's attack on New Labour spin-doctoring by suggesting that attacks in print on ministers by their colleagues started under the Tories in Margaret Thatcher's day.
fields.body:
Of all people Margaret Beckett should have known better than to rubbish Ken Follett's attack on New Labour spin-doctoring by suggesting that attacks in print on ministers by their colleagues started under the Tories in Margaret Thatcher's day.

It started centuries ago and was alive and well during the turbulent Labour government of 1974-79 in which the then Margaret Jackson served as a junior minister. The Wilson governments of 1964-70 were not without a spot of back-biting either.

Nor is the Blair cabinet, though among the governments I have reported on for 20 years this one remains the most disciplined and cohesive, despite reported tensions, some of them very real. Relations with the press are also not as bad as in Harold Wilson's stormier days.

All that, of course, is reporter-speak for dull, which forces them to go further afield for sources, sometimes to what one senior minister, furious with Mr Follett's outburst in yesterday's Observer, dismissed as "some low-level squit working on the fourth rung of the party machine whom they've had a drink with or managed to wind up on the phone".

Harsh words, and not always true. Some stories remain very well-sourced. But not as harsh as those directed by the novelist and fundraiser at Tony Blair and the two men he targetted as culprits-in-chief, Alastair Campell, the Downing Street spokesman, and Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary.

In his article, Mr Follett said Mr Blair was making "malicious gossip" a tool of government and called spin doctors political "rent boys." Secret briefings, he said, were the "equivalent of the poison pen-letter - an anonymous attack by someone scared of honest confrontation".

Morality

In the Observer he impugned Mr Blair's honour and worse. He is the boss, he suggested, he must accept the blame. "What really bothers me is the morality of it. Not to put too fine a point on it, the whole business stinks. If you are displeased with a colleague, you should look him or her in the eye and say so. That's the behaviour my parents' generation called 'manly'. It's what we expect from leaders."

It is true, as Ms Beckett and Mr Follett agreed yesterday, that Margaret Thatcher's press secretary, Bernard Ingham - the term spin doctor was not yet invented - did in 1983 describe Francis Pym, then foreign secretary, as "Mona Lott" (a radio character from the 40s).

Later he called another cabinet member, John Biffen "semi-detached". Each left the cabinet soon after. The fuss caused led to a boycott of daily Downing Street briefings by the Guardian and other papers which lasted until No 10 agreed - in John Major's day - to make such briefings attributable to "the prime minister's office."

But that is not the problem. If it were, Alastair Campbell, Tony Blair's high-profile spokesman, would have solved it in May 1997 when he put all his official briefings on the record, attributed to "the Downing Street spokesman".

No, the problem is what it has always been: who says what to whom in a dark corner, in a bar or restaurant or over the phone on a Sunday afternoon. It is also what reporters do with the information: whether they use it discreetly or take a casual aside from a backbencher and blow it up into "Top Blair aide lashes" whoever.

A crisis from the Callaghan era beautifully illustrates the dilemma. In 1977 the prime minister, James Callaghan, had been persuaded by his new foreign secretary, David Owen, to appoint his talented friend, the economics writer Peter Jay, as ambassador to Washington.

Mr Jay happened to be married to Callaghan's daughter, Margaret, and the Downing Street press secretary, a wily, honourable civil servant, Tom McCaffrey, had a brief word outside the daily lobby with the political editors of the London Evening Standard and News about the deficiencies of the incumbent ambassador.

No 10 might have got away with it had not both papers used the same headline : "US envoy was effete snob". The Tories caused a stink, but Mr McCaffrey survived.

Twenty years on, the media and the technologies at its disposal - fax, email, satellite TV and mobile phones - are much more pervasive. There is 24-hour rolling news, cut-throat competition, and politicians are held in less respect.

Hence Downing Street's obsession with staying "on message" and making sure all ministers do the same: sheer speed can magnify a disaster much faster. Ditto malicious gossip.

Is there much? Yes. There always is among politicians, though senior New Labour figures tend to be cautious in speaking candidly with journalists, even those those they know well. Why? Because they cannot be sure - as Kenneth Clarke once found when Tory chancellor - that unguarded remarks over lunch will not find their way onto Radio 4's The World at One with a minimal disguise ("Mr Clarke has told friends...").

But are personal attacks on colleagues worse than they were in the 30s when the press lords tried to ruin governments and the prime minister Stanley Baldwin called such attacks "the new cannibalism"? It remains doubtful.

After all, David Wood of the Times got a tip that Harold Macmillan was planning to sack his foreign secretary, Selwyn Lloyd, circa 1960. That too caused a stink and much abuse of Wood. Now that all concerned are dead, I can reveal that his source was, well, Harold Macmillan, who had to backtrack when the story ended up on page one, not in Wood's column.

Nowadays Mr Mandelson or Mr Campbell are usually blamed when a story blows up in the government's face: they over-spun it, they under-spun it. Chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, or the Blair aide Anji Hunter also get some flak, as do more shadowy figures in the system.

The truth is often hard to unpick. Personally, I have only once heard Blair speak slightly ill of a colleague, who he admitted "lacked guile" - and chuckled affectionately as he said it.

Self-indulgent

Ken Livingstone is something else - but Mr Follett can have no comeback. Mr Blair spoke on the record against a man who had left his party.

As for Mr Campbell, his response to what he called Mr Follett's "self-indulgent rant" yesterday - very much on the record - was typical, he said. It sounded as if his old chum might have a new book coming out.

"Challenged to provide any evidence of briefings against Mo Mowlam, he resorted to peddling an old, untrue story claiming that a spokesman for the prime minister had briefed Roy Hattersley against David Clark. That is, and always was, untrue," Mr Campbell said.

One truth all too evident last night was that this was a row long overdue. Unlike some of Labour's fairweather friends the Folletts have long been active Labour supporters. Barbara Follett is now MP for Stevenage.

Ken and Barbara remain close friends of Neil and Glenys Kinnock, for whom they worked hard raising millions. John Smith was less close, not attracted to the London celebrity circuit, Tony Blair had other friends. A natural cooling was made cooler by unwanted publicity.

Then there was the question of Barbara's political career. She hoped to become a minister, it was said, but only managed to become Jack Cunningham's unpaid private parliamentary secretary.

She is also disappointed that Labour has not done more for women, not least to ensure more, not fewer, women MPs next time. Ken Follett complains of attacks on civil liberties and a lack of moral core in the regime.

So was yesterday's outburst the grievance of a discarded and ill-disciplined attention-seeker or the "somebody's got to say it" response of a genuinely unhappy Labour supporter who does not like what he sees? Labour MPs, ministers and voters will make their own choice in a party where egotism and idealism have long marched hand in hand.

webTitle: Rail shutdown to hit Christmas travellers

fields.headline: Rail shutdown to hit Christmas travellers
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Rail travellers planning journeys over Christmas and new year will face unprecedented disruption after a decision by Railtrack to shut a large part of the rail network for 10 days during the busy holiday period.
fields.body:
Rail travellers planning journeys over Christmas and new year will face unprecedented disruption after a decision by Railtrack to shut a large part of the rail network for 10 days during the busy holiday period.

A decision to close part of the west coast mainline between London and Glasgow, which has still to be officially announced, has infuriated the Post Office, whose nationwide rail distribution network from Willesden in north-west London will be forced to close. More than 16m letters a day will be affected.

The decision, confirmed by Railtrack sources last night, will also affect passengers and commuters who use Britain's most important rail artery every day. Inter-city services between London, Birmingham, Glasgow, Manchester and Liverpool will come to a virtual halt.

Railtrack says it has to carry out vital work to upgrade the line, and that shutting the network for 10 days from 11pm on December 23 to January 2 will cause minimum inconvenience to rail users.

The Post Office is one of Railtrack's biggest customers, but was not given the opportunity to discuss the issue and has protested to Railtrack's chief executive, Gerald Corbett.

The two rail companies most closely involved are Virgin and Silverlink. Virgin will be virtually prevented from using London Euston and its services will end at Watford, Hertfordshire. Silverlink, which carries thousands of passengers into London from the north-western suburbs and home counties, will be halted.

Railtrack last night apologised for the forthcoming upheaval. It said: "We have studied all the options, but this work is essential and we have decided to carry it out when it will cause minimum disruption. People travelling for Christmas will be able to get away on time and there are no postal deliveries on Christmas Day or Boxing Day."

Rail passenger groups retorted that thousands of people travel to work between Christmas and new year.

"In many cases the trains are packed because passengers also use the trains for leisure purposes and the numbers are rising. It is appalling that Railtrack has not even bothered to prepare the public before taking this decision," said a spokesman for the National Rail Passengers' Group.

Railtrack will have to offer compensation to the Post Office. Senior Post Office executives said yesterday that until a few weeks ago, Railtrack had been assuring them that postal services would not be affected.

Railtrack is under close scrutiny from the rail regulator and the government for the mounting cost of the west coast mainline project up from £2.2bn to £5.8bn in less than two years.

webTitle: Blair backs Levy as tax row widens

fields.headline: Blair backs Levy as tax row widens
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night signalled his determination to stand by Lord Levy by letting it be known he will attend a dinner party given by Labour's top fundraiser this week, despite renewed attacks on his financial affairs.
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night signalled his determination to stand by Lord Levy by letting it be known he will attend a dinner party given by Labour's top fundraiser this week, despite renewed attacks on his financial affairs.

A week after it emerged that the multi-millionaire paid only £5,000 in income tax in 1998-99 it was reported that he had claimed £50,000 in business expenses during the year in question, £36,000 of it tax-free for travel in his capacity as an unpaid management consultant.

The former music impresario turned charity-organiser and personal Middle East envoy to the prime minister did not respond to the latest attacks on him in the Sunday Times. He failed nine days ago to win a court injunction stopping the newspaper revealing his tax return.

Yesterday the newspaper suggested that the latest disclosure undermined Lord Levy's claims "not to employ a highly sophisticated and effective tax avoidance strategy".

A week ago Lord Levy gave rare radio and TV interviews to defend both his career and his commitment to paying millions of pounds in tax rather than go into tax exile.

On Saturday he spoke to the Daily Telegraph, which has given him some editorial support in a difficult week. He told the paper that he had concentrated so much on charitable work - he is an active chairman of Jewish Care - and on politics that his £5,000 income tax year was not (as he had earlier suggested) his only low-tax year. In 1997-98 he had paid "below £10,000" for similar reasons.

Tory critics are publicly saying the Inland Revenue should take a close look at all Lord Levy's tax dealings and privately questioning whether there is any tax evasion as well as sophisticated avoidance of tax.

Earlier this week it was reported that, in addition to the taxable income Lord Levy drew in 1998-99, he took repayment of a £160,000 loan to his company, Wireart, on which he said tax had already been paid.

Among expenses it now appears were claimed by Lord Levy were motoring costs of £14,983, travel bills - including hotels - of £16,363, and sums for using his mobile and home phones. He explained that he had worked to set himself up as a consultant, but was not yet claiming fees.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, again signalled his support for Lord Levy yesterday, as Andrew Lansley, the Tory campaign strategist, promised to take it up with the Inland Revenue.

Mr Blair confirmed that he will attend a mid-week dinner at the peer's north London home - though it has nothing to do with fundraising, aides stressed.

webTitle: Kidnappers' hideouts penetrated by DJs and relatives' requests

fields.headline: Kidnappers' hideouts penetrated by DJs and relatives' requests
fields.trailText: The late-night show on Memories Radio churns out a stream of Mexican cowboy music and romantic ballads interspersed with calls from listeners all over Colombia.
fields.body:
The late-night show on Memories Radio churns out a stream of Mexican cowboy music and romantic ballads interspersed with calls from listeners all over Colombia.

It sounds like any other radio phone-in, until you realise that all the songs and messages are dedicated to victims of the country's multi-million dollar kidnapping industry.

"It happened by accident. The programme was just meant to be a bit of fun, but gradually it was taken over by relatives of the kidnap victims," the presenter, Libardo Bedoya, explained.

The show has become a lifeline for hundreds of families, and every night the station's switchboard is jammed by callers.

"I get blisters dialling the number, but it's such a relief to know he can hear me when I get through," said Adela Afanador, whose son Edgar was snatched by leftwing guerrillas in August 1998.

Heartbreak Hour, and the proliferation of similar radio programmes, reflects the fact that kidnapping has become a part of everyday life in the strife-torn South American country.

"Kidnapping has become normal. In the face of so much injustice, people become insensitive. They prefer not to think about it," said Juan Mesa of Pais Libre, an organisation which campaigns against abduction and extortion.

Increasing unemployment and a severe economic crisis have contributed to the boom in kidnapping, but its roots lie in the violence generated by nearlym 40 years of civil war.

Last year about eight people were kidnapped in Colombia every day, mostly by rebel factions who depend on extortion to fund their campaigns.

Police figures show that more than 1,000 people, including 10 foreigners, have been kidnapped so far this year.

But where once the rebels picked on the wealthy and foreign businessmen, they now cast their nets wider.

Increasingly they abduct members of the urban middle class, snatching their victims either from city streets or from holiday traffic at roadblocks on country roads.

Housewives, schoolchildren and shopkeepers have all been taken hostage, said Guillermo Restrepo, head of anti-kidnapping operations at the ministry of justice. "People think kidnapping is something that only happens to the rich, but the reality is that any Colombian could be kidnapped."
