webTitle: Change in air as Mexicans go to polls

fields.headline: Change in air as Mexicans go to polls
fields.trailText: Mexicans voted yesterday in presidential and parliamentary elections which will decide whether the world's longest- governing party will win another six years of be forced out of office.
fields.body:
Mexicans voted yesterday in presidential and parliamentary elections which will decide whether the world's longest- governing party will win another six years of be forced out of office.

Francisco Labastida is defending the presidency for the Institutional Revolutionary party (PRI) against the colourful Vicente Fox of the conservative National Action party.

Mr Labastida's best ally is the PRI's impressive electoral machine, while Mr Fox appeals to voters fed up with a party that has held the presidency since 1929.

"For the first time our vote is actually going to count," Pablo Diaz said as he queued at polling station in Mexico City.

The PRI's longevity owes much to its ability to win elections with the help of dirty tricks and, sometimes, fraud.

But in recent years opposition parties have been allowed to gain ground at lower levels of government. In 1996 wide-ranging reforms created the independent body which is organising these elections.

There are more than 800 international observers, led by former US president Jimmy Carter, and thousands of national observers watching out for irregularities.

Before polling day observers collected widespread evidence that the PRI was shoring up its support by handing out donations and putting pressure on voters with threats of withdrawing government aid.

With little to separate the two main candidates, much depends on whether supporters of the third-placed leftwinger, Cuauhtemoc Cardenas of the Democratic Revolution party, decide to switch their vote at the last minute.

One voter, Gabriela Ramirez. said: "If I vote for Cardenas it is like giving my vote to Labastida, but I don't know if I can bring myself to support a rightwinger like Fox."

Rob Allyn, who is coordinating the running of the poll, said: "There is a long history of fraud in Mexico, so although we are all hoping for the best, we are also preparing for the worst.

"It is very important to have another pair of eyes."

Besides the president the congress and senate, two state governors and the mayor of Mexico City are being elected.

The first results are expected early today.

webTitle: Universities told to charge £50,000 for a degree

fields.headline: Universities told to charge £50,000 for a degree
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Economists will this week propose that universities should be allowed to charge students as much as £50,000 in fees for three-year degrees by introducing a US-style system of financing higher education.
fields.byline: Lee Elliot Major  and Will Woodward
fields.body:
Economists will this week propose that universities should be allowed to charge students as much as £50,000 in fees for three-year degrees by introducing a US-style system of financing higher education.

Some vice-chancellors in the Russell group of 19 leading universities, which commissioned the economists' report, are privately distancing themselves from the recommendations.

The report, written by Professor David Greenaway of Nottingham University and three other university economists, calls on universities to be freed of state controls to set their own tuition fees, thus addressing their funding shortfalls. It will frame the debate on tuition fees.

Some vice-chancellors emphasise that it is an independent report and does not represent the view of the Russell group. But the proposals have supporters and have attracted interest from the prime minister's advisers, particularly Andrew Adonis, the education specialist in the No 10 policy unit, who has urged university heads to explore "top-up" fees.

The report offers a simple, free market solution to higher education's economic and social problems: charge the rich extra fees and use the money to fund scholarships for the poor.

The economists argue that current funding arrangements equate to a state subsidy for the middle classes. Students from rich backgrounds are charged a flat rate of £1,025 a year in England, but most of the fees are still paid by the government.

The economists think cash-strapped universities must be allowed to set their own fees and student numbers, as US institutions do. Annual fees for university tuition can be as much as $25,000 (£16,500) in the US. Existing state funds would be used to support scholarships for poorer students.

The new funding regime would be phased in over a number of years to give parents a chance to start saving. Eventually, prestigious institutions such as Oxford and Cambridge would be able to charge fees for degree courses at a similar market rate to the top Ivy League institutions, accompanied by an extensive range of scholarships and loans.

Ministers are keen that international research centres such as Cambridge and Oxford are able to compete with the best universities overseas in recruiting leading academics. They also want to support the efforts of universities to attract more students from poor areas but do not want to spend more public money on higher education.

The Greenaway report was commissioned this year by the Russell group after the education secretary, David Blunkett, acknowledged that another strategic review of funding for higher education was needed. He said that while he was personally opposed to top-up fees, "I won't be secretary of state forever."

Senior ministers believe that the recent row over elitism has weakened the case for top-up fees, believing they would discourage students from relatively low incomes who did not qualify for scholarships. The higher education minister, Lady Blackstone, has restated the government's opposition. Opponents include the vice-chancellors of York, Glasgow, Edinburgh, Kingston and Hull.

But even some opponents believe the shortfall in research funding in universities - amounting to a real terms cut this year - makes differential fees inevitable in the medium term. Top-up fees are strongly supported by Sir Colin Campbell, the vice-chancellor of Nottingham University, and privately by others.

The economists' conclusions, to be published on the internet at the end of the week, are part of a wide-ranging study of future academic funding commissioned by the committee of vice-chancellors and principals, due to conclude in September. Last Thursday the vice-chancellors were given an oral presentation of the report.

The report explores a number of funding options, including a graduate tax, to bring higher education funding in Britain in line with the levels seen in other countries such as the US. British universities do not have the multibillion-pound endowments and alumni donations associated with the top institutions in America.

Under their plan, Russell group universities would be modelled on Ivy League institutions such as Cornell, funded by state and private money.

The economists believe that a move to differential fees is the only way to fix the immediate funding problems facing British institutions.

"Britain's universities must be allowed to break loose from state planning," Andrew Oswald, one of the academics who helped to draft the report, wrote in the latest issue of the Economist.

The report also raises some fundamental issues about the status of universities. There are concerns that excessive state controls and fears about job security at British universities are undermining the freedom of academics to express radical and unpopular views.

fields.headline: Church helped Nazis in Italy
fields.trailText: The Catholic church in Italy helped the Nazis by laundering money and supplying intelligence about allied invasion plans, according to declassified documents.
fields.body:
The Catholic church in Italy helped the Nazis by laundering money and supplying intelligence about allied invasion plans, according to declassified documents.

Clerics collaborated with the secret service of Hitler's SS while their flock was rebelling against the retreating German army. Cardinal Ildebrando Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, agreed to transfer money to pay an SS agent, according to a message intercepted by allied code-breakers in October 1943.

The documents, part of a collection of 400,000 second world war British and US intelligence reports declassified last week, raise fresh questions about the Vatican's relationship with the Nazis.

In a dispatch to Berlin from the Rome headquarters of the SS, a Captain Peisner wrote that an agent called Basilus had contacted the cardinal. "And [Basilus] explained to me today how he intended to transfer 300,000 lire through Cardinal Schuster."

The transcript is damaging because the cardinal was not previously thought to have been one of the church's Nazi sympathisers, said James Walston, a historian at the American University of Rome.

"If true it is terrible. Schuster's behaviour was part of a wider pattern of church cooperation, motivated partly by a strong anti-communist ideology."

Another document has cast doubt on the record of Monsignor Hugh O'Flaherty, representative of the American Red Cross at the Vatican. Fr O'Flaherty, who was Irish, was hailed for helping Jews. But according to an SS report dated October 19 1943, he told one of their informants that two US divisions in Sardinia were preparing to land near Civitavecchia, a port north of Rome.

The information was correct, though the allies later changed their plan and landed south of Rome at Anzio. Prof Walston said the evidence that Fr O'Flaherty was a spy was weak, however.

"He may not have known he was talking to an informer. Everybody in Rome at that time would have been speculating about the invasion and Civitavecchia was an obvious guess. The SS agent would have known that quoting a Vatican official would make his report look more impressive to his bosses."

The documents, decrypted by the British Enigma code-breaking operation, were held by the CIA in Maryland, Virginia and released under the auspices of the Nazi war criminal records inter-agency working group, set up in 1998.

They bolstered claims that southern Italians aggressively resisted their allies-turned occupiers as British and US troops approached.

The Germans rounded up 8,000 Jews in Rome in October 1943 but did not swoop south. "Because of the attitude in the town and uncertain conditions, action could not be carried through in Naples," a report sent to SS General Karl Wolff said.

A new book by Aldo De Jaco, 1943: The Resistance of the South, claims that German atrocities galvanised the population into an uprising.

In reality, only a handful of Jews were there, but Naples was one of the few European cities to successfully block the round-ups of Jews.

fields.headline: Clash in Rome
fields.standfirst: Far right protests against gay marchers
fields.trailText: Greeted by neo-Nazis, angry cardinals, a mortified mayor and freshly-outed public figures, the 2000 world gay pride festival started partying in Rome at the weekend.
fields.body:
Greeted by neo-Nazis, angry cardinals, a mortified mayor and freshly-outed public figures, the 2000 world gay pride festival started partying in Rome at the weekend.

More than 300,000 gay men and women are expected to turn the nine-day event into a confrontation with the Vatican which neither side will readily forget.

Hundreds of thousands of pilgrims are also sweeping into the Italian capital for the climax of the Vatican's jubilee, or Holy Year.

Hours before Saturday's opening ceremony, riot police accompanied 700 supporters of the neo-fascist Forza Nuova group who marched in formation giving the Nazi salute.

The group has vowed to disrupt the festival. Religious groups and the far-right National Alliance held a separate torch-lit procession to a shrine associated with solace to "repair the shame".

Cardinal Ersilio Tonini said the church did not see gays as enemies, but he denounced the timing of the festival. "By choosing the Holy Year, the Jubilee, one chooses provocation."

Several Italian gay leaders agreed with the cardinal, but the Vatican's resistance appears to have boosted attendance.

"Whenever there's a problem, we have an outpouring of support. People are all revved up," said Deborah Oakley-Melvin, World Pride's international director.

The Vatican, which considers homosexual sex a sin, fears that pilgrims may be caught up in thefashion parades, soccer matches in drag, art exhibitions and a concert with Gloria Gaynor, Geri Haliwell and the Village People.

Heterosexual Roman men interviewed on television said they were afraid to step outdoors without their partners lest they be considered gay. Campaigners against the event say they have been vindicated by voluntary outings by public figures - a rarity in Italy.

A cabinet minister who declared himself bisexual was followed by the fashion designer Egon Furstenberg, a member of the Agnelli family, which owns Fiat.

A rebel French bishop, Jacques Gaillot, revealed yesterday that the Pope had banned him from attending a debate on religion and homosexuality.

Both sides are preparing for a showdown on July 8, when the gays plan to march to the Colosseum, although the city council has refused them a permit to march there or past any religious building.

The Green mayor, Francesco Rutelli, initially supported the festival but, to jeers, later joined forces with the rightwing opposition.

The warmest welcome is being extended by hoteliers and tour operators, who have been stung by the failure of the jubilee to generate an expected bonanza.

"World Pride is a good thing, especially with rich groups coming from the United States and the Scandinavian countries," said Antonella Compagnucci of the STO-Incoming travel agency.

Some Rome travel guides, gays point out, say that Boniface VIII called the first Holy Year in 1300 partly to divert attention from rumours of papal sodomy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Israel vows to fight for 'spies'
fields.body:
Israel vows to fight for 'spies'

Israel vowed yesterday to spare no effort in bringing about the release of 10 Iranian Jews sentenced to prison for their part in an alleged Israeli spy ring in Iran.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, told Israel's cabinet that he would ask the international community to lobby Tehran to free the men. They were sentenced to between four and 13 years on charges of spying for Israel at a court in the city of Shiraz on Saturday.
Reuters, Jerusalem

Russian police killed by mine

Three Russian policemen were killed when their car drove over a homemade landmine at a shooting range in Chechnya, officials said yesterday.

The Russian interior ministry for Chechnya told the Itar-Tass news agency that the officers had driven to a shooting range in Shelkovskaya, 30 miles north-east of Grozny on Saturday night. They were found dead after reports of an explosion.
Reuters, Moscow

'Racist' flag lowered in US

South Carolina lowered the Confederate flag, widely considered a symbol of racism against blacks in the US, from its state headquarters in Columbia on Saturday, despite protests from pro- and anti-flag campaigners.

The National Organisation for the Advancement of Coloured People had led a tourism boycott of South Carolina over the issue. As a compromise, it was raised again on a flagpole opposite the Capitol building - a controversial move because it left a confederate flag flying on state grounds.
Reuters, Columbia

Professor faces smuggling case

An American archaeology professor was detained at Athens airport yesterday after an ancient amphora dating back to Roman times was allegedly found in his possession, police said.

Michael Martin Kumpf, 55, from Iowa, was allegedly carrying the unpainted vase in his baggage as he boarded a plane for Chicago. In Greece, it is illegal to excavate, own, sell or buy ancient objects without a special permit.
AP, Athens

Impostors steal army weapons

Fifteen men posing as military officers entered an army camp yesterday and stole dozens of assault rifles, the Malaysian defence minister, Najib Razak, said.

Mr Najib said the men told guards at the army camp in the western state of Perak they were conducting a check and demanded to be taken to the armoury where they stole M16s and Steyr rifles.
Reuters , Kuala Lumpur

webTitle: Rebels kidnap German journalist in Philippines

fields.headline: Rebels kidnap German journalist in Philippines
fields.trailText: Muslim rebels holding 20 people hostage on the remote Philippine island of Jolo kidnapped a German journalist for the second time in the space of a month yesterday in an apparent bid to raise the stakes in their $20m (£13.2m) ransom demand.
fields.body:
Muslim rebels holding 20 people hostage on the remote Philippine island of Jolo kidnapped a German journalist for the second time in the space of a month yesterday in an apparent bid to raise the stakes in their $20m (£13.2m) ransom demand.

German media reports said Andreas Lorenz, a correspondent for the weekly magazine Der Spiegel, was abducted yesterday at gunpoint by members of Abu Sayyaf, an Islamic faction fighting for a separate Muslim homeland in the south of the country.

Mr Lorenz, who has been covering the Philippine hostage crisis since it began in April, was among a group of 11 European journalists who last month bribed their way into the rebel encampment and were subsequently forced to pay £16,500 more to ransom themselves out. Yesterday he was travelling into the jungle in another attempt to interview the hostages

Der Spiegel said it had not been in contact with Mr Lorenz yesterday, but his kidnapping was confirmed by Philippines police in the southern province of Sulu. The journalist's driver who witnessed the abduction, said their jeep was ambushed by a group of armed rebels who dragged Mr Lorenz to their vehicle, ordering him to "stop shouting". The driver was then allowed to escape.

The kidnapping coincided with publication of a letter by one of the German hostages, Renate Wallert, in the Philippines' Inquirer newspaper. Ms Wallert wrote that she and the other hostages were "in a dreadful situation living under the worst possible conditions" and had been refused access to doctors for more than a month.

Ms Wallert, who is suffering from high blood pressure and has difficulty walking, recently issued a desperate plea in an interview with Der Spiegel saying: "We are dying here, and there is nothing we can do."

Another hostage, the South African, Monique Strydom, is believed to have suffered a miscarriage. The rebels' leader, Galib Andang, was reported to have told the Inquirer that journalists would no longer be allowed to visit the camp where the western hostages were being held.

Germany was said last month to be considering an offer of "humanitarian aid" to the hostage-takers to resolve the impasse. Berlin has refused to discuss its handling of the crisis for fear of jeopardising any deal with the rebels.

On Saturday, the rebels reportedly allowed a dozen Christian missionaries into their camp after the religious group offered a "gift" of 70 sacks of rice and about £2,000. But it appears that the evangelists were not allowed to see the hostages, who were being held in a separate location.

Heavily armed Islamic insurgents first kidnapped the hostages from the remote Malaysian resort island of Sipadan on Easter Sunday. They were then taken by boat to Jolo, a southern Philippines guerrilla stronghold.

fields.headline: Spin, or no spin?
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText:
Mo Mowlam The ex-Northern Ireland secretary and party pin-up was yesterday reported to be deemed too "unreliable" to be a key player on radio and TV in the coming election. Is it further proof that "Mo" is out of favour and has been sidelined by her old friend Tony Blair? Alastair Campbell has always denied that he, Blair, chief of staff Jonathan Powell or Anji Hunter, Blair's political aide, ever brief against her in private. Others close to Blair have expressed frustration at what they see as her inattention and misjudgments. Mowlam fuels media stories by complaining about "whispers".
Verdict: not proven

Gordon Brown In January 1998 the Observer reported close aides of Blair as admitting that the chancellor had "psychological flaws" during a row over Paul Routledge's pro-Brown biography. It was one of several media stories suggesting that Blair had reined in his powerful chancellor. Campbell was challenged by the Tory MP David Ruffley at a select committee hearing and denied it. But Ruffley may have asked the wrong question and Campbell's authorship is widely believed. He may have wanted the "flaws" point to appear in a column - instead of page one.

webTitle: Now for Emmerdale five nights a week

fields.headline: Now for Emmerdale five nights a week
fields.trailText: After a remarkable revival that would have set Seth Armstrong's moustache twitching, Emmerdale, the rural series whose once-dreary storylines made One Man and His Dog appear cutting-edge, is to be relaunched as a daily soap.
fields.body:
After a remarkable revival that would have set Seth Armstrong's moustache twitching, Emmerdale, the rural series whose once-dreary storylines made One Man and His Dog appear cutting-edge, is to be relaunched as a daily soap.

ITV will announce today that the show, which was saved from oblivion by a mass cull of the dullest characters in the mid-1990s, will be broadcast five nights a week from the autumn.

The decision marks the culmination of a slow climb back to prime-time popularity for Britain's second-oldest television soap, which began in 1972 as Emmerdale Farm. It grew in popularity over the years, but by the early 1990s tastes changed and Carlton threatened to pull it from the schedules in the London area if ratings did not improve.

Phil Redmond, the Brookside creator, was called in to save it. In classic soapland style, he ordered a massacre: a plane crash on Beckindale wiped out the time-served regulars of the Woolpack bar.

Duly spiced up with adultery and lesbianism, and accompanied by a raunchy advertising campaign, the series emerged from the ashes as Emmerdale and became a permanent fixture of the peak-time schedules.

It now regularly attracts 12m viewers, of which an unusually high proportion are in the commercially lucrative 16-34 age group. The show's popularity among young viewers, boosted principally by the introduction of sexier characters, was one of the main reasons for the decision to run it every day.

The Emmerdale announcement is a boost for the Granada group, owner of Yorkshire Television, which makes the show. Granada fears the proposed merger of the other two main ITV groups, Carlton and United, will threaten its position as one of the biggest providers of programmes to the ITV network, and is lobbying hard against the plan. Carlton and United, whose proposed link-up will be ruled on by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, later this month, will use the Emmerdale commission as evidence against Granada's case.

At today's launch, ITV will unveil a raft of programmes with big-name stars. John Thaw, Amanda Burton, Ross Kemp and Robson Green all feature in new series. David Liddiment, the network's director of programmes, is said to want "stars, stars, stars" to boost dwindling ratings.

fields.headline: Motorcycle legend killed in race
fields.trailText: Joey Dunlop, whose legendary exploits in motorcycle racing won him thousands of fans across the divide in Northern Ireland, was killed yesterday road racing in Estonia.
fields.body:
Joey Dunlop, whose legendary exploits in motorcycle racing won him thousands of fans across the divide in Northern Ireland, was killed yesterday road racing in Estonia.

Dunlop, 48, from Ballymoney, Co Antrim, won a record-breaking 26 Isle of Man TT races. The Manx parliament bestowed on him an honorary knighthood after he won three races in this year's championship, in which six riders died.

Dunlop, married with five children, was killed instanteously yesterday after winning the first race on the card. He hit a tree during a 125cc race on a 6.2 mile circuit in the capital, Tallin. His funeral will draw tens of thousands of bikers from all over the world.

Dunlop, who ran a pub, was three weeks ago accorded a hero's reception when he returned home from the Isle of Man. Thousands cheered him through Ballymoney's streets as he toured in an open double-decker bus.

The rider, who began racing in 1969, took the first of his TT titles in 1976.

He was world champion five times and won six consecutive formula one championships from 1983.

Dunlop, whose brother Robert is a also a successful road racer, was awarded the MBE for his motorcycling exploits, and the OBE for his charity work. Most of that centred on aiding orphaned children in Romania and the Balkans.

Northern Ireland's first minister, David Trimble, and Seamus Mallon, deputy first minister, last night joined in a cross-community tribute. They said in a statement: "Everyone in Northern Ireland, not just fans of motor sport, has followed Joey's glittering career with tremendous pride and satisfaction.

"In particular, his recent string of successes in the Isle of Man TT gave us all something to be proud of.

"Five times world champion, Joey was a brilliant sportsman, a true man of the people, and a wonderful ambassador for Northern Ireland. It will be hard to find his like again."

Billy Nutt, a leading motorcycling official in Northern Ireland, said: "He was just an unbelievable character, and for it to end this way is just devastating."

fields.headline: Secrets and lies
fields.standfirst: The BBC has filmed a 'wildlife documentary' with people as its subject. But, says  Mark Lawson, it should really have dug much further into the lives of the family in question
fields.trailText: The BBC has filmed a 'wildlife documentary' with people as its subject. But, says Mark Lawson, it should really have dug much further into the lives of the family in question
fields.body:
In the 1980s - following the success of David Attenborough's zoological documentaries - most sitcoms and a majority of one-off plays would include a scene in which a couple snogging on a sofa were watching Life On Earth. Animal behaviour and animalistic passion would then be counter-pointed. "At this point the female displays," Sir David would whisper, as the girlfriend leaned back to elevate her chest. The scene would generally end with the man doing a terrified detumescent flinch as the great naturalist intoned: "After sex, the female kills the male."

This old television joke turns serious, well, semi-serious, in The Secret Life Of The Family (Wednesday, 8pm, BBC1) in which the Attenborough tactics (filming of mating and nurturing rituals, time-delay cameras, dispassionate analysis of behaviour) are applied to a human family to produce a sort of Social Life On Earth. The Benthall family let cameras inside their house, and even drains, throughout an August day last year. An advanced environmental scanner showed the invisible bugs on their bed-clothes and food.

Confusingly, the mother of this family's a well-known sitcom actress: Janine Duvitski from One Foot In The Grave, here using her married name. This may lead some viewers to believe that the project is a spoof, but the complicating presence of a recognisable actor may be explained by the fact that only Equity members were prepared to agree to this level of exhibitionism. Although in fairness it should be said that this show is partly a BBC spoiler of Big Brother - an elimination gameshow featuring members of the public in a lensed-up house, forthcoming from Channel 4.

But The Secret Life Of The Family relies less on voyeuristic video (CCTV in the living room) than gimmick pictures. X-ray photography turns a Benthall daughter dancing in the kitchen into a skipping skeleton. Many other sequences resemble that sci-fi stand-by: the man with see-through vision who becomes unable to eat and drink because he sees bacterial monsters in every pie and pint. Fancy cameras reveal the "giant cannibal mites" stalking across the bedsheets. The white duvet is shown to have a hidden inner decoration resembling a 60s album cover.

But analysis of these scenes finally brings to mind not Attenborough but Lineker and Hansen. Silky pundits - a cardiologist, a nutritionist, a pair of quip-slick behavioural consultants - talk us through slow-motion replays of the family sleeping, eating, disagreeing. We learn that burgers should be cooked through and that a hand held out for shaking should be "straight not dominant, and give the same pressure you receive".

It's common to accuse these exercises of voyeurism - Big Brother is about to get that big-time - but the real complaint here is that the cameras aren't nosy enough to justify the anthropological billing. A Benthall adolescent has his first kiss with a girl transmitted to the nation, but the parents here submit to little more intrusion than interviews, although Janine's menopause is diagnosed by the medical pundit.

What separates humans from animals is jobs, mortgages, contraception. Yet, although Paul Benthall jokes that his first thoughts on waking are "sex and money", The Secret Life Of The Family never opens the cheque book or pulls back the duvet. I'm not asking for BBC1 to become C5, but so much of human behaviour is driven by financial or erotic considerations that, without these aspects, any attempt to do an Attenborough on the family is superficial.

For example, a cardiologist assesses the physical and mental pressures on Jan and Paul. But are they working? Is the lavish home with swimming pool paid for or exorbitantly loaned? Was their agreement to let the cameras in a career move, or financial necessity? These questions may be intrusive, but that's not an objection easily sustained by a couple who've just let the BBC wire their house for pictures and sound.

In any secret camera project, the most important subject is sex, be it absent or present. The Dutch Big Brother showed couples making love under bed-clothes and the British version hints at the same possibility. This wouldn't be possible or desirable in BBC 1 peak-time, but mating is a major theme of anthropology and its absence prevents any sense that The Secret Life Of The Family is offering a man and woman in full.

The project finally blows itself up when, over film of the Benthalls at a poolside barbecue, the behavioural consultants note that "something is badly wrong". Too many "fake smiles and fake conversations". They excitedly conclude that the presence of the cameras is causing people to act rather than behave. They might have added that, as the Benthalls are thespians, many of their friends may be actors, so what we're watching is professional actors acting socially.

These layers of artificiality condemn The Secret Life Of The Family to keep its secrets. An anthropological film about humans, with no mention of sex, work or money, is about as useful as a zoological series which decides it's inappropriate to invoke the food chain. The revelation that our duvets and fridges are invisible Goyas of microscopic life is no compensation for this failure to go inside the humans.

Dramatic debut

In the last 15 years, the BBC has had more heads of drama - and more spells in which the desk sat empty while potential applicants pretended not to hear the request - than bosses of any other department. That's not surprising. Peak-time drama is the most terrifying area of scheduling. Location filming is more expensive per minute than any broadcasting genre except Premiership football, and the difference here is that Sky and ITV aren't trying to force the BBC out of this game.

Drama is also the form in which it's hardest to predict how an idea will turn out on the screen. Game shows and documentaries can have formats so compelling that you'd need to leave the camera lens cap on to get them wrong. In fiction, there are so many variables - casting, direction, the mysterious matter of which characters win public affection - that it's alarmingly easy to spend £6m on a series nobody watches. That's why head of drama is television's soccer-manager job.

But Border Cafe (Sunday, 9.20pm, BBC1) has the feel of a justified gamble: a good day in the casino of popular taste. Written by Tim Firth (Preston Front, Neville's Island) and set in a cafe, the series is triggered by a genuinely original dramatic situation. Cafe owner Charlotte (Elizabeth Carling) is the former lead singer of hit rock band True North. She's stalked by Ronnie (Georgia McKenzie) who played her in tribute band Untrue North and lost her career when Charlotte left the band. Charlotte offers her a job at the cafe.

The wit of this odd symbiotic relationship is matched by the quirkiness of Firth's writing. A young woman who makes fun of Yoko Ono's silly glasses suddenly pauses and adds that she wouldn't of course say that if there was anything wrong with her eyes. BBC1, though, has seen straight in commissioning Border Cafe, which is in a tradition of northern comedy (Bennett, Wood, Rosenthal) but also brings its own spices to the menu, both verbally and visually.

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: This Wednesday, at Lancaster House in London, there will be one of those very outward displays of the so-called special relationship. Some 250 British and American financiers and entrepreneurs - such as Frank Zarb, chairman of the Nasdaq stock market, and Sir Martin Sorrell, boss of advertising giant WPP - will line up to hear from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, and the US ambassador, Philip Lader, just how well things are going.
fields.body:
This Wednesday, at Lancaster House in London, there will be one of those very outward displays of the so-called special relationship. Some 250 British and American financiers and entrepreneurs - such as Frank Zarb, chairman of the Nasdaq stock market, and Sir Martin Sorrell, boss of advertising giant WPP - will line up to hear from the chancellor, Gordon Brown, the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, and the US ambassador, Philip Lader, just how well things are going.

The evidence will be there in the statistics. Figures to be published on the day by the Department of Trade's Invest in Britain bureau will show that, despite the strength of sterling and the screams of pain from Britain's manufacturing heartlands, inward investment in the UK is booming.

The figures released this time last year looked exceptional. A record 650 inward investment projects were recorded, creating or safeguarding almost 120,000 jobs.

During 1998, Britain attracted some £38bn from foreign investors - worth more than a quarter of all foreign direct investment inflows into the EU and some 13% of total world inflows.

But this time around the numbers will be even bigger and they will come with a special, welcome twist: more than a quarter of all new projects will have come from the technology, media and telecoms sectors, indicating that US companies in particular view Britain as Europe's digital nerve centre in the new knowledge-based economy.

But whatever the raw figures shout in terms of how the British economy is coping outside euroland, there will be clear reasons for caution.

Whether they come from Japan, the far east, or across the Atlantic, inward investment decisions, due to their tendency to be heavily capital-intensive in nature, tend to be made on long-time horizons. Many of today's projects have been years in the making and a good proportion predate Labour's election victory.

What is more, in the case of US investors at least, economists generally agree that Britain's competitive advantage is being steadily eroded, if only for the simple reason that American firms are becoming much more confident in dealing with continental business partners directly.

The warning to Mr Byers from Andrew Fraser, chief executive of the bureau and one of the DTI's most senior civil servants, was written in early May, when sterling was at a historic high against the euro and the debate was raging over the effect on British exports. Since then, an interest rate hike by the European Central Bank has led to a weakening of sterling against the euro.

But Mr Fraser's own concerns are long term and structural in nature - focusing on the growth of central and east European competition, for example, where labour costs are cheaper. Fraser, who was appointed chief executive of the Invest in Britain bureau by the last Conservative government in 1994, travels constantly drumming up investors and has an ideal vantage point from which to relay to ministers the mood in the international investment community.

By way of illustration of what he describes as "unendurable pain" in the manufacturing community faced by the exchange rate, he points out that Philips employs over 15,000 in central Europe and recently closed a Scottish facility to shift production of lightbulbs to Hungary.

His particular worry is that while plant closures in the automotive and textiles sectors have drawn the headlines, the real threat is in areas such as consumer electronics, where technologies are changing rapidly and investors, such as the Japanese, are having to make quick decisions about re-equipping manufacturing facilities.

For the Japanese, the situation is particularly acute due to economic conditions at home, where the economy refuses to reinflate. Their corporations here can no longer tolerate continuing losses.

At the same time, rows over moves in the budget to reform taxation of multinationals, leading to claims that some big firms based in the UK were being taxed twice on corporate profits, have highlighted a sense that Britain's standing in the world of global business is slipping away.

The Lancaster House conference is entitled "enterprise and technology for all: seizing the opportunity". Clearly, there is a worry in Whitehall that Britain is in real danger of losing what it already has.

fields.headline: Looking at power
fields.standfirst:
The Greens are becoming important both here in Europe and in the US. But power is not good for them, alas
The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: This is a tale of two parties. The first is the Green party in America, which has just selected consumer-rights advocate and maverick, Ralph Nader as its presidential candidate. Nader's support currently stands at 7% in the polls.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two parties. The first is the Green party in America, which has just selected consumer-rights advocate and maverick, Ralph Nader as its presidential candidate. Nader's support currently stands at 7% in the polls. That is not enough for Nader to make it into presidential debates, but more than enough for him to make a crucial difference between Democrat Al Gore and Republican George W Bush, who are running neck and neck.

The second is the Green party in Germany, which has just emerged from a divisive row at its congress over nuclear power. The government, in which it is a junior partner, had just reached a deal with the nuclear industry to phase out nuclear energy and shut down power stations, within 32 years. One of the party's co-leaders said she would resign if congress backed the deal; another said the coalition would collapse if he didn't. The congress supported it. The row continues. Meanwhile the party, which has seen its vote decline in the last 14 federal, state and European elections, is haemorrhaging support.

The first has no chance of power and is rising in popularity; the second is in power and finding its popularity dwindling. More intriguingly, those two conditions may well be interrelated. Limited evidence seems to suggest that there is an inverse relationship between a Green party's proximity to power and the number of people who want to back it. In other words the more it looks as though they actually might play a significant role in running a country, the less of a role people want them to play.

It is not a new dilemma. It has been an issue ever since the magical moment in 1983 when the German Greens wandered into the Bundestag wearing jeans and carrying potted plants. To what extent could they influence the political establishment and to what extent would the political establishment influence them? On the night of their election the late Petra Kelly, one of the key figures in the party during the 70s and 80s said: "Parliament is like the marketplace for us, or the building site, where we can spread the information. Parliament is not our goal, only part of our strategy." On hearing this, one of her colleagues grumbled that if she carried on talking like that: "We will slide into a minority sect faster than we can talk about it."

You can see the argument played out in Joschka Fischer's wardrobe. When he took the oath as the environment minister of Hesse in 1985 he did so in jeans and trainers. Now he is the German for eign minister and wears three-piece suits. Superficial? It would be if his politics had not changed just as dramatically. Fifteen years ago he was an opponent of Nato; last year he supported the bombing of Serbia.

This tension has always been depicted as a straightforward split between two factions - the "realos" and the "fundis". Realos believed that if you were going to stand in elections then you had to make some concessions to electoralism and if you wanted to work in coalitions you would have to compromise. The fundis declared that the very reason why they received their support was because they did not operate or look like other parties. As with most political constructs - old and New Labour, wet and dry Tories, modernisers and traditionalists - the putative split between realos and fundis was hopelessly simplistic and crude. However, it also had some basis in reality. The Greens have had to decide whether they can balance being a party of protest and a party of power and if so, at what price.

Nor is it a dilemma particular to the Greens. These calculations underpin the nature of all electoral politics. "What do we want to give up if we want to get in?" are the staple issues that have informed Labour's transformation over the past 15 years. Only when the Tories start asking themselves the same questions might they have a chance of being re-elected.

The answers necessarily change with the circumstances. Where the Greens are concerned, the circumstances at present are crucial. Greens have taken up positions in five European governments - France, Germany, the Netherlands, Italy and Finland. They also support center-left administrations in Sweden and New Zealand. And they have recently made a strong showing in Britain too. Thanks to the introduction of proportional representation they now have two MEPs, three GLA members and an MSP. The row between realos and fundis is no longer the stuff of internal bickering but the life and death of governments.

By any standards this is an impressive achievement. All the more so when one considers that, unlike other parties, the Greens have no rigid socio-economic base on which to rely. The American Greens may be strongest among the alternative lifestyles of California. But it is run from the offices of the local steelworkers union in rundown Gary, Indiana, and the Texas branch was founded in the headquarters of the American TUC. To not only create but cement an electorally viable political tradition, drawn from a mixture of the young, pacifists, trade unionists and environmentalists, in less than 20 years, is no mean feat. Keeping it together in government will be just as tough.

Key to its success will be the Greens' relationship both with the rest of the left and with its own activists. Nader, for example, is already being accused of drawing crucial support from Gore that might let Bush in through the back door. He rightly responds that the choice between Gore and Bush is scarcely a choice at all. Both are "drab and dreary" and reflect the interests of corporate America. If Gore wants his votes then he will have to shift to the left to get them, just as he has been shifting to the right to scoop up disenchanted Republicans.

The Greens in Germany have also made a difference. The agreement on nuclear power and the granting of citizenship rights for foreigners born in Germany have been major achievements which would not have happened without them. But they have paid heavily for their support and have been hopelessly compromised by Fischer's support for the war. While Nader may not wish to follow the German Greens, the German Greens, and their European and Antipodean allies, could do worse than learn some things from. He gained his bargaining position partly through his work in the anti-capitalist demonstrations in Seattle and Washington and joint campaigns with unions. He is the candidate for a party, but he is also part of a movement. His relative electoral strength is not an end in itself, but an illustration of his influence outside of the mainstream. The stronger he is from the outside, the more clout he will have on the inside.

Greens are right to take positions in government, but not at any price. Unlike their social democratic coalition partners, they are more than simply electoral machines. Taking up ministerial positions demands that they deepen, not weaken, their links with the wider movements. If the price for doing so is too high, they should forgo the opportunity and wait until the orthodox left has raised its game. It is possible to have power without office.

gary.younge@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Blair's plans on the spot
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's comments about city-centre rowdiness come not a moment too soon (Blair wants on-the-spot fines for louts, July 1). The mayhem caused by the English during Euro 2000 is a direct consequence of our tolerance of what takes place in city and town centres the length and breadth of the country every weekend.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's comments about city-centre rowdiness come not a moment too soon (Blair wants on-the-spot fines for louts, July 1). The mayhem caused by the English during Euro 2000 is a direct consequence of our tolerance of what takes place in city and town centres the length and breadth of the country every weekend.

For successive generations of English youth, the Big Friday/Saturday Night Out Experience has become such an institution that one would now be hard-pressed to find a town of any size anywhere in the country that is not set aside on Friday and Saturday nights for the exploits of pub-crawling binge-drinkers, hunting in single-sex packs whose members can be aged anything from mid-teens to mid-40s.

For many Brits, the whole point of being on holiday, or abroad, is that one can enjoy every night as if it were Friday or Saturday night.
Danny Gleisner
Leeds danny@dgleisner.fsnet.co.uk

 I wouldn't like to be using a cashpoint late at night when a drunken, violent, yob is dragged there by a copper exacting an "on-the-spot" fine. It's scary enough as it is.
Daphne Romney
London didi@weststand.demon.co.uk

 When on-the-spot fines spawn numerous fake police officers accusing innocent people of being drunk, noisy or loutish, then frogmarching them to a cash machine to hand over £100, will the real old bill have to guard hole-in-the-wall machines?
Max Hess
Folkestone, Kent max@truesocialism.freeserve.co.uk

 The quickest possible way to corrupt a police force is to give it the right to levy substantial spot fines. Certain officers will find it simpler and pleasanter to accept a smaller sum without the need to fill out forms and issue receipts.
Francis King
Norfolk

 Simon Hoggart's fascination with the number of men having criminal records could start a whole new sport (Simon Hoggart's diary, July 1). A few months ago we had a brief spate of politicians confessing to having smoked cannabis as students. Perhaps Simon could find out how many male MPs have criminal records.
Geraldine Curtis
London geraldine@brixton.new.labour.org.uk

 I cannot accept Quentin Poulsen's view that America is less violent than Britain (Letters, July 1). Of course there are areas of America where violence is minimal, but the same is true here. At at least in Britain we do not have (or at least have not yet had) schoolchildren killing other schoolchildren with firearms. Perhaps it will come as Britain assimilates more and more socio-economic policies which derive from the United States.

Mr Poulsen is right however when he describes the moronic and boorish behaviour which is now the common currency in Britain. How sad to see the way we are now perceived by the rest of the world.
Chris Waller
Bristol chriswaller21@yahoo.co.uk

 So Quentin Poulsen thinks we English are small-minded and spiteful? He says that we regard doing something that "annoys the hell" out of someone we have never met to be an achievement. Well, Quentin, you've just "achieved" with me. As I don't believe that living here is mandatory, I can only say "missing you already".
Robin Muskett
Peterborough Alpha1@droom.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Bigotry is everywhere
fields.trailText: The media coverage of David Copeland has wrongly focused on his personality defects, ignoring the central issue that his bombings were not isolated incidents, but an extreme manifestation of widespread bigotry (Bomber gets six life terms, July 1).
fields.body:
The media coverage of David Copeland has wrongly focused on his personality defects, ignoring the central issue that his bombings were not isolated incidents, but an extreme manifestation of widespread bigotry (Bomber gets six life terms, July 1).

There is an ongoing oppression of black and gay people ranging from violence to legislative inequalities to verbal abuse and to silent prejudice. There has been no coverage of the impact his attacks had on the black, Asian and gay communities across the country or how members of the far right such as him feed off mainstream politicians' policies on asylum seekers and section 28. Instead he has been confined to the fringes of society (he's not "one of us") and been adorned with the notoriety and attention he so desperately sought.
Yasmin Khan
Birmingham

 First Kenneth Noye and now David Copeland. Why do you turn convicted criminals into celebrities by devoting the best part of the front page of your paper to their photographs?
Gavin Clements
Malvern, Worcs

webTitle: A concrete solution to a bridging problem

fields.headline: A concrete solution to a bridging problem
fields.trailText: At Waterloo it was once the norm to play military music to coerce commuters to march together in "common time" in order to move about the station more efficiently. The opposite principle could be applied to break the step of commuters en route from the north bank of the Thames to the Tate Modern via the resonant Millennium Bridge (Designers back in step over bouncing bridge, June 29).
fields.body:
At Waterloo it was once the norm to play military music to coerce commuters to march together in "common time" in order to move about the station more efficiently. The opposite principle could be applied to break the step of commuters en route from the north bank of the Thames to the Tate Modern via the resonant Millennium Bridge (Designers back in step over bouncing bridge, June 29).

Rather than deploy mechanical dampers at a cost of thousands, loud-hailers could be strategically positioned to play arhythmic compositions from our most trying contemporary composers. The best composer I can think of who would be conducive to inducing the "right kind of walk" would be George Ligeti, who is an example of a particularly arhythmic and atonal 20th-century musical genre called, most appropriately, Musique Concrete. Ligeti, if anyone, could break the step of any number of eager users of the bridge, and make it into the engineering success which it undoubtedly deserves to be.
Alan Hancock
Richmond, Surrey alanh@zoo.co.uk

 The designers of the Millennium Bridge clearly failed to use the correct reference material. While available engineering data and standards did not foresee the effects of synchronised walking on the bridge, the readily available work Pup on a Picnic by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera, featuring Tom and Jerry, clearly shows the alarming bouncing movement caused by the synchronised marching of a column of ants on just about anything they come into contact with.
Will Townsend
Melksham, Wilts TownsendW@aol.com

 What I marvel at is Lord Foster adducing "ambition" as an acceptable excuse. The core design criterion of civil engineering is functionality. Aesthetics can be an important consideration, but if a structure is not functional, then it is not engineering, it is a folly, perhaps art. In civil engineering, a major component of functionality is safety: civil structures are meant to be used by large numbers of people, with near-perfect safety.

This is a good perspective for considering Foster's statement "Can you ever be over- ambitious? I would rather be accused of being over-ambitious than of being lily-livered". I wonder how happily Lord Foster would accept a flight on a new airplane which its chief designer told him was extremely elegant, but "we're not really sure of the effects of our ambitious structural design".
Cole Coleman
London

 I recall from my school days that everything has a "natural frequency" and objects which oscillate at their natural frequency eventually break. I can't understand why the engineers didn't consider this at an earlier stage. Was it a case of we'll cross that bridge when we come to it?
Patrick McNamee
London

Ligeti, if anyone, could break the step of any number of eager users of the bridge, and make it into the engineering success which it undoubtedly deserves to be. Alan Hancock Richmond, Surrey alanh@zoo.co.uk  The designers of the Millennium Bridge clearly failed to use the correct reference material. While available engineering data and standards did not foresee the effects of synchronised walking on the bridge, the readily available work Pup on a Picnic by William Hanna and Joseph Barbera, featuring Tom and Jerry, clearly shows the alarming bouncing movement caused by the synchronised marching of a column of ants on just about anything they come into contact with. Will Townsend Melksham, Wilts TownsendW@aol.com  What I marvel at is Lord Foster adducing "ambition" as an acceptable excuse. The core design criterion of civil engineering is functionality. Aesthetics can be an important consideration, but if a structure is not functional, then it is not engineering, it is a folly, perhaps art. In civil engineering, a major component of functionality is safety: civil structures are meant to be used by large numbers of people, with near-perfect safety. This is a good perspective for considering Foster's statement "Can you ever be over- ambitious? I would rather be accused of being over-ambitious than of being lily-livered". I wonder how happily Lord Foster would accept a flight on a new airplane which its chief designer told him was extremely elegant, but "we're not really sure of the effects of our ambitious structural design". Cole Coleman London  I recall from my school days that everything has a "natural frequency" and objects which oscillate at their natural frequency eventually break. I can't understand why the engineers didn't consider this at an earlier stage. Was it a case of we'll cross that bridge when we come to it? Patrick McNamee London

fields.headline: Poll watch
fields.trailText: Jonathan Steele (Campaign corruption, June 29) ignores two crucial aspects of foreign observers at elections; that their presence can lead to the greater safety of the electorate and that they can expose regimes by alerting the interest of the foreign media.
fields.body:
Jonathan Steele (Campaign corruption, June 29) ignores two crucial aspects of foreign observers at elections; that their presence can lead to the greater safety of the electorate and that they can expose regimes by alerting the interest of the foreign media.

I was responsible for an East Timorese observer programme last August, which took place in a context of violence and intimidation. The mere presence of foreign observers gave the local population the confidence to turn out and vote. The role of Indonesian observers was crucial as they were quickly able to identify the abuses perpetrated by the Indonesian army and alert the international community.

The involvement of international observers heightened media interest and therefore exposed a military strategy which was desperate to influence the outcome through intimidation and coercion.
Catherine Scott
Asia policy officer, Catholic Institute for International Relations

webTitle: A bid to bounce Mr Blair

fields.headline: A bid to bounce Mr Blair
fields.standfirst: There are other ways of taming the pound
fields.trailText: Andrew Fraser is a senior civil servant in the Department of Trade and Industry, and chief executive of its Invest in Britain bureau. As such he has a special duty of care for British manufacturing industry, and when he concludes, as he does in the memorandum to his political boss, Stephen Byers, which we disclose today, that the strength of the pound against the euro is "deeply dangerous", he deserves to be listened to.
fields.body:
Andrew Fraser is a senior civil servant in the Department of Trade and Industry, and chief executive of its Invest in Britain bureau. As such he has a special duty of care for British manufacturing industry, and when he concludes, as he does in the memorandum to his political boss, Stephen Byers, which we disclose today, that the strength of the pound against the euro is "deeply dangerous", he deserves to be listened to. What he says makes a healthy change from the complacency with which the government has treated this issue while jobs have been savaged and whole industries put at risk - a complacency which has repeatedly been condemned in these columns. The prime minister and the chancellor may try to dismiss the ravages of the high pound as unfortunate but unavoidable, but Mr Fraser knows better. If we go on as we are, he says, we face a "meltdown" of major manufacturing sectors, and a loss of major inward investors - his special reponsibility.

So far, so persuasive. But the fact that Mr Fraser's concerns now have a far wider audience than he may have expected reflects a second dimension to what he is saying. His recommended solutions - take on the Eurosceptics; declare that getting into the euro is "indispensable" to securing Britain's manufacturing base - are a powerful boost for the case being made by those cabinet ministers, of whom Mr Byers is one, who despair of the Treasury's caution on Britain's prospects within the euro zone, and want Mr Blair to listen far less to the doubts of Gordon Brown.

In that context it is worth repeating here a warning given in our financial notebook on Saturday: "The strength of the pound against the euro and the debate over whether or not Britain should sign up for the single currency are not the same thing. Entwined, perhaps inex tricably, they may be. Identical they are not _ Signing up for the euro is not the only solution to the strength of the pound." To suggest that an instant commitment to getting us into the euro is the single effective answer is one-club economics. It sweeps aside such necessary considerations as the rate at which we would go in - a condition so catastrophically overlooked when Margaret Thatcher took Britain into the ERM. It also underrates the political implications. Labour is committed to a referendum on entry, and to win that means engineering a radical reversal of the present mood of the country, where doubts about the euro are growing - not only among those with a sentimental attachment to saving the pound, but among all those who see the euro as the engine of a wider integration which might take decision-making further and further away from them. Such people cannot simply be steamrollered into acceptance.

So while Mr Fraser's warnings need to be heeded, the moral which some will be keen to draw from them should not be swallowed whole. They are not only part of the story - an ingredient in a civil servant's agenda which also demands a generally more industry-friendly government than we have now; even to the point of complaining that the National Institute for Clinical Excellence "continues to arouse the suspicions of all of our pharmaceutical investors". Heed the substance, yes; but suspect the spin. You don't need to be Ken Follett, whose rebukes to Tony Blair have been so ludicrously overplayed this weekend, to be on the watch for manipulation. It is clearly going on here. The government should be awake to the dangers which Mr Fraser charts. But as one cabinet minister sensibly said in a TV interview yesterday, it should not be bounced. And that, by the way, was Stephen Byers.

fields.headline: Follett's folly
fields.trailText:
The bilious attack by Ken Follett on Tony Blair is just one more nail in the coffin of Labour hopes and aspirations by their own supposed supporters. It was always the inclination of leftwingers to tear their party apart whenever they judged it to be found wanting. But it will not be the Folletts of this world who will suffer when they have eased the Tories back into power to continue their policy of transferring assets from the poor to the rich. It will be the ordinary people and pensioners such as myself.
David Smith
Boston, Lincs
smith.boston@btinternet.com

Boston, Lincs smith.boston@btinternet.com

 What hopeful signs may we detect from the frenzied flutter in New Labour's dovecote resulting from Ken Follett's modest caution? It strongly suggests that despite the immense and loathsome professionalism of the art of spinning, we do not, after all, mistake image for reality, nor shadow for substance. There must always be an aspect of aspiration, vision, and promise in politics, but there must be real ideas and genuine practicalities. The sooner Labour reverts to putting ideas into practice the better for us all.
Robert Giddings
Poole robert@parkstonepoole.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: Rewriting the book trade
fields.trailText: Waterstone's sacking of Robert Topping, manager of its Manchester Deansgate store, is symptomatic of crisis in the book trade, but this crisis is not new (Manager in the frame as book trade hits crisis, July 1). My own period in book-trade management in the 70s and 80s coincided with a period of almost perpetual crisis. As the chain stores became ever bigger and competed for market share, many towns and cities saw fine smaller and independent stores close in their dozens. An entire layer of diversity was stripped out of the marketplace.
fields.body:
Waterstone's sacking of Robert Topping, manager of its Manchester Deansgate store, is symptomatic of crisis in the book trade, but this crisis is not new (Manager in the frame as book trade hits crisis, July 1). My own period in book-trade management in the 70s and 80s coincided with a period of almost perpetual crisis. As the chain stores became ever bigger and competed for market share, many towns and cities saw fine smaller and independent stores close in their dozens. An entire layer of diversity was stripped out of the marketplace.

The group I worked for sought to instigate charges for window displays, reduce the range and quantities of new titles purchased, focus sales on a more profitable range of bestsellers and reduce its overall stockholding. None of this is new - and economically, there is a kind of irresistible logic to such a strategy, especially in an environment where the volume of books published continues to spiral, margins are constantly eroded and overheads soar.

The disturbing thing about this constant crisis is that the book trade has learnt so little from it. Bookstores continue to seek out ever more costly locations and premises, and many now occupy sites which generate such massive overheads that one must question whether their kind of bookselling can ever be profitable.

Within the next few years three things will happen: First, the pendulum will swing back towards more modest small and medium stores, where customer service, stock knowledge and bookselling skills are at a premium. Second, the media and entertainment industries which permeate bookselling and publishing will recognise that the kind of profit margins they seek can rarely be generated by books and never sustained. They will almost certainly pull out of books. This will be a good thing. Third, the publishing industry will find it must publish less, and less wastefully.
Alun Severn
Oldbury, W Midlands alun@ukiah.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Beware judges in pyjamas
fields.standfirst: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.trailText: Marcel Berlins: Writ large
fields.body:
They're called pyjama injunctions because, according to folklore, they're granted by High Court judges who, due to the lateness of the hour, are already in kipping gear. In fact, I know of only a few judges woken up to make such court orders; one, I remember, was described as wearing beige jammies, which should have disqualified him from being a judge in the first place. Anyway, the point is that on weekends and late at night, when the High Court isn't sitting, there is always a judge on duty, on a rota basis, to deal with legal emergencies, which very often consist of people trying to stop a newspaper from publishing something.

Last weekend, Lord Levy failed to get a judge - not as it happens, in pyjamas, but fully clothed at the end of a phone - to ban the Sunday Times from revealing his low-tax affairs. The reason Mr Justice Toulson allowed publication was because he knew his stuff; he was an expert in the relevant field of law. But most weekend judges are not, and this has led to some curious and wrong decisions, such as that of the judge who, at Jack Straw's request, granted an injunction stopping the Sunday Telegraph from publishing leaked bits of the Stephen Lawrence inquiry four days prematurely.

The fact is that judges who don't know their media law are usually too scared to give the go-ahead to publish. Caution and ignorance tells them to stop the publication. But it's pure chance whether the duty judge you get, however dressed, knows a lot or very little. Is it not time to make sure that the judges on emergency call have some experience in the subjects they're likely to be asked to decide?

* lt pains me greatly to give publicity to a certain football team, but I have a duty to extend your appreciation of our modern ultra-cool judiciary. Below left, is a picture of a High Court judge. His name is Sir Robin Jacob. He is modelling the new, sponsored, specially designed summer judicial uniform. No, he's not, he's wearing an Arsenal shirt. For those looking at the pic in black and white, it's red.

The Lawyer magazine has published the names of 61 solicitors who, it says, earn more than £1m a year. I do not believe that the 61 gave the mag their tax returns. The list is largely an extrapolation of individual earnings from the published accounts of the big City firms.

It's a valid exercise because the figures show profits per partner at various levels of seniority, and how many partners are in each band. But the results look bizarre. Of the million-earners, 43 are from one firm - Slaughter and May; another 16 from Allen & Overy. None are with Britain and Europe's biggest firm, Clifford Chance, whose top partners trouser a mere £800,000 annually. The explanation for S & M's predominance, I learn, is that the firm concentrates "on premium billing, rather than volume service". I must try it myself sometime. The barristers' list of 15 £1m-earners is far more open to question, although I wouldn't be too surprised if the toppest silk, Lord Grabiner QC, did indeed earn close to £2m. But I doubt that the libel king, George Carman QC, is a million man; it's not that he's not good enough but the kind of work he does isn't among the highest paying.

*In my years as a journalist I've been invited to many hundreds, perhaps thousands, of lunches. I have eaten well, and I have eaten badly, but at least I have eaten. This week, for the first time, I was asked to attend a lunch with a particular twist: "No lunch will be provided." It's all part of the American Bar Association's conference in London in a couple of weeks. The lunch in question will be graced by Robin Cook and Madeleine Albright,the US secretary of state. They will eat. So what will be the role of the non-lunch journos? Ah, here it is. "NB. Observer Status Only." So now it's clear. I've been asked along to watch lots of other people scoffing. On reflection, I think I'll decline.

webTitle: Is it safe to speak out?

fields.headline: Is it safe to speak out?
fields.standfirst: It's a year since new legislation was passed to protect whistleblowers at work.  Sally Weale  asks if it's working
fields.trailText: It's a year since new legislation was passed to protect whistleblowers at work.  Sally Weale  asks if it's working
fields.body:
There are a lot of nursing homes around Blackpool. It's the sort of place many elderly people imagine spending their last days - in a pleasant home, not far from the sea, with all those hazy memories of summer holidays. But not all these places offer the sort of care for their elderly residents that we might expect.

In those where there is neglect and abuse, there are probably staff who don't like what they see. They are reluctant to speak out. They are frightened for their jobs. It is easier to stay silent or quietly leave.

Bryan Bladon did neither. He blew the whistle and, like many before him, was sacked. But unlike his predecessors, Bladon had the law on his side - a new law that protects whistleblowers against sacking or other forms of victimisation.

The Public Interest Disclosure Act, described by campaigners in the US as the most far-reaching whistleblower law in the world, is a year old this week. Last month Bladon, a 51-year-old nurse, became the first known whistleblower to receive compensation as a result of the legislation, after taking his former employer to an employment tribunal. He was awarded £23,000 and hopes his experience will encourage others to expose bad practice - not only in nursing homes, which is Bladon's personal interest, but elsewhere too.

Since the act came into force on July 2 last year, three cases are known to have been ruled on by a tribunal. In each, the so-called whistleblower has won the claim - compensation payouts on the other two claims are yet to be finalised. In total, 200 claims have been brought in the past year, yet campaigners say that unless government, businesses and union leaders embark on a major awareness campaign, the act will remain largely unheeded, particularly in the private sector.

As a result, disasters such as the sinking of the Herald of Free Enterprise and the baby deaths at Bristol Royal Infirmary, which might have been prevented had employees been able to voice concerns without fear of persecution, could go on happening in a culture that remains one of inertia, cover-up and secrecy.

So what does it take to become a whistleblower? Bladon had been working as a charge nurse at an old people's home outside Blackpool for almost three months when he became concerned about the way some residents were being treated. Bladon told his immediate manager - verbally first, then in a written account. He assumed it would be passed on to the home's proprietor, ALM Medical Services, but he heard nothing. He left it for nine days, but when he witnessed further incidents, he contacted the social services inspectorate and the home was raided last September. When he next turned up for work, Bladon received a frosty reception from colleagues.

The inspectors sent a directive to the home's proprietor, ordering an investigation into Bladon's concerns. Bladon was summoned to a disciplinary hearing and, on September 16 last year, was dismissed. With the backing of his union, Unison, Bladon took the home's owner to an employment tribunal which found decisively in his favour - a triumph for whistleblowers, but at high personal cost.

Among the other successful cases is that of Antonio Fernandes, found to have been unfairly dismissed by Netcom Consultants, a Reading-based telecommunications company, after he blew the whistle on a boss who allegedly asked him to sign off bogus expenses amounting to £370,000.

Age is against him and he thinks potential employers may be apprehensive and see him as a troublemaker. But faced with the same circumstances he would do the same again. He did not do it for himself, he says, but because he cared for the company.

"It's a long process. It leaves you out in the cold. You feel victimised and you lose confidence. All I did was follow my conscience. You have to do what you essentially believe is right."

The third known case is that of Kostana Azmi who was found to have been unfairly dismissed after she raised concerns about the governance of the Orbis charitable trust for which she worked.

There may be other resolved cases, details of which have not yet been made public. The government, it seems, would like to keep it that way. In April, Public Concern at Work, the charity that advises whistleblowers and campaigned so effectively for the legislation, won a High Court ruling that opened up the details of pending tribunal claims to public scrutiny. The government is appealing. Public Concern, which receives 800 inquiries a year on its helpline, is aware of a number of other cases in the pipeline including alleged misuse of a lottery grant and suspect research which may have been relied upon for formulating public policy.

Guy Dehn, Public Concern's director, said he was delighted that the first three tribunals were successful. "It's early days but it seems to be working well in practice. Even so, a third of NHS trusts still have no whistleblower policy.

"When cases start coming through and we get more publicity and high awards, awareness will increase, but it will be a long process. That's regrettable. Because a lot of people don't know they've got the protection."

While it is largely unheard of in this country, the legislation has attracted much interest overseas. The South Africans have adopted similar legislation, Germany has produced a draft bill, the US is interested in the UK approach and the OECD has brought out a paper praising the act.

"It ought to be promoted more widely by government, unions and business," says Dehn. "If this legislation was well-promoted it would have a broad effect on the conduct of organisations in two to three years. If it is not promoted, we are probably looking at 15 years. But it will work," he insists. "My concern is that if it's going to take 15 years to sink in, one could have some serious incidents which might have been prevented if people had known about the act."

According to Dehn, whistleblowing still has negative connotations for many, whatever protection the law might offer. It is still associated with people fighting personal battles, making anonymous leaks to newspapers. It smacks of betraying colleagues, letting the side down and people are afraid it results in victimisation and loss of employment.

Stephen Bolsin, the anaesthetist who spent five years trying to alert the authorities to unsatisfactory standards of paediatric heart surgery at the Bristol Royal Infirmary, last year welcomed the Public Interest Disclosure Act, but he highlighted the difficulty of changing a deeply entrenched culture.

According to Public Concern, the act's success should not be measured by the number of cases that come to tribunal - the legislation is struc tured to encourage employers to deal with whistleblowers' concerns rather than face the bad publicity of a possible employment tribunal and a hefty compensation award. Employers will continue to ride roughshod over legitimately raised concerns; employees witnessing corruption, wrongdoing and dangerous practice will stay silent and people may be hurt, or even lose their lives in tragedies that could have been avoided had the whistle been blown.
