fields.headline: Nostalgics of the world unite
fields.standfirst: Moscow, the city that dreamed of leading the world into a bright new future, is now more interested in rebuilding the past.  Jonathan Glancey reports
fields.trailText: Moscow, the city that dreamed of leading the world into a bright new future, is now more interested in rebuilding the past. Jonathan Glancey reports
fields.body:
Constructivism was a style and a way of thinking pursued by a number of radical architects just after Russia's October Revolution. It proved to be one of the most influential approaches to modern architecture. This abstract, geometric architecture, free of bourgeois, aristocratic and Tsarist traits, symbolised the hopes of those artists who truly believed that the workers' paradise was little more than a Five-Year Plan or a New Economic Policy away.

The movement is physically best summed up by Ilya Golosov's Zuyev Club, still standing a little worse for wear on Moscow's Lesnaya Ulitsa. Built in 1929, not long before Stalin stamped down on Modern movement design, this workers' club is a memorable essay in the art of handling Platonic forms: a glass cylinder on the street corner containing the main stair intersects cubes and rectangles. There is no decoration. Eight hundred years of pre-revolutionary Russian history has been discarded. Architects from across Europe came to look and to borrow the stark yet powerful visual vocabulary of the constructivists, and they're still doing so today. One has only to look at the striking geometry of designs by Zaha Hadid and Daniel Libeskind to see how the Russian constructivists are still affecting the course of modern architecture.

But not in Russia itself - far from it. The latest style in Moscow is what might be called reconstructivism. Wherever a historic building once stood but was destroyed, a more or less exact replacement now seems to be called for. Although not official policy, this growing attempt to re-create pre-revolutionary, pre-Stalin Moscow is largely driven by the office of the capital's mayor, Yuri Luzhkov. So much so that Luzhkov, with his equal enthusiasm for flash-trash postmodern public art and shopping malls, has been nicknamed the "great architect of capitalism". Stalin was, of course, the "great architect of socialism", although this referred to his construction of the Soviet state and empire rather than his love of histrionic skyscrapers, bombastic hotels and eye-boggling apartment blocks.

The triumphal symbol of Luzhkov's reconstructivism is without doubt the vast and vulgar Church of Christ the Saviour, completed between 1997 and last year at the cost of something like £240m. This hulking pile of domed white marble is a re-creation of the ugly church that Tsar Alexander I commissioned in celebration of Napoleon's retreat from the gates of Moscow in 1812. It took 45 years to build, but Stalin destroyed it in a day. That was in 1931; the site was to be used for the long-discussed Palace of the Soviets. The winning design was to be topped with a 300ft statue of Lenin that would bring the total height to about 1,000ft. It never materialised, because of a lack of funds and Hitler's Operation Barbarossa, which saw Nazi troops at the gates of Moscow at blitzkrieg speed.

The abandoned site went on to house one of the largest swimming pools behind the Iron Curtain, and now the Church of Christ the Saviour. Ugly it may be, yet the church - or the church that was - has long been a part of Moscow folk memory. This is where many couples courted, canoodling on benches set around this enormous sacred snub to Napoleon. Now it snubs communism, even though hardened old ladies still walk here holding aloft portraits of the great architect of socialism, praying that the bad old days will come back as surely as the Church of Christ the Saviour has.

The mayor's instincts are probably right as far as popular sentiment goes. In any case, Moscow is a huge city and the reconstruction of a few historic monuments is surely not a sign that the buzzing Russian capital is suffering from a debilitating case of cultural regression. Still, any city has to ask itself why it feels the need to rebuild the past, especially when that past was darker and more dismal than the present.

Step into Red Square today and you pass through the Resurrection Gate. This colourful confection may look like a page of picture-book 17th-century Russian architecture but it is in fact a reconstruction of the chocolate-box gateway that Stalin had demolished, again in 1931. Removing the gateway enabled waves of high-kicking troops, together with tanks and artillery, and later rocket and missile launchers, to parade unhindered through the city and across Red Square, where Soviet leaders would take the salute from Lenin's tomb, a grim interlocking of less than lovely geometric forms designed by Aleksei Shchusev, one of Stalin's pet architects. Now the reconstructed gates help to protect the Kremlin from criminal elements who might have less ceremonial uses in mind for their military hardware.

Pass through the gateway with today's army of garishly dressed tourists snapping away at any building with an onion dome, and here's another reconstruction, this time the blancmange-like Kazan Cathedral. This sweet conceit is a reproduction of the early 17th-century church demolished on the orders of you-know-who in 1936. Consecrated in 1637, the original cathedral was built to house the icon of the Kazan Virgin. She has since emigrated to St Petersburg and a reproduction went on show when the reconstructed cathedral was consecrated in 1993. Luzhkov and Boris Yeltsin, then president of Russia, were among the congregation.

In a way this reconstruction has been a success. Where once there were long queues of Soviet citizens waiting to file past Lenin's cadaver on the other side of Red Square, today the first Soviet leader's mausoleum is largely a plaything for tourists, while local women and children crowd into the little new cathedral to light tapers and kiss freshly painted icons. Communism may have given way to criminally driven capitalism in Moscow, yet a much older religion represents the beliefs of Muscovites excluded from the loud and provocative world of the new rich.

However, once you add in the rash of postmodern office blocks, shopping malls, banks and other new capitalist junk, plus some of the most bizarre new public art to be found anywhere in the world, 21st-century Moscow is about as vulgar as architecture gets this side of Shanghai or Shenzen. The new look is both unrepentantly kitsch and a perfect match for the rampant capitalism and reinvigorated Orthodoxy that drive and underscore it.

Will things change? Not for a while - or only for the worse. Moscow has always been a showy city, its architecture loud and richly unclear. The oddities in its architectural history are purist buildings like Golosov's Zuyev Club, and not such hideous newcomers as the hugely popular Okhotny underground shopping mall. Foreign architects are not unwelcome here, but those who propose designs shot through with the spirit of the constructivists (very many architects worldwide) are considered to be too expensive to warrant serious attention. In any case they either can't or won't give post-revolutionary Moscow what it appears to want - commercial and religious kitsch and the history that Stalin stole away.

webTitle: Dear Wills, I'd hate to be you

fields.headline: Dear Wills, I'd hate to be you
fields.standfirst: Barry Hale is 18, just like Prince William. Barry comes from a Liverpool council estate but, he tells the prince, he doesn't envy him at all - except for the Britney Spears thing, of course
fields.trailText: Barry Hale is 18, just like Prince William. Barry comes from a Liverpool council estate but, he tells the prince, he doesn't envy him at all - except for the Britney Spears thing, of course
fields.body:
Dear William,

I am an average 18-year-old boy who has just finished A levels. I have also just finished making a documentary for the BBC about my opinions on your life and your family. We have very few things in common apart from our age and I am very relieved this is the case. You may well be extremely rich (by a normal 18-year-old's standards), you may be the most eligible bachelor in Britain, if not the world, and you may also be a close personal "friend" of Britney Spears, but I would never want to be in your position. (Except for the Britney Spears thing.)

The reason I wouldn't want to be you, and why I pity you, is that despite these things you are missing out on events that everyone should experience when they are young. You lack the basic thing that every other "normal" person of your age has: freedom. And the fact that you don't have this removes the chance you have for a life.

I sit in wonder at the state the monarchy is in today, and at the views of their supporters. In my opinion the royals have had their day and are useless in a modern society. If they don't change, then sooner or later they will be removed. The most popular reason for keeping the monarchy is that they bring money in through tourism. But for much of the time the Queen and her entourage are not even in the country, never mind in Buckingham Palace. Even when they are in their most famous abode, they hardly stroll out on to the balcony and salute the visitors. Tourists don't come to see your Gran, William, but rather her house, and traditions like the changing of the guard.

The next argument is that the Queen and her family are a good representation of Brits abroad. No! English people are seen as pompous, arrogant and obnoxious. These false assumptions are reinforced by the royals. Nobody is fooled by Prince Charles grinning at a party held in his honour in an African village. His eyes stare into space as if he is envisaging an extremely amusing polo match, or one of his pack of dogs chasing after a fox. The real representatives of our country should be the likes of Elton John and Richard Branson, or any of the people who were acknowledged at the bravery awards this spring: compassionate, hardworking, sincere people.

Another argument from royal supporters is that "Britain wouldn't be Britain without the monarchy". If this is the case we should turf them out now, because we could do with a change. Britain would lose the elitism which stems from and is legitimised by the royals. Everything this country does is constantly compared to past achievements. Our football matches are always preceded by shots of us winning the World Cup in 1966. This nostalgic look into the past is a sure sign we are going to crash out of the competition. It's all right to be proud of our past achievements, but we always finish our nostalgia trips by saying, "It will never be as good as it used to be." We can't shake this attitude off while the monarchy remains and reminds us of times gone by, when we were the best at everything.

William, I feel sorry for you because you have been born into bonded slavery. I would never want to be in your position. I would love to ask you if you are happy, or if you really want to be king. From the day you were born the royal advisers and spin doctors were rubbing their hands together, shouting, "Eureka!", and began spreading statements like "His upbringing will be different from the other royal children."

Yeah, right. Your life was different from other royal children. It was also completely different from the upbringing of every other person in the world: you were pronounced "the saviour of Britain" (or at least of the monarchy). How can anyone live up to expectations like that? You have been through a lot in your life and you have handled it all spectacularly well. fields.headline: Garry, champion of the world
fields.standfirst: When Irish playwrights conquered the West End and Broadway, they had one person above all to thank.  Lyn Gardner  meets director Garry Hynes as her latest production arrives at the Royal Court
fields.trailText: When Irish playwrights conquered the West End and Broadway, they had one person above all to thank. Lyn Gardner meets director Garry Hynes as her latest production arrives at the Royal Court
fields.body:
Irish theatre is stuffed with the great and the good. A lot of them are dead and most of them are men. Garry Hynes is an exception. Garry is short for Gearoidin, the Irish version of Geraldine.

For the past 25 years, since she founded the Druid theatre company in Galway, Hynes has cut a swathe through Irish theatre and beyond. She championed neglected Irish writers such as Tom Murphy in the mid-80s, with productions that then transferred from Galway to London's Donmar Warehouse. These plays were the advance guard for the Irish invasion of London's theatreland a decade later, in which Hynes also played a major part. Martin McDonagh was a Hynes discovery, his Beauty Queen of Leenane plucked from a pile of unsolicited scripts. In 1998 Hynes's Broadway production of McDonagh's Leenane trilogy won her a Tony, making her the first woman ever to win one for best director. Anything Dublin could do, Hynes could almost always do better.

Then there was Hynes's time as artistic director of Dublin's Abbey theatre, from 1990 to 1993. She was the sixth director in seven years and her first production was heavily criticised, yet she managed to drag that venerable but backward-looking institution into the modern era, despite much opposition and malicious rumour.

If Hynes were a man she would probably be called determined and quietly confident, but since she's female and five foot nothing she tends to get labelled as tough as old boots. It doesn't worry her one jot. She is, says Deborah Warner, "a woman who is brave and has tremendous nerve". Her conversation is characterised by the same precise and forceful intelligence that marks her direction. What you see is what you get.

Hynes, 47, is in London for the British premiere of Marina Carr's On Raftery's Hill, about a family living in the rural Midlands of Ireland. Before our meeting, I sit outside the Royal Court reading the script. Although the sun is warm, I feel as if a cold, clammy hand has taken hold of my heart.

The story of a wealthy farmer whose fields are full of rotting carcasses but whose real acts of pollution take place with his own children inside the farmhouse, Carr's play, with its brutality and incest, is as terrible as any Greek tragedy. As the critic for the Irish Times quipped, it makes even The Beauty Queen of Leenane seem like a light romantic comedy.

"There is a ferocity about the play and subject matter that is not easy. But it's only hard to believe if you don't want to believe it," says Hynes. Druid commissioned On Raftery's Hill in 1996, shortly before Hynes returned to the company. Although the play was born in the mid-90s, its subject matter chimes with current events in Ireland, particularly the spate of revelations about child abuse. The play has become part of the nation's debate about how it cares for its children.

"There has been a stunned quality to the response, and a degree of shock. There is a real need for people to think that people aren't like the family in the play," explains Hynes. "Some people have been angry that Marina doesn't condemn any of the characters, and it's something I had to work through and come to terms with when I was directing it. But you have to see these people's behaviour in the play as a continuum, and one of the things I realised is that the emotions and needs of these characters are exactly like my own. You can't say that they are less than human. These girls really love their father. Dinah and her father are locked in a terrible kind of marriage."

As with all of Carr's plays, including The Mai and Portia Coughlan (which Hynes premiered at the Abbey), the family stands as a metaphor for Ireland, and what appears to be a domestic situation has a public application. This is a quality that runs through many of the plays that Hynes has championed, whether it is the old classics such as Juno and the Paycock or the plays of Synge, all six of which she shortly intends to produce in repertoire, or the work of young writers such as Carr and McDonagh.

Hynes bristles slightly at the suggestion that a play such as On Raftery's Hill is a welcome breath of fresh air given the tendency of so much Irish drama to mythologise. "This play is only a demythology if you take the view that all the previous plays are mythologies," she says briskly. She eyes me beadily: "Would you say the work of Eugene O'Neill is a mythology or a debunking of the Irish American experience?"

Of course Hynes is right. Good plays can both mythologise and debunk, and Hynes's choice of work over the years has reflected a determination to explore the realities and myths of what it means to be Irish in the modern world. With the exception of some work for the RSC and the New York premiere of Arthur Miller's latest play, Mr Peter's Connections, Hynes has explored only the Irish canon. It is not for want of offers. The Tony brought in a flood of jobs that she turned down.

"I considered them all on the basis of whether they were something I absolutely needed to do, and most weren't. So often, all that people want you to do is repeat what you've just won an award for." Even returning to Druid after the Abbey is part of the pattern - although some suggested she was just running for shelter after a battering in Dublin.

"It is probably open to that interpretation," says Hynes dryly. She says she is interested in Irish plays simply because she is Irish - although that interest is more pronounced because the time she was born, the early 50s, marks the divide between the old Ireland and the new.

"Growing up, I had an automatic expectation of university and a career but all around me were the remnants and stories of an Ireland that was disappearing or gone. It was the need to explore that life that had gone before - how we had got from that to this - that interested me. I think that the plays of Martin McDonagh took me full circle. I feel there will be a shift in the coming years."

That shift may be marked by the courage of Carr's play, which doesn't hold the characters up for judgment but peers into the dark heart of one family, maybe the dark heart of Ireland itself, and tries to understand it.

"The circumstances of the play are close to cases that have become public in Ireland ," says Hynes. "But On Raftery's Hill is not documentary realism. What I like about it is that it doesn't fall into the trap of thinking that by revealing or documenting something we can stop it. Ireland has been awash with revelations. But nothing really changes."

On Raftery's Hill is at the Royal Court, London SW1 (020-7565 5000), till July 22.

fields.headline: Paint it black
fields.standfirst: Pencil, paper, miner's helmet.  Jill Tunstall joins the underground artists
fields.trailText: Pencil, paper, miner's helmet. Jill Tunstall joins the underground artists
fields.body:
It's a warm morning, the sky is blue and the sun is blazing. But none of that matters to the group of artists gathered in a south Wales lay-by. They are going where the sun never shines, where all is dim and gloomy - and that's just how they like it. These are the members of the International Society for Spelaeological Art (ISSA).

The day starts with a communal change by the side of a road. The group squeeze into wetsuits, wellies and helmets, while chatting of pencils and sketchbook carriers. Their destination is Bridge Cave in the Little Neath cave system. Getting into it involves wriggling through a muddy tunnel, over sharp rocks that shred unprotected knees, then squeezing through a boulder choke, where the ceiling has caved in, and wading through a fast-flowing, freezing underground stream. And this is one of the easier outings. I was only minutes into it when I began to think that Bridge was a cave too far.

This is the way Ceris Jones feels every time she goes underground. At the beginning of the day she had sat in the cave entrance, on the verge of hyperventilation, before forcing herself through this tunnel, which narrows to just 18in in parts. Even so, Jones, an art teacher from Preston, is an active member of this group of underground artists. Her terror manifests itself in stark prints that depict nightmarish worlds of suffocatingly black, claustrophobic tunnels.

"These are the nasty things that I've been going through," she says later, gesturing at a painting of a caver wedged inside a tunnel. "I never depict the cave environment, just the people, and I try to get a feeling of why they are doing it."

Why they do it soon becomes apparent as we wade into Bridge Cave's magnificent chamber, and a dozen head-torches light up banks of stalactites, glinting quartzite crystals and a natural bridge spanning the breach. The group perch on rocks, pull out their pencils and sketchbooks and begin to work, capturing the half-lit scene, its shapes and shadows. Non-artist cavers are employed as models, or hurriedly sketched as they wade by.

The ISSA was started six years ago by a group who were cavers first, artists second. Now they have members who are "artists who cave". Between them they produce everything from dramatic compositions in charcoal to watercolours, pastels and silk screens.

For Ian Chandler, a retired lecturer from Bristol, caving is about more than visual interpretation. A poet and sculptor, he records the sounds of the caves - the dripping of water and the scrape of boots on tunnel walls - to accompany his poetry readings. On the surface he works in reclaimed metals, hammering steel and water-stained copper piping to produce evocative images of sumps and rifts, sculptures you have to look inside - just like the caves themselves.

Given artists' usual preoccupation with the quality and quantity of light, isn't the lack of it inside the caves frustrating? Jenny Keal, a professional artist from Builth Wells in Wales, explains that this very absence of light makes all the struggle and discomfort worthwhile. "Cave painting is to do with light because you have only a small amount of light focused on what you're interested in. If you're a landscape painter, you see far too much outside. That's the hardest part of landscape painting - not being able to see it all. Whereas here it's easy because you can only see a little bit at a time."

"When I first came into caves to paint it was all about formations," says her partner, David Bellamy, who works in watercolours and pastels, and also leads painting expeditions to mountain regions. "But then you suddenly realise it's more about caving itself. I like sketching the figure, like Jenny coming through a rift high up, about 60ft above, when all that's holding her up is the pressure of her limbs against the walls. I'll do a quick sketch and say, 'Can you hold it a second?' You should see the look on her face, but the dynamism in the body is just amazing. It's like a very dynamic life class."

"A lot of it's the lack of sky, as well," says Robin Gray, an art teacher who hails from Cheddar in Somerset. "You're within a total landscape. Rather than sitting on top of, or in, the landscape, you're actually inside it - and it's wonderful. There's a colour that very few people need very much of on the surface, and that's black. Down here there's a lot of black."

And a lot to discover, as Ian Chandler, who has caved for more than 40 years, points out: "Caves are really one of the last unexplored places on earth, one of the places that still can't be seen by satellite and where you can go and know no one has been before."

But they do have their down side. Drop your sketchbook, as Chandler did, and it will be swept away. Two years of work was lost in Bridge Cave that day, which is a shame because, as he says in his poem, Matienzo: 25 Years: "It's not being there that's important/ It's draughting an image/ Of breezy funnels/ For others to sniff."

The ISSA can be reached through Robin Gray on 01934 744957.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Testament Of Dr Mabuse/Sling Blade/One Night Stand/Bring Me The Head Of Alfredo Garcia
fields.body:
The Testament Of Dr Mabuse

(Fritz Lang, 1933)

6pm, FilmFour

One of Lang's finest films and his last German production, a multi-stranded horror-thriller that's way ahead of its time. The criminal mastermind's now firmly locked up in an insane asylum, but a coordinated crime campaign is being waged on the city with his hallmark efficiency, baffling police, psychiatrists and the criminals themselves.

Sling Blade

(Billy Bob Thornton, 1996)

10pm, FilmFour

The actor/writer Thornton's astonishing debut as director is about as left-field as they come. It's the story of a mentally deficient Arkansas man's attempts to rejoin society: he's spent most of his life in a psychiatric institution for murdering his mother and her lover when he was 12. But his new friendship with a boy (Lucas Black) and his mother (Natalie Canderday) brings him into conflict with her abusive boyfriend (Dwight Yoakam). Beautifully, tenderly acted, with vivid cameos from Robert Duvall, Jim Jarmusch and the late JT Walsh.

One Night Stand

(Mike Figgis, 1997)

12midnight, Sky Premier

Intriguing to see Wesley Snipes as non-action man in a thoughtful, melancholy study of relationships and life's little ambushes, similar in tone to Figgis's Leaving Las Vegas. Snipes plays Max, a married LA ads director, whose shallow life is shaken to the core by a brief sexual encounter with Nastassja Kinski's Karen, and by his renewed friendship with the Aids-stricken Charlie (Robert Downey Jr). The performances are excellent - Snipes should hang up the guns more often.

Bring Me The Head Of Alfredo Garcia

(Sam Peckinpah, 1974)

1.15am, Carlton Cinema

Peckinpah's bloody modern western has washed-up piano player Warren Oates taking on mobsters, bikers and bandits to deliver said flyblown head to the Mexican gangster who's offering a big reward: it belonged to the man who impregnated his daughter. All sweat, death and bloody retribution in this doom-laden meditation on the human condition, one of Peckinpah's finest. Gig Young, Robert Webber and Emilio Fernandez also star.

But his new friendship with a boy (Lucas Black) and his mother (Natalie Canderday) brings him into conflict with her abusive boyfriend (Dwight Yoakam). Beautifully, tenderly acted, with vivid cameos from Robert Duvall, Jim Jarmusch and the late JT Walsh. One Night Stand (Mike Figgis, 1997) 12midnight, Sky Premier Intriguing to see Wesley Snipes as non-action man in a thoughtful, melancholy study of relationships and life's little ambushes, similar in tone to Figgis's Leaving Las Vegas. Snipes plays Max, a married LA ads director, whose shallow life is shaken to the core by a brief sexual encounter with Nastassja Kinski's Karen, and by his renewed friendship with the Aids-stricken Charlie (Robert Downey Jr). The performances are excellent - Snipes should hang up the guns more often. Bring Me The Head Of Alfredo Garcia (Sam Peckinpah, 1974) 1.15am, Carlton Cinema Peckinpah's bloody modern western has washed-up piano player Warren Oates taking on mobsters, bikers and bandits to deliver said flyblown head to the Mexican gangster who's offering a big reward: it belonged to the man who impregnated his daughter. All sweat, death and bloody retribution in this doom-laden meditation on the human condition, one of Peckinpah's finest. Gig Young, Robert Webber and Emilio Fernandez also star.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Composer Of The Week/The Secret History Of Conan Doyle
fields.body:
Even by the standards of his Baroque contemporaries, Georg Philipp Telemann's productivity was astounding. After 50 years' hard labour, scholars have still to complete the full catalogue of an oeuvre which included 40 operas, 200 concerti, 600 orchestral suites and more than 1,000 religious works. To nominate him merely as Composer Of The Week (9.0am, Radio 3) seems a gross understatement but Donald Macleod offers a titbit or two to give some taste of the whole.

Biographer Humphrey Carpenter offers a glimpse into The Secret History Of Conan Doyle (11.0am, Radio 4) on the 70th anniversary of the writer's death. With an alcoholic father and a domineering mother, Doyle (pictured) didn't have a happy childhood and it wasn't surprising he lost his Roman Catholic faith early on. Unfortunately he then tended to believe almost anything anyone told him with sufficient conviction. As an adult he accepted that Bacon had written Shakespeare's plays and became a fervent spiritualist.

webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Patricia Arquette in A Nightmare On Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors
fields.body:
Patricia Arquette in A Nightmare On Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors (Chuck Russell, 1987)

Who: Patricia shares her profession with her siblings Rosanna, David and Alexis, and both her father and grandfather. She had a son, Enzo, when she was 24, and her early career was very much in the shadow of big sister and Desperately Seeking Susan star, Rosanna. Dross like Prayer Of The Rollerboys (with has-been teen idol Corey Haim) gave way to the likes of True Romance and Ed Wood. Her marriage to Nicolas Cage, with whom she co-starred in Martin Scorsese's Bringing Out The Dead, ended recently among rumours that they were never really a couple. Arquette's abandoned her arty roots recently, appearing in the dire Stigmata, and starring alongside Adam Sandler (and her dad) in comedy Little Nicky - where Sandler plays one of Satan's three sons.

The role: Kristen Parker, a teen suicide case who's actually being stalked in her dreams by Freddy Kruege.

Best line: Talking to Nancy Thompson (Heather Langenkamp), who battled Freddy in the first Nightmare movie, Kristen says "The man in my dreams - he's real, isn't he?" Note that the man in her dreams may well not be the man of her dreams.

Cringe factor: Low. Although she does spend a lot of the film emitting a series of startlingly high-pitched screams.

Other wannabes: Laurence Fishburne turns up as a hospital orderly.

Critical judgement: Richard Harrington, in the Washington Post, called Patricia "a shorter, chunkier version of Daryl Hannah".

Also not starring in: A 1987 episode of thirtysomething called Good Sex, Bad Sex, What Sex, No Sex.

A Nightmare On Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors, FilmFour, Tuesday July 4, 12.15am.

fields.headline: Walking with dinosaurs
fields.standfirst: Weekend TV:  Nancy Banks-Smith
fields.trailText: Dalziel And Pascoe/Inspector Morse/Witness/Brookside
fields.body:
As the Assistant Chief Constable said, when Dalziel mistook her for the stripper and told her to go and powder her bits for the lads: "What I saw was a dinosaur." As it happens, we are all devoted to dinosaurs, which is a bit of luck for Morse, Frost, Dalziel and Taggart (deceased). Not one of them is focused, on message or safe to be left alone with a computer.

Dalziel And Pascoe (BBC 1) and an Inspector Morse repeat (ITV) went head-to-head on Saturday. Or, more precisely, Morse sneaked up behind Dalziel and tried to bite a meaty lump out of his audience. These Jurassic contests aren't for the squeamish but they certainly shake up Saturday night.

Dalziel has returned from his bullets-in-the-guts sick leave. Someone said sotto voce - but not quite sotto enough - "I thought you were dead." An unsafe assumption, even for a dinosaur.

Everyone thought Abbie Hallingsworth was dead too. Dalziel had caught her murderer 19 years before. Then a woman calling herself Abbie Hallingsworth reappears.

WDC Kendall, who probably believes that for every drop of rain that falls, a flower grows, trusted Abbie and tried to shoehorn her back into the bosom of her wealthy family. Dalziel did not. "The dead walk? Not in Yorkshire."

A visit to the man convicted of Abbie's murder in prison hospital shows Dalziel's bedside manner to advantage ("I've had some good news. I've just heard you're dying"). As Dalziel says to Pascoe: "He's no more a victim of anything than I'm bloody Tinkerbell. Only don't tell Mint Cake here." (Mint Cake is WDC Kendall). "The way she goes believing people, she'll have me dressing in a tutu." If you need a helpful gloss on this, Tinkerbell persuades otherwise sane audiences to say they believe in fairies.

Dalziel does not believe in fairies. In this he resembles Miss Marple, who always believes the worst of people on the grounds that this usually proves to be the case.

A Sweeter Lazarus was better written than strictly necessary. When a solicitor says "My client is a respected businessman", Dalziel's tongue moves around his bag of a face, shifting the bumps about a bit. "Why is it, when I hear that, that I always want to check my fillings?" A much better metaphor for mistrust than counting your spoons. The businessman is not, by nature, an impulsive type. Dalziel calls him "the kind who checks the bog paper before he sits on the pan". And you don't get much more anal retentive than that.

It all kept you nicely nervous for 90 minutes and there were some particularly fine seaside shots with breakers coming in like killer whales. Abbie? Oh, she was an impostor, of course. Dalziel's bullet-riddled gut reaction was right from the start. There is something right about these old dinosaurs. Not correct, right .

Witness (Channel 4), a documentary about the death of pets, was saddest at the end, which seems appropriate. A man was talking about the death of his dog. His distressed words fell over each other. "She'd got all these cancers all the way round here. Took her to the vet, hoping for miracle. You take her down, you know? And they were very good. And they said it would be a shame to keep her going the state she was in. And it came as a bit of a shock but we lost her there and then." There was more to this than a dog. The waiflike wife, holding his hand, was dying of cancer too. He said "Shall we take a stroll?"and they walked round the pet cemetery perfectly in step, like a couple who had kept pace with each other for a long time.

Pet Heaven was full of rather endearing eccentrics. It was also informative. The cremation of dead pets, who are treated as clinical waste, was a revelation. Machinery screamed, bin bags melted, stiff little legs emerged. Nigel, who collects 6,000 pets a week from veterinary practices, said "I've got two dogs at home. They won't go as mass cremation." Terri, whose husband runs a pet cemetery as personal as a corner shop, has an even better idea. "My dogs are not going to die. It's not allowed and that's the end of it."

"What's odd about me? Name one odd thing about me." Ron "The Rug" Dixon in Brookside (C4). Scriptwriters can be very cruel.

webTitle: Paul Smith: Just a regular knight

fields.headline: Paul Smith: Just a regular knight
fields.standfirst: He taught British men to dress and built a multi-million pound fashion empire. But the UK's most successful designer is suprised that anyone has noticed, finds the Guardian's new fashion editor,  Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.trailText: He taught British men to dress and built a multi-million pound fashion empire. But the UK's most successful designer is suprised that anyone has noticed, finds the Guardian's new fashion editor,  Jess Cartner-Morley
fields.body:
Sir Paul Smith is a very British fashion designer. Seemingly genuinely embarrassed by all the fuss over his recently awarded knighthood, he waves away my congratulations. "Ooh, yes! Aren't I posh?" While the elegant young people working on the Covent Garden shopfloor downstairs have the faint haughtiness perfected by staff in such stores, upstairs in his chaotic attic workroom the boss appears devoid of airs and graces. The message is clear: I may be Britain's most successful designer and head of a multi-million pound fashion empire but I'm just a regular bloke.

A regular bloke, that is, sporting a rather dapper, brightly coloured striped shirt in the finest cotton, with the whitest of white T-shirts showing at the collar. He is tall at 6ft 4in, but well-dressed enough to look elegant rather than lanky. His accent is Midlands-soft, but he talks as fast as any Cockney; even sitting still, he moves around constantly, balancing on the back legs of his chair like a child, raking his hands through his unruly salt-and-pepper hair.

He heard about the knighthood in the office, when his assistant, Colette, was opening the post, he explains. "She was going through the gas bills and so on, and suddenly she said, 'I think you'd better take a look at this one. It's from Downing St.' It was weird because I'm sure there's lots of other people out there who deserve them, so I feel very humbled by it. But really, I have worked hard and it is quite nice ... and my mum and dad aren't around anymore but they'd have been dead pleased."

He may have successful stores from Taipei to New York - there are over 200 in Japan alone - but describing a talk he gave at a recent textile event in Italy, Smith exclaims "there was the boss of Gucci, the boss of Prada, the boss of Louis Vuitton, and little old Paul Smith from England!"

How British: to spend 30 years building a business with an annual turnover of £177m, and then be surprised that anyone has noticed.

Paul Smith, now by some distance Britain's most financially successful fashion designer, was born in Nottingham in 1946, the son of a draper. As a teenager he was a passionate cyclist, covering up to 300 miles a week until an accident at 17 landed him with a broken femur and put an end to his racing ambitions. At a loose end, he began hanging around a local pub, which happened to be frequented by students from the local art school. "I met fashion designers, architects, photographers, artists ... this whole world opened up to me."

It was at the Bell that he met Pauline Denyer, his partner ever since, a fashion design graduate of the Royal College of Art who encouraged Smith, by now something of a dandy, to open a boutique. "The first Paul Smith collections were actually designed by Pauline, not by me. Then slowly, through working with her, and studying, I went on to design the clothes myself and she went back to art school and her original love of painting."

In 1976, six years after the first Paul Smith boutique opened in Nottingham, Smith showed his first men's collection in Paris. The signature combination of first-class tailoring and witty detailing - "classic with a twist", as Smith terms it - was already there. The Covent Garden store, still his London headquarters, came three years later; childrenswear in 1991, womenswear in 1994; this summer sees the launch of Paul Smith fragrances for men and women. "I don't actually have a lot of money stuck in a bank somewhere, but I've paid for my houses and I have a nice income," is how Smith puts it. Pauline owns "a big part" of the business, although she no longer takes an active design role.

Smith has long been an outspoken critic of the British fashion industry. In 1992, he refused the British Designer of the Year award because he thought it was "a bit self-congratulatory. I don't see the point of it. Most of the people who've won over the years have not had very substantial businesses. I wanted to say, we're great at ideas but can we please try to sort out the business side." He is now on a government taskforce which hopes "to rethink how to make the most of the potential of the design industries, to encourage people to believe that design can create wealth. In Britain we have this goldmine of talent, but we don't understand how to harness ideas, promote and manufacture them.

"One of the things the industry suffers from in Britain is that a lot of the clothes are very extreme, and it's always the extreme clothes that get in the newspapers anyway because they make stronger pictures. So the perception of the public is that fashion is all very extreme, and the perception of young designers in college is that the way to be successful is to do something very extravagant and attention-seeking."

Smith describes himself as not political, but responsible: "I'm interested in issues and in doing things where I can help."

So what is his take on the recent "superwaif summit", and the evidence that images of extremely thin catwalk models might encourage anorexia? Smith wheels out the fashion industry's stock response. "I hope it's not true, but it could have an element of truth. It's hard to know what to do ... the fact is that, unfortunately, clothes do look better on the catwalk on slimmer girls."

It is men upon whom Smith has had the greatest influence. "The way men dressed changed in the early 80s and I sort of nudged them into it, I think. I helped persuade them that wearing a shirt that had some colour in it, or a tie that was a bit brighter, was fine - not feminine or attention-seeking." Which men in the public eye does he think dress well? There is a long pause. "Very few," he offers sagely. Tony Blair? "He looks fine. He wears some of our suits, actually. But the difference between politicians here and politicians in France and Italy is that on the continent they wear bespoke suits, so that they really fit."

The secret of his success, Smith says, has been an ability to marry design and business. "Hopefully, I'm similar to Tom [Ford, head designer at Gucci] in this way - he has that balance, in that he has a design talent and also understands the business."

It is still designing that he loves best. "I'm really hanging on to that, because what happens to a lot of people is that they become a businessman, a front man. I work hard at staying involved in every stage of the design process. I can still recognise my clothes when I see people wearing them in the street because I choose all the fabrics, all the colours."

Attitude is important too. "I'm a positivist. I'm a nice bloke - no, it sounds big headed to say that, doesn't it? But I love life and I've got an open mind."

He still feels strong ties with Nottingham. One of the nice things about the knighthood, he says, apart from all the "smashing" letters (including one from Cherie Blair, who "said she was delighted to see my name on the list and that it was very well deserved") was the pleasure and pride it brought the pattern-cutters and box-packers at his Nottingham business. He doesn't bother wooing celebrity clients (he has plenty, anyway) but one of the few people he has given free clothes too (along with David Bowie, "because he's quite a good friend") is the actress Samantha Morton, "because she's from Nottingham, and she was up for an Oscar and I was proud of her".

There is an endearing absence of suaveness about Smith. Standing behind my chair to take a call, he starts absent-mindedly rubbing my shoulders. A few minutes later, back in his chair, he breaks off mid-sentence and exclaims, "Oh! I've just realised, I was stroking your neck! I'm sorry. I sometimes do that to the girls in the office, give them a little massage. Sorry, sorry, sorry."

It is impossible to imagine the impeccably slick Tom Ford forgetting himself like that; there's something charming about Smith's guileless inability to stay in media-mode.

It is Smith's birthday on Wednesday: "Yup, 21" (54, in fact). He'll be in Paris, dealing with the aftermath of his men's catwalk show the previous day so he won't have much time to celebrate, but "we're going on holiday the week after. We're off for a month." Where to? "Italy. We've, er, we've got a house there."

Whereabouts? "Well . . . we've got two actually. One in Tuscany, one in Sardinia. We'll spend two weeks in each. Oh, dear, sorry. That sounds like showing off, doesn't it?"

Where to? "Italy. We've, er, we've got a house there." Whereabouts? "Well . . . we've got two actually. One in Tuscany, one in Sardinia. We'll spend two weeks in each. Oh, dear, sorry. That sounds like showing off, doesn't it?"

fields.headline: Redwood wins comeback as 'spin-stopper'
fields.standfirst:
Hague U-turn on dumped shadow minister
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: John Redwood yesterday won belated vindication for his career as one of the shadow cabinet's most effective performers when William Hague brought him back into his team - six months after dropping him.
fields.body:
John Redwood yesterday won belated vindication for his career as one of the shadow cabinet's most effective performers when William Hague brought him back into his team - six months after dropping him.

The former Welsh secretary, who got a two-year head start in opposition after he resigned from John Major's cabinet in 1995 to challenge Mr Major for the Tory leadership, has been put in charge of the parliamentary campaigns unit, with the informal title of "spin-stopper". Despite being shunted off to the backbenches, Mr Redwood, an ardent free marketeer, has never given up and a constant stream of attacks on Labour or European Union policy failings spews from his computer.

He has claimed several ministerial scalps already and plans to focus in the short term on whipping up rage among motorists and the tabloid press over rising petrol prices, which the Tories blame on the government rather than market forces.

In effect, the MP for Wokingham - who was nicknamed the Vulcan for his disconcerting intensity - will coordinate the group of backbenchers who harry vulnerable ministers, above all Tony Blair, who is sometimes rattled by heckling.

A former Fellow of All Souls and head of the Thatcher policy unit, Mr Redwood will put his mind to deconstructing Labour's policy claims and spending figures as the chancellor's comprehensive spending review looms in the middle of this month.

All but Mr Redwood's most bitter enemies in the Tory ranks admit that Mr Hague made a mistake in replacing him as environment spokesman last February. He was succeeded by Archie Norman.

Mr Hague put a positive spin on his change of heart yesterday.

"We have long said that Labour is all spin and no substance," he said. "I look forward to John and his team providing another formidable layer of opposition and helping to expose the misleading spin of this government as they continue to let down the country in so many ways."

Mr Redwood said: "I wanted to highlight today with this new job that Labour was over-spinning. Spin is destroying this government and doing a lot of damage to the country. The public want to be told the truth."

True to his Vulcan-ish sense of humour, the MP let it be known that he had been spinning on the cricket pitch yesterday, playing in a match at his old Oxford college, Magdalen - probably to annoy its Labour tormentor, Gordon Brown.

fields.headline: No: 1668
fields.standfirst: Fifa
fields.trailText: Fifa
fields.body:
Full name: Fédération Internationale de Football Association.

Age: 96.

Status: Governing body of football.

Number of members: 202 (more than the UN).

Size of executive committee: 24, including representatives from footballing hotbeds Botswana, Malta and New Zealand.

Why has it got a French name? I thought we invented football. We did and the intention was to give the UK a leading role. But we failed to show up for the inaugural meeting in Paris. We also refused to play in the first World Cup, held in Uruguay in 1930. We eventually saw the light in 1946.

Oh well, we're true believers in the global game now. Indeed. So much so that we've just spent £10m trying to convince Fifa that England should host the 2006 World Cup.

Will we get it? Don't be silly. Fifa would rather stage it on Mars than give it to England, as we'll discover when the committee announces its decision in Zurich on Thursday.

It's a swiss: I think you mean a swizz.

Why does Fifa hate England? Our 40-year sulk didn't help. But it's really all to do with neo-colonialism: read your Stuart Hall.

The It's A Knockout presenter and Man City fan? Almost certainly not.

Where did we go wrong? In about 1974, when Sir Stanley Rous was ousted as president of Fifa by the Brazilian Joao Havelange in a dastardly coup by third world ingrates against a fine old English gentleman/long-overdue democratic revolt against European domination (delete according to preferred Stuart Hall).

So who will get it? South Africa, in line with the wishes of Havelange's successor, Sepp Blatter, who wants to develop the game in Africa.

Admirable. Surely even backers of the English bid will accept that. "It's a blatant piece of political chicanery" (Tony Banks).

Where do we go from here? Johannesburg.

Do say: "All we asked for was a level playing field."

Don't say: "Who is Stuart Hall?"

fields.headline: The truth about forced marriage
fields.standfirst: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown on why a new report is right to take a tough line
fields.trailText: Yasmin Alibhai-Brown on why a new report is right to take a tough line
fields.body:
Finally, and long, long after Asian women's groups first asked for it, we have an official condemnation of forced marriages in this country. These are marriages without free consent, where duress is used to make individuals conform; they are prevalent in some (not all) British Asian communities. A controversial report published last week by a Home Office-appointed working group, of which I was a member, has come out with a firm message: "We must value ... our diversity [but] we must not excuse practices that compromise or undermine the basic rights accorded to all people."

Home Office minister Mike O'Brien has added his voice, saying "multicultural sensitivity is not an excuse for moral blindness". This is a radical departure from the politics of cowardice. There has been a conspiracy of silence on this issue for decades. MPs who depend on the "ethnic" vote have knowingly allowed these violations to go on in exchange for the support of conservative, middle-aged Asian men who are violently against the inexorable changes they see in their communities, especially among young women.

Some feel the group should have taken an even tougher approach. Last week, my fellow working party member Hannana Siddiqui of Southall Black Sisters resigned in protest at the group's refusal to condemn methods of putting women in hiding back in touch with their families. She argued that the practice of mediation placed young women under even greater pressure to return home and put their safety at risk.

Even so, the report is important. We are talking about a thousand cases per year, born of an enormous clash of expectations. It was men who decided to come here. They brought women as bearers of their children, their culture, their religion. This part of their life was not going to change. At home, they could behave as if they had never left.

But the women changed. Some had to work and became more independent. Many side with their daughters when it comes to forced marriage; others overcompensate by colluding in it. The girls, meanwhile, have grown up with a stronger sense of individuality than their elder sisters. Though few have gone all the way in rejecting social codes (teenage pregnancies are still rare among Asians), this 90s generation is assertively autonomous in a way that terrifies their parents. So they pack them off, under some pretence, and marry them off. By the time they come back, if they do, they are tamed, pregnant or already mothers. Izzat (honour) is satisfied.

Changing these attitudes will take a long time. But this report puts the girls' needs at the forefront and now that Asians themselves are advocating action, social workers, teachers, the police and others will be free to intervene without being called racist.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Lorry driver on death charge
fields.body:
Lorry driver on death charge

A French lorry driver aged 28 will appear before magistrates today charged with causing death by dangerous driving.

He was arrested following an 11-vehicle crash on the M6 in Leicestershire on Friday in which three died.

Call to protect Scots mussels

Police and Scottish Natural Heritage yesterday appealed for the public's help in protecting freshwater pearl mussels.

Scotland is seen as Europe's stronghold for the species, with most colonies in rivers in the Highlands and on Tayside.

Women stand guard at palace

Four women are among 150 Australian soldiers taking up the Queen's Guard on every other day until July 20, to mark Australia Week.

Yesterday they marched at Buckingham Palace to Waltzing Matilda.

Holidaymaker dies in Majorca

Kevin Skeavington, 18, fell to his death from a balcony at the Honolulu hotel in Majorca on Saturday night, while on holiday.

His parents in Mansfield, Nottingham, Tina and Darren, were said yesterday to be too upset to talk.

Flash floods hit the north

Flash floods hit parts of northern England yesterday as half the month's usual rain fell in six hours.

At Chester, an electrical storm caused a downpour that in minutes left roads and pavements under two or three feet of water.

£7.2m jackpot is rolled over

Saturday's lottery jackpot of £7.2m is rolled over as no ticket had the winning numbers: 11, 16, 22, 39, 42, and 48; bonus 38.

Thunderball numbers were 9, 16, 17, 24, 31, and the Thunderball was 4.

webTitle: Holiday firms urged to protect Ibiza ravers

fields.headline: Holiday firms urged to protect Ibiza ravers
fields.trailText: Tour operators, airlines, hotels and clubs should provide health education and advice to young ravers booking sun and dance holidays in Ibiza, according to researchers who found "disturbing" levels of drug abuse and unsafe sex.
fields.body:
Tour operators, airlines, hotels and clubs should provide health education and advice to young ravers booking sun and dance holidays in Ibiza, according to researchers who found "disturbing" levels of drug abuse and unsafe sex.

A team at Liverpool John Moores University studied questionnaires distributed at Ibiza's airport. They found that although less than 3% of those surveyed took ecstasy on five or more days a week in Britain, the figure jumped to 42% while on Ibiza.

Use of cannabis soared from 29% on five or more days while at home to 54% on Ibiza, and almost 31% said they had used more than one drug during their stay. Nearly 90% had drunk alcohol on five or more days while on the Spanish island.

With 700,000 British visitors expected to head for Ibiza this year, the researchers called on holiday companies to provide health education materials and advice.

"While the potential for substance-related ill health is dramatically elevated in Ibiza, harm minimisation measures in such resorts remain scarce," writes Professor Mark Bellis in a paper in the International Journal of Drug Policy today. "And although holiday companies attract a sexually active market, safe sex messages are either absent or ineffective."

The research team found "disturbing" levels of unprotected sex: almost 54% of the sample had had sex while on holiday and more than a quarter did not use a condom, although 23% had sex with more than one partner.

Prof Bellis said many companies traded on images of long nights of booze and sex. "Club 18-30, one of the most successful youth tour operators, includes in its mission statement, 'Try sex in the surf... drink all your duty free on day one'. In the short term, harm minimisation measures such as educational leaflets, information on seeking medical assistance abroad and easy access to condoms seem essential steps in protecting the health of young holiday makers."

But a spokeswoman for the Association of British Travel Agents said: "Where the risks are exactly the same as one would be facing in the UK, you can assume that customers have a degree of responsibility for their own safety. A holiday brochure is not the place for delivering advice, and I don't think it would make one bit of difference anyway."

Club 18-30 said its customers were given a voucher for free condoms, plus an advice booklet on drugs, produced in conjunction with the Health Education Authority.

The company's general manager, Andy Tidy, added: "While we are not moral guardians, it has always been our stance to encourage young people to take a responsible attitude towards drugs and sex. People of all ages tend to over-indulge while on holiday, whatever their recreational preferences."

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: I always hoped one day Daughter might tire of Glastonbury, but this year, 21 and grown up, she was off again.
fields.body:
I always hoped one day Daughter might tire of Glastonbury, but this year, 21 and grown up, she was off again. She had managed to forget the horror of it all: the mud, the sopping clothes, tent-thieves, rip-off snacks, queues, filth and physical collapse. We tried to warn her as she left. "The lavatories!" wailed Grandma. "Beware of the E coli," droned Gardener. "Mind the dangerous drugs!" I shouted.

But Daughter returned home safe, glowing with health. How had she managed it? How had she slept among the hordes? Easy. The bands finished at midnight, then you could tramp to the Sacred Area and chill among the drug peddlers. You called out whatever you wanted and a salesperson would pop up and supply it. Naturally Daughter and her boyfriend stuck to strawberry cider. They slept through Rolf Harris, a bitter disappointment, missed Madonna, but found the fairy shop, saw the two nude men, heard Moby and the fabulous Baby Heads, starring her very first boyfriend, lost the mobile, found it.

But on day three, things took a turn for the worse. "There is a dark side to Glastonbury," said Daughter ominously. The place was plagued by urinating men. "They were doing it everywhere, even on tents!"

This reminded me of my youth and my one and only pop festival - 35 years have passed and neither the music nor the lavatories has improved. Daughter described the stench and filth vividly. "Everyone was fucked," she cried, "and you couldn't wash. Two little lots of showers for 120,000, we couldn't find those tap-water people, gangs broke down the fences and charged £10 entry and it took us two hours just to get out of the car park!"

"So was it really horrible?"

"No. We had a great time!"

fields.headline: The falls guy
fields.standfirst: If you took your lover to Niagara to propose and she said no, what would you do?  Tim Dowling reveals what one man's epic voyage of misery, self-pity, unsuitable women and excess alcohol says about how the sexes handle breaking up
fields.trailText: If you took your lover to Niagara to propose and she said no, what would you do?  Tim Dowling reveals what one man's epic voyage of misery, self-pity, unsuitable women and excess alcohol says about how the sexes handle breaking up
fields.body:
When we say, as Neil Sedaka once said over and over again, that breaking up is hard to do, we are usually thinking about the loathsome chore of dumping a boyfriend or girlfriend, the guilt that comes of having to break someone's heart, and the guilt that comes of not feeling that guilty after all. It's not pleasant, but it has to be done. In this sense, breaking up is hard to do in the same way that writing thank you letters is hard to do.

Breaking up is, of course, much harder to do if you are the person getting dumped. Getting dumped isn't really breaking up; it's being told to piss off. The ground drops from under your feet, the air is knocked out of your lungs and a section of your brain is given over to internal screaming. Someone you loved and trusted now won't speak to you or return your phone calls, disappearing with a large chunk of your social network in tow.

The first time it happens is the scariest, catching you by surprise, usually when you're of too tender an age to regard temporary insanity as a learning experience. As for the worst time, for most of us it is probably still to come and there is nothing we can do to brace ourselves. Relationships often come to a point at which you can either stay together forever or break up. How can we possibly prepare for both outcomes?

It's clear that men and women nurse broken hearts differently, although it is not always clear what those differences are. One thirtysomething woman's recipe for a cure ("A little bit of stalking, quite a lot of bad-mouthing, too much alcohol and then sleeping with other people") sounds like it would work just as well, or as badly, for either sex. Men may be encouraged to put the old relationship behind them more quickly, but that doesn't mean they do.

In his new book Independence Day (published tomorrow by Abacus), Jim Keeble charts his months-long, bitterly funny, broken-hearted odyssey through the United States after being dumped by his girlfriend of seven years as he proposed to her in Niagara Falls, the honeymoon capital of the universe. It is a chronicle of misery, self-pity, ill-advised dating and generous alcohol intake which will be surprisingly familiar to men who thought they invented this particular form of therapy. "I think it's much more lonely in a way, being a dumped man," says Keeble, who is feeling much better now. "I think there are real differences in the support network."

By which he means to say that for men there is no support network, at least not among other men. "There is sympathy for half an hour," he says, "then it's 'Let's go and have a drink' and 'Isn't she fit, there at the bar, why don't you go and talk to her?' " Male friends rapidly lose patience with the abject, pathetic wallowing that is a necessary, if unattractive, part of getting over someone. They tend to want to solve your problem for you as quickly and simply as possible, and alcohol and sex are what they most often prescribe.

Dumped men often prefer the company of women at such difficult times, as women seem more familiar with the pathology of the broken heart. "I found I'd hang out with female friends a bit more after it happened," Keeble says. "You could go around the block several times talking about it. Which is actually pretty much all you want to do."

It is interesting to note that after a break-up, men and women do not necessarily retreat to the exclusive company of their own gender. One obvious reason for this is the need to spread yourself as thinly as possible. As you lurch from self-pity to self-help speak, from grumbling that all men are bastards to making secret late-night phone calls and begging him to take you back, from drunk to drunker still, most of your friends will be too annoyed by you to look after you full-time.

You end up seeking the company of whomever you think is prepared to tell you what you want to hear, whether it's "You're better off without her" or "Maybe you should ring her right now". You re-establish contact with all those old friends, male or female, who always thought your boyfriend was an idiot.

By the third week, dumped men and dumped women have usually exhausted their supply of sympathetic single friends and progress to hanging around the homes of happily married couples, with predictably depressing results. After a month or so, it's necessary to start lying about being well and truly on the mend, because no one in your acquaintance wants to hear otherwise.

One key difference between the sexes is how they handle the severe dent to one's self-esteem that being chucked necessarily entails. Traditionally, women use a break-up as an opportunity for self-improvement, changing their job or their hair, losing weight, moving house. Men, on the other hand, prefer to go off the rails, emerging from a period of self-destruction considerably worse for wear, chastened but none the wiser.

Jim Keeble's epic trip around some of America's more soulless tourist destinations was just a more adventurous version of this well-worn method. "I was on this nihilism kick. The future didn't exist," he says. "I just wanted to go to these places that had this image of hedonism, reinvention and superficiality. I guess Vegas, LA and Florida are pretty much the key destinations for that."

He also points out that this strategy is perhaps not as useless as it sounds. "Maybe it's a sort of short sharp shock therapy. You plunge completely into the unknown and you're forced to build up armour very quickly." In the rush to get over the pain of a broken heart, anything that seems like it might help is worth a try.

The difference in the approaches of the sexes to being dumped is in the end fairly negligible, since none of them does any good. Time is the only healer for a broken heart, a process that is rather too slow for most of us, followed by falling in love again, a process that is entirely too unpredictable to be relied upon. Following his travels around the landscape of his own broken heart, Keeble has an alternative solution. "I recommend everybody goes out and writes a book. That's the way forward."

But even years later, he can't look forward without a glance back. "Seven years and then you go and ask somebody to marry you and they say no. In Niagara Falls. It was pretty uncool."

It's not pleasant, but it has to be done. In this sense, breaking up is hard to do in the same way that writing thank you letters is hard to do. Breaking up is, of course, much harder to do if you are the person getting dumped. Getting dumped isn't really breaking up; it's being told to piss off. The ground drops from under your feet, the air is knocked out of your lungs and a section of your brain is given over to internal screaming. Someone you loved and trusted now won't speak to you or return your phone calls, disappearing with a large chunk of your social network in tow. The first time it happens is the scariest, catching you by surprise, usually when you're of too tender an age to regard temporary insanity as a learning experience. As for the worst time, for most of us it is probably still to come and there is nothing we can do to brace ourselves. Relationships often come to a point at which you can either stay together forever or break up. How can we possibly prepare for both outcomes? It's clear that men and women nurse broken hearts differently, although it is not always clear what those differences are. One thirtysomething woman's recipe for a cure ("A little bit of stalking, quite a lot of bad-mouthing, too much alcohol and then sleeping with other people") sounds like it would work just as well, or as badly, for either sex. Men may be encouraged to put the old relationship behind them more quickly, but that doesn't mean they do. In his new book Independence Day (published tomorrow by Abacus), Jim Keeble charts his months-long, bitterly funny, broken-hearted odyssey through the United States after being dumped by his girlfriend of seven years as he proposed to her in Niagara Falls, the honeymoon capital of the universe. It is a chronicle of misery, self-pity, ill-advised dating and generous alcohol intake which will be surprisingly familiar to men who thought they invented this particular form of therapy. "I think it's much more lonely in a way, being a dumped man," says Keeble, who is feeling much better now. "I think there are real differences in the support network." By which he means to say that for men there is no support network, at least not among other men. "There is sympathy for half an hour," he says, "then it's 'Let's go and have a drink' and 'Isn't she fit, there at the bar, why don't you go and talk to her?' " Male friends rapidly lose patience with the abject, pathetic wallowing that is a necessary, if unattractive, part of getting over someone. They tend to want to solve your problem for you as quickly and simply as possible, and alcohol and sex are what they most often prescribe. Dumped men often prefer the company of women at such difficult times, as women seem more familiar with the pathology of the broken heart. "I found I'd hang out with female friends a bit more after it happened," Keeble says. "You could go around the block several times talking about it. Which is actually pretty much all you want to do." It is interesting to note that after a break-up, men and women do not necessarily retreat to the exclusive company of their own gender. One obvious reason for this is the need to spread yourself as thinly as possible. As you lurch from self-pity to self-help speak, from grumbling that all men are bastards to making secret late-night phone calls and begging him to take you back, from drunk to drunker still, most of your friends will be too annoyed by you to look after you full-time. You end up seeking the company of whomever you think is prepared to tell you what you want to hear, whether it's "You're better off without her" or "Maybe you should ring her right now". You re-establish contact with all those old friends, male or female, who always thought your boyfriend was an idiot. By the third week, dumped men and dumped women have usually exhausted their supply of sympathetic single friends and progress to hanging around the homes of happily married couples, with predictably depressing results. After a month or so, it's necessary to start lying about being well and truly on the mend, because no one in your acquaintance wants to hear otherwise. One key difference between the sexes is how they handle the severe dent to one's self-esteem that being chucked necessarily entails. Traditionally, women use a break-up as an opportunity for self-improvement, changing their job or their hair, losing weight, moving house. Men, on the other hand, prefer to go off the rails, emerging from a period of self-destruction considerably worse for wear, chastened but none the wiser. Jim Keeble's epic trip around some of America's more soulless tourist destinations was just a more adventurous version of this well-worn method. "I was on this nihilism kick. The future didn't exist," he says. "I just wanted to go to these places that had this image of hedonism, reinvention and superficiality. I guess Vegas, LA and Florida are pretty much the key destinations for that." He also points out that this strategy is perhaps not as useless as it sounds. "Maybe it's a sort of short sharp shock therapy. You plunge completely into the unknown and you're forced to build up armour very quickly." In the rush to get over the pain of a broken heart, anything that seems like it might help is worth a try. The difference in the approaches of the sexes to being dumped is in the end fairly negligible, since none of them does any good. Time is the only healer for a broken heart, a process that is rather too slow for most of us, followed by falling in love again, a process that is entirely too unpredictable to be relied upon. Following his travels around the landscape of his own broken heart, Keeble has an alternative solution. "I recommend everybody goes out and writes a book. That's the way forward." But even years later, he can't look forward without a glance back. "Seven years and then you go and ask somebody to marry you and they say no. In Niagara Falls. It was pretty uncool."

webTitle: Rescued confirm ferry sank killing hundreds

fields.headline: Rescued confirm ferry sank killing hundreds
fields.trailText: Just as the search for survivors from a foundered Indonesian ferry was about to be called off yesterday, fishermen rescued 10 people who had survived for almost four days in the shark-infested waters by clinging to debris.
fields.body:
Just as the search for survivors from a foundered Indonesian ferry was about to be called off yesterday, fishermen rescued 10 people who had survived for almost four days in the shark-infested waters by clinging to debris.

The six men and four women, aged from 12 to 29, are the first to be found since the Cahaya Bahiri, which was carrying an estimated 500 people, disappeared on Thursday morning near Karakelong island, 120 miles north-east of its destination, Manado on Sulawesi island.

Contact with the Cahaya Bahiri (Light of the Ocean) was lost on Thursday, soon after its captain radioed that it was taking on water in a fierce storm off the north-east tip of Sulawesi. The ship was equipped with very few lifejackets and was licensed to carry 270 people.

Setio Rahardjo, head of Indonesia's search and rescue agency, said the survivors had confirmed that the wooden-hulled ferry, which left Tobelo on Halmahera island on Wednesday, sank after taking in water in rough seas.

There had been intense speculation about the fate of the ferry, which was packed with refugees fleeing sectarian fighting in the Moluccas, because search teams found no wreckage. On Friday a priest on Halmahera claimed that it had been hijacked by militant Muslim fighters and taken to a remote island.

The hopes of the hundreds of people waiting at Manado port for news of their loved ones were briefly raised after a rescue ship reported that it had spotted the vessel at anchor off a remote island. This turned out to be a different vessel.

"Until now we had been praying that the ship was still afloat," said John Girobus, whose mother was on board. "Now we know it has sunk and only a few people have been rescued. Everyone is very worried about their families."

Another relative waiting at the quayside, Anne Paneda, said she had escaped on a refugee ship a week ago but the rest of her family were on the missing ferry. "My husband and my two children had to take the boat . . . They're in the missing boat," she said, sobbing.

The ship was reported to be carrying about 30 people injured in an attack on Duma last week, during which more than 100 people, mainly Christians, were killed. Muslim militants stormed the village on Halmahera island, setting fire to a church.

It was one of the bloodiest clashes in the Moluccas, where more than 3,000 people have been killed in the past 18 months. The conflict intensified in May when hundreds of militant Muslims from Java and Sumatra in western Indonesia arrived on a holy war.

The Cahaya Bahiri's owners said the captain had been forced to take on many extra passengers because they were desperate to escape the bloodshed.

Mr Rahardjo said that the search, which was about to be called off when the survivors were found at 7am yesterday, would continue today, but that he was not optimistic about the chances of finding more people alive. The region's air force commander, Lieutenant Colonel Agus Barnas, said the search might be extended for three days.

One of those pulled from the water, Orpa Matayani, 18, told rescue officials in Manado that the ferry sank very rapidly after the hold, full of copra, started filling with water in very rough weather.

She said her group, all of them dehydrated, exhausted and sunburnt, survived by holding on to each other. She had no idea what happened to the other passengers.

The boat that found them, the Minahasa IX, took the survivors to Linrung town on the island of Selababu for medical treatment. One other body was pulled from the sea.

In Rome yesterday, the Pope expressed "great sorrow" for the victims, and prayed for peace in the Moluccas. Speaking to pilgrims in St. Peter's Square, he said of those presumed dead: "I pray that the Lord grant them their eternal reward and I invoke with all my force peace and security for those islands tormented by violence."

webTitle: A black day at Black Dyke as bandmaster quits

fields.headline: A black day at Black Dyke as bandmaster quits
fields.trailText: The world's most famous brass band has lost its musical director after a cut in sponsorship and a row over the merits of commuting from one end of the M1 to the other.
fields.body:
The world's most famous brass band has lost its musical director after a cut in sponsorship and a row over the merits of commuting from one end of the M1 to the other.

James Watson, who has won fresh laurels for the Black Dyke Mills band during an eight-year stint at its Bradford home, left "very suddenly" according to fellow-trustees, following proposals to appoint a more locally based assistant.

Mr Watson, who is also professor of trumpet at the Royal Academy of Music and a leading concert soloist, said yesterday that he was depressed and disappointed after facing a fait accompli at a board meeting which was "like a court martial".

He added: "The proposal for a local bandmaster was artistically unacceptable. It risks creating two grades of concert, A-stream and B-stream. But it was a done deal, I could see that.

"I've eaten, slept and breathed Black Dyke for eight years, not to mention driving half a million miles to rehearsals and concerts."

Mr Watson's energy has seen the band nominated for an Oscar for the score of Babe 2, provide theme music for the TV series Ground Force and Dinner Ladies, and tour to New York, Bermuda and Toronto.

He also imported social reform to Yorkshire from his home in Watford, facing down bitter opposition last year to the appointment of horn player Leslie Howie as the first woman musician in Black Dyke's 145-year history. "I lost 20 players in a matter of weeks over that," he said. "But we have four women out of 28 musicians now, and the atmosphere in the last six months has been happier."

The chairman of Black Dyke's trustees, Bradford wool merchant Sir James Hill, said Mr Watson was a great loss.

He added: "We wanted to make some changes but we also wanted him to stay, but he didn't want to discuss it. He resigned very quickly and suddenly."

The loss comes at a difficult time for Black Dyke, after the end of £500,000 sponsorship over six years from the Bradford and Bingley building society.

The band has appointed a new musical director, Nicholas Childs, the former principal conductor of the Fodens lorry works band.

Mr Watson said: "I am having to get get used to a gap in my life. I just realised that it's a month since I put petrol in my car, and the tank's still half full."
