fields.headline: Back in rude health
fields.standfirst: Castle makeover gives fountain a priapic boost
fields.trailText: The rudest fountain in England has been recreated, from fragments of shattered stone and a few 17th century scribbled drawings.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The rudest fountain in England has been recreated, from fragments of shattered stone and a few 17th century scribbled drawings.

The effect is so startling that it has been left out of the teaching packs sent to local schools.

"We've had to stick our neck out a bit," Lucy Worsley, the English Heritage buildings historian who researched Bolsover Castle, in Derbyshire, before the £3.6m restoration, and exposed it as a Jacobean party house on an epic scale.

The fountain was formally switched on this weekend, by Sir Neil Cossons, chairman of English Heritage, after at least two centuries of dereliction.

The fountain is the centrepiece of a garden built with "love seats" and "bowers of bliss". It is topped with the only surviving original figure, a rather lumpy Venus.

She now looks down on a ring of little boys in black marble, and a lower circle, hidden inside the basin of the fountain, of phallic heraldic beasts, grim Roman emperors, and baby satyrs clutching horrifed ducks and swans. All the figures spurt water, except the emperors.

The original design, which was never executed but survives in a 17th century sketch by the architect Robert Smithson, was even more eye-popping: half a dozen women in niches, each spurting water from a different orifice.

The castle was built by Charles Cavendish, and his son William.

The last inhabitant was a Victorian vicar, the Reverend Hamilton Gray, who planted cabbages in the bowers of bliss, whitewashed the rooms where William had written bawdy poetry, and averted his eyes from the "Virtues" wall paintings.

The restoration was completed with an £1.7 EU regional development grant.

webTitle: All washed up: a giant secret of the deep

fields.headline: All washed up: a giant secret of the deep
fields.trailText: They are one of the ocean's great mysteries. Researchers know them mostly by their beaks, or bits of tentacle. Whole servings are very rare.
fields.body:
They are one of the ocean's great mysteries. Researchers know them mostly by their beaks, or bits of tentacle. Whole servings are very rare.

But British Antarctic Survey scientist Amanda Lynnes looked out of a window from her research base on Signy Island to see freshly dead gigantic squid flopped on the shore, being torn to pieces by hungry giant petrels.

The mollusc was 2.3 metres (7ft 6in) to the tip of its longest tentacle, and it weighed 29kg (64lb). It was the largest whole specimen of Kondakovia longimana seen. Ms Lynnes will reveal her findings to a conference of cephalopod experts at Aberdeen today. "Most of the evidence we have comes from the vomit of whales, seals and seabirds," she said.

"What you see are the beaks, made of really hard material, and we find that in the vomit. And also poo. So it is very rare to find a whole specimen like that. We don't get to see them very often."

Small squid are everywhere. Big squid - there are 10 species more than 2 metres long - are harder to find.

Last year a US team went to New Zealand to seek the squid Mesonychoteuthis hamiltoni, a species reported to grow up to 18 metres long, and the variety most often pictured wrestling with sperm whales.That too is known only from beaks and occasional strandings.

webTitle: Hi-tech pointer to Welsh rebel's last resting place

fields.headline: Hi-tech pointer to Welsh rebel's last resting place
fields.trailText: Hi-tech ground mapping technology previously used by Channel 4's Time Team programme has given researchers renewed hope in their efforts to solve one of the enduring mysteries of Welsh history.
fields.body:
Hi-tech ground mapping technology previously used by Channel 4's Time Team programme has given researchers renewed hope in their efforts to solve one of the enduring mysteries of Welsh history.

For centuries scholars have puzzled over the likely burial place of Owain Glyndwr, the celebrated Welsh military leader who rose up in rebellion against the English crown and declared Wales' first parliament 600 years ago.

Details of Glyndwr's final days are shrouded in mystery. He was offered, but refused, a royal pardon and has long been thought to have died after going into hiding with his family in Herefordshire, then a Welsh-speaking area.

Now, a geophysical survey of an ancient monument in Herefordshire's Golden valley has found evidence of the remains of a religious building that could lend weight to the legend that the rebel was laid to rest there.

The survey, using ground radar and other non-invasive techniques, was carried out last week over a 400 square metre area at Monnington Court, near Vowchurch, by a Cardiff-based team of ground investigation specialists acting for the Owain Glyndwr society.

The society pinpointed the site last year after the burial place was reportedly divulged by John Scudamore, a descendant of Glyndwr's daughter, Alice. The Scudamore family, which supported Glyndwr's rebellion, and whose seat is at nearby Kentchurch Court, is said to have handed the secret down through successive generations.

Ironically, the suspected burial place of the one time Prince of Wales is now owned by his 21st century successor after it was acquired by the Duchy of Cornwall as part of a recent property deal.

Nick Russill, whose company, TerraDat, has previously conducted ground surveys for Channel 4 and BBC archaeology programmes, said the geophysical work carried out on the historic motte and bailey at Monnington Court had found unexpected evidence of a substantial stone building with walls a metre thick on top of the mound. The north-south alignment suggested it was a religious building.

"The survey was non-invasive. It did not show evidence of a burial site on the moat and bailey, but this does not necessarily rule one out," he said. "The discovery of the building adds more weight to the story. If you were to dig, the chances are you would find more than the survey revealed."

Tony Carter, the society's researcher, said yesterday he was encouraged by the survey. He is calling on English Heritage to carry out further investigations on the site.

"We are encouraged by what has been found because this fits in with our theories. This has taken us a step closer to solving the mystery of Glyndwr's resting place. It is an exciting day."

He said that if it could be proved Monnington Court was Glyndwr's burial place, the society would like to see some form of memorial erected on the site so that people could pay their respects to a "great statesman and military leader" of the day.

The society was not looking for any remains to be returned to Wales, he added.

The search for Glyndwr's last resting place comes at a time of intense interest in the rebel's story, as Wales prepares to mark the 600th anniversary of the start of his campaign in September 1400.

A dispute that made a prince

Glyndwr, a lord from the Welsh marches, fought for the English king, Richard II, against the Scots in the 1380s. He rebelled against Richard's successor, Henry IV, after a land dispute, and in September 1400 was proclaimed Prince of Wales.

His revolt, which received widespread support across Wales, resulted in the capture of Harlech and Aberystwyth. It culminated in Glyndwr calling his own parliament in Machynlleth in 1404.

As the rebellion began to falter Glyndwr sent letters to Charles VI, the King of France, in 1406, asking for military assistance. The so-called Pennal letters, named after the village near Machynlleth from where they were dispatched, set out what amounted to Gylndwr's manifesto for Wales, including the building of universities and the establishment of an independent church subject to the Pope in Avignon, rather than to the see of Canterbury.

With sporadic uprisings the rebellion did not die out completely until 1415. Glyndwr was offered, and refused, a pardon.

webTitle: Ousted editor joins a king of spin

fields.headline: Ousted editor joins a king of spin
fields.trailText: One of the most formidable partnerships in spin is launched today. Max Clifford has signed the former scourge of his top clients, the last editor of the News of the World, to his PR firm.
fields.body:
One of the most formidable partnerships in spin is launched today. Max Clifford has signed the former scourge of his top clients, the last editor of the News of the World, to his PR firm.

Phil Hall, who was cast aside a month ago to make way for the dynamic (and much younger) Rebekah Wade, could not have swapped sides in more spectacular style. "Max has made PR fashionable when it was once scorned," said Mr Hall, explaining the poacher-turned-gamekeeper move in his first interview since leaving the NoW.

Mr Hall's decision will leave editors quaking. There are few more experienced hands in the tabloid newspaper world: during 27 years in journalism, and in particular over the past five years, he has been involved many memorable stories.

During his tenure at the NoW, the paper brought down Lord Archer's ambitions to become mayor of London by revealing he persuaded a friend to lie on oath during a libel action; ended Lawrence Dallaglio's captaincy of the England rugby team with claims - of which he was later cleared - that he had taken and dealt in drugs; and revealed the improbable tale that Michael Jackson was to father a child.

Many of the stories were drawn from Mr Hall's personal contacts, but despite increasing the paper's market share and delivering a string of industry awards, he could not stem the newspaper's circulation decline. He was sacked when sales dipped below 4m.

In an interview with the Guardian, Mr Hall, 45, insisted that he felt no bitterness towards his former employers, who have furnished him with a handsome severance package. "I don't have to work for two years if I don't want to," he said. He was full of praise for Wade, 31, whom he claimed as a protege.

He starts work today at Max Clifford Associates - a somewhat misleading title, since the firm is effectively a one-man show - as a "media consultant". It is understood that he will be involved in the heart of the Clifford business.

Stories involving many of Mr Clifford's clients appeared in the NoW during Mr Hall's editorship, and the pair have become close friends. Mr Clifford, who has built up a £1m business over 30 years from his cramped offices in central London, said he was delighted that Mr Hall had agreed to join him.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Newspaper round-up
fields.body:
Observer

The government was secretly warned that five British car plants were in jeopardy along with tens of thousands of jobs in a union document passed to Tony Blair weeks before BMW dumped Rover .

Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, is expected to refuse to relinquish the contract its Connex rail arm has to run the London South Central franchise until 2003. Connex is one of the most reviled passenger rail operators.

Mail on Sunday

Tesco chief executive Terry Leahy is in talks to buy Real, Germany's biggest hypermarket chain, for £3bn. Real has 260 stores and is part of the pan-European food and retail group Metro.

Sunday Telegraph

Friends Provident is in line to pay windfalls of up to £1bn under plans being drawn up to float Eureko, the pan-European consortium of insurers in which it has a significant stake.

Virgin Group and London Electricity will this week launch an internet energy company and pledge to lower prices for gas and electricity to households.

BAE Systems, formerly British Aerospace, is expected to be named as the preferred bidder for Sanders, the US electronic warfare company, in a deal worth about $1.5bn

Sunday Times

Vickers Defence Systems is understood to be close to winning a tank order from Greece that could be worth up to £2.4bn.

The government is preparing a £100m aid package in an attempt to secure further investment in the Nissan car plant on Wearside, which is threatened by the strong pound.

Sunday Business

The government releases figures this week showing inward investment in Britain is booming, despite the strength of the sterling. The news is expected to add to the strain on pro-single currency ministers who have argued that Britain is failing to attract business while it stays out of the euro.

Financial services group Standard Chartered is in discussions with Chase Manhattan to acquire the US bank's Hong Kong retail business for up to £1bn.

Sunday Express

British Telecom handed over its entire national database of 23m business and personal customers to a tiny Doncaster-based computer company, Computer Data Preparation Services, according to the newspaper.

IoS

Vodafone, the world's biggest mobile phone company, faces the possibility of a shareholder revolt over its share incentive plan. Institutional investors said they plan to register a protest against decisions such as one-off £10m bonus for chief executive Chris Gent.

The Treasury may lose up to £800m over a plan from mobile phone group One2One to resolve the payment row that emerged in the government's auction of third generation licences. The dispute centres on deferred payment concessions Orange and Vodafone gained.

fields.headline: Oracle president resigns
fields.standfirst: Two lines spell end to reign at software powerhouse that set snoopers on Microsoft
fields.trailText: Oracle president Ray Lane has resigned - sparking speculation that his departure has been forced by last week's disclosure that the world's second biggest software company hired a detective agency to garner information on rival Microsoft.
fields.body:
Oracle president Ray Lane has resigned - sparking speculation that his departure has been forced by last week's disclosure that the world's second biggest software company hired a detective agency to garner information on rival Microsoft.

There was no official explanation for Mr Lane's sudden departure, which was announced in a terse two-line statement.

The company continued to insist last night that the move was not triggered by the news that it had snooped on organisations which supported Microsoft in its recent antitrust court case.

Oracle has denied knowledge of the detective agency's methods, which included sifting through rubbish bins.

But the timing of Mr Lane's resignation - coming just before this week's Independence Day holiday - has led to the assumption in Silicon Valley that he was being made a scapegoat for the company's embarrassment.

Mr Lane, 53, joined the company in 1992 from Booz Allen & Hamilton, a leading international management consultancy. He effectively ran the day to day business while Oracle's expansive chairman, Larry Ellison, led the strategic development - but was said to have taken more of a back seat in recent months.

Since his arrival, Oracle's annual revenues have soared from $1bn to almost $10bn, while its shares have jumped from less than $10 eight years ago to $84.06 at Friday's close. The price is now likely to come under heavy pressure.

Oracle's fourth quarter net profit leapt 76% to $926m, beating analysts' expectations, when it was announced last month. The company's shares have outperformed the Standard & Poor's business services index by more than 100% so far this year.

Analysts said Mr Lane was credited with turning the business round in the early 1990s after its earnings were hit by the discovery of inaccurate accounting for software sales.

This weekend's statement from Mr Ellison simply said Oracle was "grateful to Ray Lane for all of his efforts. He will be missed. We wish him nothing but the best." Mr Ellison is expected to act as president and chief operating officer until a replacement is found but Mr Lane will remain as a non-executive director on Oracle's board.

Mr Lane is among the most-wanted senior executives in Silicon Valley and has previously been tipped as a likely candidate for top jobs at Hewlett-Packard, Compaq Computer and Novell.

Last week, Oracle confirmed that it had hired Investigation Group International to look into the activities of two groups which supported Microsoft during the latter's antitrust trial. Microsoft was found to be operating in breach of competition laws and the court ordered its break up. Microsoft is appealing against the decision.

The investigation by Oracle of Microsoft's allies is the latest turn in the continuing rivalry between the two companies. Six years ago Oracle was simply a supplier of corporate database software - now it is a one of the key players in the e-commerce business.

Microsoft reacted to the snooping revelations by accusing Oracle of trying to "tarnish its image and invite government intervention."

Mr Ellison has denied any personal knowledge of the snooping on Microsoft until last week, but he took full responsibility for the company's actions.

webTitle: Trinity Mirror may join RIM fray

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror may join RIM fray
fields.trailText: Trinity Mirror is expected to decide this week whether to ask for regulatory permission to bid for Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post and 101 other regional newspapers.
fields.body:
Trinity Mirror is expected to decide this week whether to ask for regulatory permission to bid for Regional Independent Media, owner of the Yorkshire Post and 101 other regional newspapers.

Any decision by the publisher of the Mirror, Racing Post and regional titles such as the Liverpool Echo to seek the go-ahead from the Department of Trade and Industry to make a formal approach is likely to inflate the price tag, already in the region of £650m.

Two potential bidders for the privately owned, Leeds-based group have already emerged and Trinity Mirror is expected to be concerned about being lured into paying too much for the operation, which made £32m profits last year.

The US company Gannett, which owns regional newspaper group Newsquest, was first to ask the DTI about bidding for RIM, quickly followed by Johnson Press.

Bidders need approval from the regulators because of rules governing media ownership of paid-circulation newspapers.

All three groups recently took part in the £450m battle for control of News Communication and Media (Newscom), which fell to Newsquest.

The involvement of Trinity Mirror, which refused to comment last night, was taken as an indication of its desire to boost its presence in the rapidly consolidating regional newspaper industry and as a sign that it was cautious about the levels at which deals were being struck.

RIM has appointed investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston to review all its options, which are said to include a stock market flotation. However, because the regulatory process can take up to four months, Chris Oakley, the chief executive, has said the outcome of the situation is unlikely to be known until the autumn.

Industry experts, citing the experience of the tussle for Newscom, believe that the DTI might again allow a free-for-all to decide control of RIM.

Created in 1998 as a buyout of United News & Media's regional newspaper assets, RIM is 50% owned by venture capitalist Candover, with other stakes held by investment bank Goldman Sachs and Alpinvest, a Dutch venture capital group.

The group bought the business for £360m and could be on track to double its investment in two years, the period of time when venture capitalists begin to look for ways to realise their investments.

The jewel in the crown of the RIM group is the Yorkshire Post, which was founded in 1754 as the Leeds Intelligencer.

In addition to newspapers, the group has interests in websites and a shareholding in Fish 4, a regional press classified advertising database.

fields.headline: Leslie Wilkins
fields.standfirst: Statistician and criminologist curious about the causes of crime
fields.trailText: Professor Leslie Wilkins, statistician and criminologist, who has died aged 85, began his career in the second world war at the Air Ministry. The techniques he pioneered there, analysing aircraft accidents, provided the methodological basis for a devotion to criminology, first at the Home Office, then in the US.
fields.body:
Professor Leslie Wilkins, statistician and criminologist, who has died aged 85, began his career in the second world war at the Air Ministry. The techniques he pioneered there, analysing aircraft accidents, provided the methodological basis for a devotion to criminology, first at the Home Office, then in the US.

Wilkins was brought up in in Hampshire, educated locally, and learned about statistics at evening classes while working in the aircraft industry. His expertise in statistics took him to lead an Air Ministry team, specialising in operational research which had a longterm effect on aircraft safety. Wilkins said that the search for a scapegoat to blame got in the way of preventing air accidents; he realised that blame had to be taken out of the equation to prevent accidents - or crime.

Walkins became one of the first to develop "pattern recognition". He assessed flying hours on a particular plane, as opposed to total flying hours; he looked at take-offs and landings (where most accidents happen), he checked instrument design. He noted that tail-gunners had a good survival rate in crashes because they faced backward. Crucially, he realised that the most obvious answer was not, in fact, the most important. This insight he later brought to the study of criminal justice.

After the war, Wilkins joined the government's social survey and, in 1948, received the Royal Society's Francis Wood Memorial Prize for his survey methods, having correctly predicted the percentage of soldiers entitled to the Victory Medal who would actually claim it - saving the Exchequer a lot of money - and beginning market research. Another less successful survey taught a significant lesson. He was asked to forecast how much people would spend on gambling if controls were lifted: one of his assistants came up with £10 per week per family, when average weekly family income was about £12. Wilkins was sceptical. His inquiry revealed that an assistant, told to interview people at random, had worked the platform at Liverpool Street station which served Newmarket and its racecourse.

Under the 1948 Criminal Justice Act, the Home Secretary could make criminological research grants. The first went to Wilkins and Herman Mannheim, at the London School of Economics, to predict the recidivism rate of Borstal boys. Their book, Prediction Methods In Relation To Borstal Training, is a classic tool of criminological analysis. Today's risk assessments in probation and parole are its direct result.

In the early 60s, Wilkins, then deputy director of the Home Office research unit, resigned. His ideas about crime and its causes had not met with much favour, while his advice that the criminalisation of drug use would feed the black market and the power of organised crime had been officially rejected. He worked for the UN Institute in Tokyo and then emigrated to the School of Criminology at Berkeley, California, before moving to the University of Albany in 1969. He developed the Federal Parole Board's decision guidelines and, more controversially, federal sentencing guidelines. These became the basis for sentencing guidelines in many states.

Wilkins kept returning to his wartime experience . In his book Social Deviance (1964), he applied his operational research approach to criminality. Before Wilkins, the tradition was to look for the reason individuals committed crimes. Wilkins pointed out that that approach did not explain why a crime takes place. He saw both the genesis of crime and the workings of criminal justice as - to use a Wilkins word - an analogue of a complex operating system. If you wanted to stop crime you must understand the system and intervene where most effective. His work on time series, deviance amplification and decision theory has been nearly as influential as his work on risk and process.

Leslie Wilkins was a great teacher and mentor to those who studied under him. He is survived by his wife Barbara, two sons and two daughters.

 Leslie Wilkins, statistician and criminologist, born March 8 1915; died May 8 2000

fields.headline: Genghis Khan rallies Mongolia's voters
fields.trailText: Mongolia went to the polls yesterday in an election that has been strong on democracy but weak on solutions for the country's devastated economy.
fields.body:
Mongolia went to the polls yesterday in an election that has been strong on democracy but weak on solutions for the country's devastated economy.

Nomadic herdsmen, many of whom lost most of their livestock in this year's severe winter, travelled many miles to cast their ballots.

The Democratic Union coalition, weakened by infighting and economic paralysis, was strongly challenged by the former communist Mongolian People's Revolutionary party (MPRP).

The MPRP's popular leader, Nambariin Enkhbayar, denounced the government for "serving not the people of Mongolia but small groups of business people and politicians".

In 1998 the coalition was disrupted by controversies leading to three changes of administration and prime minister.

Mr Enkhbayar, 42, says he is an admirer of Britain's New Labour and has promised more jobs, free education and higher public service wages.

His eve-of-poll rally in Ulan Bator featured rock stars dressed in Genghis Khan warrior outfits. They paraded on horseback on a large stage in the Soviet-style former party headquarters.

The MPRP added glamour by enlisting the help of the Spice Girls of the steppes - an all-girl band called Lipstick. The group signed an exclusive contract to play at MPRP rallies, where they sang and danced with Mr Enkhbayar.

But Ganaa, Gerlee, Degi and Ichko said they would not vote for the new-look Communist party, which ruled Mongolia for 75 years until it was swept from power by the democratic coalition in a 1996 election.

"Democracy has given us a lot," said Gerlee, 21. "It has given us the chance to sing and dance the way we want to."

Mongolians have taken to democracy enthusiastically: in the 1996 election the turnout was 90%. There are twice as many candidates and parties for the current election to the parliament, the Great Hural.

Most of the economy has been privatised, apart from such big state-owned companies as a copper mine and the national airline. Ulan Bator is a lively capital thriving on an extensive black economy.

The winter of extreme frost and snowstorms known as the Zud, which devastated livestock, pushed up inflation, to an annual rate of 14.2% by the end of April. The price of meat has risen by 36% in the past quarter and has doubled since the beginning of 1999.

More deaths are expected in the malnourished herds, because the grasslands have been denuded by overgrazing since the end of collective farming.

Many nomad communities were chronically under-nourished even before the Zud.

A 1997 survey showed that more than one in five children under five was seriously under-nourished, and more than a third showed clinical symptoms of rickets.

Mongolia has moved from ultra-Stalinism during the long decades in the Soviet camp to an assertive democracy which nourishes national pride more successfully than it feeds the population.

Progress towards strengthening democracy has been assisted by several projects for legal and institutional reform sponsored by the UN commission for human rights.

The high commissioner, Mary Robinson, is expected to visit next month, when Ulan Bator hosts a regional meeting on human rights in north-east Asia. She can expect a much warmer reception than she received in neighbouring China last year.

webTitle: Dolphins dying out in sick Indus

fields.headline: Dolphins dying out in sick Indus
fields.trailText: One of the world's rarest species of dolphin is dying off because one of the world's biggest irrigation systems has reduced its habitat in the Indus River in Pakistan.
fields.body:
One of the world's rarest species of dolphin is dying off because one of the world's biggest irrigation systems has reduced its habitat in the Indus River in Pakistan.

The Sukkur barrage, a monument to British engineering completed in 1932 and feeding 3.2m hectares (8m acres) of farmland, is one reason why no more than 500, and perhaps as few as 350, of the blind Indus River dolphins may be left.

It and other irrigation works upstream have shrunk the dolphins' habitat and reduced its gene pool, leaving the population vulnerable to disease and worsening and a growing burden of untreated sewage, illegal pesticides and industrial waste.

"The Indus River dolphin is the animal we can least afford to lose in Pakistan," said Richard Garstang, a conservation adviser at WWF Pakistan. "The threat is very real. The population could crash at any time."

The dolphin, known locally as the bhulan, swam freely in the river for millions of years. But the population became fragmented when engineers began to carve up the river with irrigation projects at the beginning of the 20th century.

In the past five years the population has stopped growing, and scientists fear that pollution may have caused genetic problems, or harmed the animal's reproductive system.

"There has been a progressive reduction of the plasticity of the gene pool, so that if something comes along like a bug in the water then everyone of them could be susceptible and the population would crash," Mr Garstang said. "The genetic capacity to adapt to change is reduced. We don't know how long they have left."

The dolphins also suffer from human predation. Many are trapped in nets and fishermen defy the threat of fines to use dolphin bile as bait. Others are killed for their oil, which is sold as a cure for arthritis.

Up to 20 a year are caught in the thousands of miles of irrigation canals, which are closed and left to dry out once a year.

Fishermen kill them in canals, fearing that may eat the fish stocks. Recently the body of a dolphin was recovered riddled with bullets.

"We still need to do scientific research to determine the exact problem with the dolphin, but we don't have the funds," said Hussain Bux Bhaagat, deputy conservator of wildlife for Sind. "This animal must live."

It is becoming clear that the dolphins' problems are a warning that the Indus itself is sick. Decades of extensive irrigation has drained the river of water and allowed the sea to intrude northwards.

Agricultural land near the coast has become infertile and mangrove forests are dying. In some areas the water is too shallow for the dolphins to swim.

"The river is shrinking," said Tahir Qureshi, head of the coastal ecosystem unit at the IUCN, the world conservation union. "There is no management, the authorities don't have the funds."

webTitle: Police accused of dirty war against Nepal's Maoist guerrillas

fields.headline: Police accused of dirty war against Nepal's Maoist guerrillas
fields.standfirst: Executions and atrocities mark battle against rebels
fields.trailText: They arrived at Rama Yadav's house at night, locked his children in the kitchen and seized his cashbox. Then the Maoist rebels who have been fighting the Nepalese state for four years fled to a nearby village.
fields.body:
They arrived at Rama Yadav's house at night, locked his children in the kitchen and seized his cashbox. Then the Maoist rebels who have been fighting the Nepalese state for four years fled to a nearby village.

The police caught up with them there. Six rebels unwisely took shelter in a house. The police set light to it. In the gun battle that followed all the rebels were shot dead except one - 17-year-old Bhagwati Chaudhary.

According to human rights agencies, the police interrogated her, then shot her.

That summary execution last month is just the latest example of extra-judicial killing in Nepal.

Since 1996 the authorities have been struggling to contain the growing communist insurgency in the remote mid-west of what was once a peaceful Himalayan kingdom. At least 1,500 people have been killed, two thirds of them by the Nepalese police.

"We have very clear evidence that extra-judicial killing is going on," Krishna Pahadi of the Human Rights and Peace Society said. "If the police suspect someone of being a Maoist they simply kill them."

The situation has become so grave that the European Union recently intervened for the first time, urging the Nepalese government not to violate human rights and to begin talks with the Maoist rebels.

Nepal's hardline prime minister, Girja Koirala, who came to power in March advocating a military solution to the Maoist problem, now appears to have responded to international pressure.

"There is no alternative to talks," he said. But his critics say he is not serious about negotiation.

The Maoists have also been responsible for a series of outrages. Two months ago they beheaded a suspected informer, leaving the victim's head in a tree. Two weeks ago they killed 21 people, including 12 policemen, during a gunfight in the Jarjarkot district of western Nepal.

They have ruthlessly eliminated supporters of the ruling Nepali Congress and other rival parties. About 1.5m of Nepal's 20m people now live under their control, in what amounts to a de facto state run from the hill district of Rolpa.

Active also in several districts in the east of Nepal, they have an army of between 3,000 and 5,000 troops, armed with homemade guns and primitive bombs.

Successive governments in Katmandu have been slow to respond to the crisis. Earlier this month 150 refugees from the west of Nepal arrived in Katmandu after a gruelling 26-day trek, seeking government protection. They say that their MPs are now too scared to live in the districts they represent.

"We have become victims of both police and Maoist guerrillas. In the eyes of police, we are the supporter of Maoist and in the eyes of Maoist guerrillas we are informers to the police," Him Bahadur Budha, from Rolpa, said.

The insurgency is masterminded by Prachanda, the general secretary of the underground Maoist Communist party. His aim is to overthrow Nepal's constitutional monarchy and replace it with a Maoist republic.

The group, which began its uprising in February 1996, has links with other revolutionary groups. In Maoist villages, where the red flag flies, Prachanda has introduced collective farming. His cadres collect taxes and impose justice.

The former MP Padma Ratna Tuladhar, who has been asked by the prime minister to negotiate with the rebels, said yesterday that he was "pessimistic" that the conflict could be swiftly resolved.

Before sitting down to talks, the Maoists want the police to account for more than 40 supporters who have disappeared while in custody.

Before his government collapsed under the pressure of the Maoist problem, the former prime minister Krishna Bhattarai said that many of the detainees had been executed without trial.

The Maoists' paper, Janesh, recently conceded that some members had grown corrupt. The movement was going through a period of "critical self-evaluation", it said.

But in many areas the Maoists continue to enjoy popular support. In the village of Kara, for example, which the police burned to the ground last year, the son of a prominent politician kidnapped by the Maoists has been put to work as a stonemason.

Pitamber Sharma, of the Integrated Centre for Mountain Development, said yesterday that only economic reform could stop the insurgency.

"In the mountains 60-65% live below the poverty line. There is no electricity, no television and no transport," he said. "I don't see any prospect of the Maoists taking over Nepal. But if conditions continue as they do, we are going to create a situation of protracted civil war."

fields.headline: Don't scrap the factory yet
fields.trailText: Given recent concerns for the future of jobs at places such as Longbridge, Dagenham and now Nissan in Sunderland, it is past time Britain diagnosed the real reasons for the erosion of its manufacturing base.
fields.body:
Given recent concerns for the future of jobs at places such as Longbridge, Dagenham and now Nissan in Sunderland, it is past time Britain diagnosed the real reasons for the erosion of its manufacturing base.

One is the notion that in the digital age manufacturing no longer matters. Almost everyone who influences policy-making has come to believe manufacturing industries are inexorably destined to migrate to the second and third worlds. The strategy for Britain is said to be to withdraw as quickly and painlessly as possible and to move to supposedly more lucrative businesses in such fields as computer software, entertainment, and financial services.

That is a ludicrously superficial misreading of modern economic trends. The post-industrialists don't understand what modern manufacturing is. To them, the archetypal form of manufacturing these days is the sort of low-grade work carried out in the sweatshops of the third world.

Sweatshops are highly unrepresentative of modern manufacturing in that they are extremely labour-intensive. With investment rates as high as $500,000 or more per worker, advanced areas of manufacturing in countries such as Germany, Japan, and Switzerland can be astoundingly capital-intensive. Typical of modern advanced manufacturing are the hi-tech factories that make the miniaturised components and ultra-pure materials used in the electronics industry.

A commitment to advanced manufacturing produces many benefits of which the most obvious is a wide range of jobs. Whereas post-industrial businesses provide jobs mainly for people among the most intelligent 10% of the population, even the most advanced areas of manufacturing provide jobs for people of almost every level of capability.

A second point for manufacturing, and particularly advanced manufacturing, is that it generally does far more for a nation's balance of payments than do post-industrial businesses. Whereas post-industrial products typically entail a strong cultural element, most manufactured products are culture-neutral. This is particularly likely to be true of the higher levels such as production of hi-tech materials and components.

Manufacturing's export strength is notably apparent in such electronic components as liquid crystal displays (LCDs). The Japanese, who dominate in this business, export as much as 80% of their output. The reason is clear: LCDs can be used without adaptation by consumers all over the world.

Contrast that with a typical post-industrial business such as computer software. Even mighty Microsoft's exports from the United States account for only 25% of total sales, reflecting the fact that most of its products need substantial adaptation to fit the culture of foreign markets. An additional problem - shared by many other post-industrial businesses - is that its products are easily copied and therefore heavily pirated in many export markets.

A third advantage of advanced manufacturing is that it pays high wages. This is a reflection of the fact that its workers are typically backed by large amounts of capital and proprietary production knowhow. These greatly enhance workers' productivity, and greater productivity is the royal road to higher wages.

The proof lies in international economic statistics. Almost without exception, countries with the highest per capita incomes are noted for their strong manufacturing bases. In particular, of the 13 countries that at last count exceeded Britain in wages at market exchange rates, all but two exceeded us also in the proportion of their workforces they devoted to manufacturing.

Even that ultimate exemplar of post-industrialism, the United States, has been losing out rapidly in the wages league table to manufacturing countries. With the dollar down dramatically on balance against most major currencies in the past 10 years, the US is now exceeded in wage rates by six countries: Japan, Switzerland, Germany, Sweden, Denmark and Austria. In each case, they devote a much larger share of their workforces to manufacturing than does the US.

For Britain, the message is clear: the way forward for manufacturing is to increase its capital intensity and knowhow intensity. On both counts, policymakers can do much to help. But they probably will not do so if they continue to imagine manufacturing is yesterday's business.

 Eamonn Fingleton is author of In Praise of Hard Industries: Why Manufacturing, Not the Information Economy is the Key to Future Prosperity, published by Orion Books

fields.headline: Doris Drown
fields.standfirst: Pioneer of the organisation that became Mencap
fields.trailText: In 1948, Doris Drown, who has died aged 93, was told that her third son, Derek, was an "ineducable imbecile". In those days such children were usually put away in an institution or hidden away at home. But Drown was convinced that people with a mental handicap deserved at least as much as everyone else and pioneered setting up organisations to campaign for mental health care. In 1954 she was the first mother to appear on television to talk about her mentally handicapped child.
fields.body:
In 1948, Doris Drown, who has died aged 93, was told that her third son, Derek, was an "ineducable imbecile". In those days such children were usually put away in an institution or hidden away at home. But Drown was convinced that people with a mental handicap deserved at least as much as everyone else and pioneered setting up organisations to campaign for mental health care. In 1954 she was the first mother to appear on television to talk about her mentally handicapped child.

When Drown was told about Derek, almost no help was available and there was no direct way of finding other parents in the same predicament. Undeterred, she gradually contacted local families, equally isolated and desperate, and helped set up the Association for Parents of Backward Children. In 1955 it was renamed the National Society for Mentally Handicapped Children, and in 1980 became the Royal Society for Mentally Handicapped Children and Adults (Mencap).

Drown was brought up by her mother - a lone parent after her father left home - and went to schools in West Hampstead. She qualified as a teacher at Avery Hill College, London, and taught in King's Cross until her marriage in 1930; teachers then were expected to be single. Teaching gave her valuable experience which she drew on when starting the first co-operative school for the mentally handicapped in 1950. Housed in a Kensal Rise church hall, it was dependent on donations, and subscriptions from the children's families. In that then poor area of north London, payments were not always maintained, but Drown managed to persuade local government to fund training centres.

In 1952, she asked an artist friend to design a charity Christmas card . The national card scheme became so profitable it funded a large expansion of the charity's work.

When her son Derek was 18, Drown moved him on doctor's advice to Cell Barnes Hospital, a long-stay unit in St Albans. Drown found the separation painful and was often in tears after early visits. But she became active in the hospital's friends group and later promoted the Cell Barnes Trust, to find visitors for residents.

Her work continued for decades and she became vice-chairman of Mencap, while still chairing her local Willesden association. When she was in her seventies, she started taking hospital residents, who had never had a normal holiday, away for a week at the seaside; she overcame prejudice and turned the trip into an annual event. Drown resisted Conservative governmental plans of the 80s for "care in the community", even though the programme had developed as a result of her early attempts to get wider acceptance in the community for those with mental handicap. The programme threatened Derek's settled life, since long-stay hospitals such as Cell Barnes were under threat of closure. Drown understood that people would be more vulnerable out in the community and have less access to many of the projects that had been developed on hospital sites.

As her opposition to care in the community increased, she found herself at odds with Mencap and in 1985 she joined Rescare, a charity devoted to maintaining a wider choice for the mentally handicapped in need of permanent support. She started its welfare arm, and became its honorary life vice-president. Her involvement followed naturally from her conviction that professional orthodoxy was beginning to outweigh the feelings of parents in decisions affecting people unable to lead a normal independent life.

Drown's husband, Dudley, who campaigned with her, died in 1973. Her final years of ill-health were lightened by the knowledge that Derek was happy and well cared for in a Mencap home.

She is also survived by two other sons, David and Duncan.

 Doris Kate Drown, campaigner, born June 12 1906; died May 27 2000

As her opposition to care in the community increased, she found herself at odds with Mencap and in 1985 she joined Rescare, a charity devoted to maintaining a wider choice for the mentally handicapped in need of permanent support. She started its welfare arm, and became its honorary life vice-president. Her involvement followed naturally from her conviction that professional orthodoxy was beginning to outweigh the feelings of parents in decisions affecting people unable to lead a normal independent life. Drown's husband, Dudley, who campaigned with her, died in 1973. Her final years of ill-health were lightened by the knowledge that Derek was happy and well cared for in a Mencap home. She is also survived by two other sons, David and Duncan.  Doris Kate Drown, campaigner, born June 12 1906; died May 27 2000
